``6c. After section 29 of the Principal Act the following Part is inserted:
`PART 4-REFERENDUM TO CHOOSE ELECTORAL SYSTEM
Definitions
`30. In this Part, unless the contrary intention appears:
``declaration vote'' means any of the following:
(a) a postal vote;
(b) a pre-poll vote;
(c) an absent vote;
(d) a provisional vote;
``election ballot paper'' means a ballot paper for the election;
``referendum'' means the referendum referred to in section 31;
``referendum ballot paper'' means a ballot paper for the referendum;
``the election'' means the election whose polling day is the same day as voting day for the referendum;
``voting day'' means the day when the votes are to be taken for the purposes of the referendum.
Referendum to choose electoral system
`31. (1) A referendum is to be held to enable the electors of the Territory to choose which of 2 voting systems is to be used at future elections.

`(2) The 2 systems are the single member electorates system and the proportional representation (Hare-Clark) system, more fully described in the Referendum Options Description Sheet set out in Schedule 3.
`(3) Votes for the purposes of the referendum are to be taken on the same day as polling day for the next general election to be held after the commencement of this Part.
Administration
`32. (1) The Electoral Commission is to conduct the referendum.
`(2) A person who holds an office or appointment under this Act for the purposes of the election is taken to hold that office or appointment also for the purposes of the referendum.

`(3) The Electoral Commission may, on behalf of the Commonwealth, engage such temporary staff as it thinks necessary for the purposes of the referendum. A person so engaged is taken to be an officer for the purposes of this Part.
`(4) The Australian Capital Territory Electoral Officer may give directions to officers about the conduct of the referendum on matters not provided for by or under this Part.
Distribution to electors of Referendum Options Description Sheet and arguments for and
against different options

`33. (1) The Electoral Commissioner must, not later than 14 days before voting day, cause to be printed and to be posted to each elector, as nearly as practicable, a copy of the Referendum Options Description Sheet set out in Schedule 3.
`(2) The Electoral Commissioner must:
(a) print the Referendum Options Description Sheet so that the descriptions of the 2 systems appear side by side in 2 vertical columns; and
(b) determine by lot which option is to occupy the left-hand vertical column in the Sheet and print the Sheet accordingly.
`(3) If, within 2 weeks after the commencement of this Part, there is forwarded to the Electoral Commissioner:
(a) an argument in support of the single member electorates system option, consisting of not more than 2,000 words, authorised by the Minister; or

(b) an argument in support of the other option, consisting of not more than 2,000 words, authorised by the Leader of the Opposition in the House of Representatives and the Leader of the Australian Democrats in the Parliament;
the Electoral Commissioner must, not later than 14 days before voting day, cause to be printed and to be posted to each elector, as nearly as practicable, a pamphlet containing the argument.
`(4) If both arguments are forwarded to the Electoral Commissioner in accordance with subsection (3), the Electoral Commissioner must:
(a) print both arguments in the same pamphlet; and

(b) print those arguments side by side in 2 vertical columns, so that the left-hand column is occupied by the argument in support of the option whose description occupies the left-hand column in the Referendum Options Description Sheet.
`(5) The Commonwealth and the Territory must not spend money in respect of the presentation of the argument in support of either of the options except in relation to:

(a) the preparation, printing and distribution of the Sheet and pamphlet referred to in this section, or the preparation and distribution of translations into other languages of material contained in that Sheet and pamphlet;
(b) the preparation and distribution of presentations of that material in forms suitable for the visually impaired;
(c) the provision by the Electoral Commission of other information relating to either of the options; or

(d) the salaries and allowances of members of the Parliament, of members of the staff of members of the Parliament, of members of the Legislative Assembly, of members of the staff of members of the Legislative Assembly, or of persons who are officers or employees within the meaning of the Public Service Act 1922.
Entitlement to vote
`34. (1) A person is entitled to vote at the referendum if he or she is entitled to vote at the election.
`(2) A person must not vote more than once at the referendum.
Compulsory voting
`35. (1) A person who:
(a) is entitled to vote at the referendum; and
(b) fails to vote at the referendum without a valid and sufficient reason for the failure;
is guilty of an offence punishable, upon conviction, by a fine not exceeding $50.
`(2) Subsection (1) does not apply to an Antarctic elector or an eligible Territory overseas elector.
Ballot papers
`36. (1) The ballot papers are to be in the alternative formats set out in Schedule 4, one format with one option appearing first, the other format with the other option appearing first.

`(2) So far as is practicable, ballot papers are to be issued to voters so that no 2 consecutive voters at a particular place where ballot papers are issued will receive ballot papers of the same format.
`(3) Ballot papers are to bear an official mark approved by the Electoral Commission by notice published in the Commonwealth Gazette.
Scrutineers
`37. (1) Subject to subsection (2), a person appointed as a scrutineer for the election is taken also to be appointed for the referendum.
`(2) At each place where referendum ballot papers are being counted, the number of scrutineers for a candidate must not exceed the number of officers engaged in the counting.
Procedures for polling
`38. (1) The same polling booths are to be used for the election and the referendum.
`(2) The same ballot boxes may be used for the election and the referendum.
`(3) The hours of polling for the referendum are to be the same as for the election (including any adjournment or resumption of polling).
`(4) Subject to subsection (6), a person must be issued with a referendum ballot paper at the same time as he or she is issued with an election ballot paper.

`(5) The provisions of the Electoral Act relating to the issue of fresh election ballot papers in substitution for spoilt election ballot papers apply in the same way in relation to referendum ballot papers.
`(6) A person who is issued with a fresh election ballot paper because the ballot paper has been spoilt need not be issued with a fresh referendum ballot paper.
`(7) A voter who is entitled to assistance in marking an election ballot paper is entitled to the same assistance in marking a referendum ballot paper.
`(8) A person who casts a vote (other than a declaration vote) for the election must cast his or her vote for the referendum in the same way.
Declaration voting
`39. (1) A person who casts a declaration vote for the election must cast his or her vote for the referendum in the same way.
`(2) The marked referendum ballot paper of a declaration voter must be placed in the same envelope as the election ballot paper.

`(3) The referendum ballot paper of a declaration voter is to be admitted to further scrutiny for the referendum if, and only if, the election ballot paper is admitted to further scrutiny for the election.
`(4) A voter who is entitled to assistance in casting a declaration vote for the election is entitled to the same assistance in casting a declaration vote for the referendum.
Marking a ballot paper
`40. A voter must mark his or her ballot paper in accordance with the directions on it.
Informal ballot papers
`41. (1) A ballot paper is informal if, and only if:
(a) it:
(i) does not bear the official mark; or
(ii) is not authenticated by the initials of the issuing officer;
and the Australian Capital Territory Electoral Officer is not satisfied that it is an authentic ballot paper; or
(b) it has no vote marked on it or the voter's intention is not clear; or

(c) it has on it any mark or writing (other than a mark or writing authorised by law or placed on the ballot paper by an officer) by which, in the opinion of the Australian Capital Territory Electoral Officer, the voter can be identified.
`(2) Effect is to be given to a ballot paper according to the voter's intention, so far as that intention is clear.
Scrutiny
`42. The Australian Capital Territory Electoral Officer must:
(a) cause the number of votes in favour of each option, and the number of informal votes, to be counted; and
(b) as soon as practicable after the count is concluded, publish a notice in the Commonwealth Gazette setting out the numbers so counted.
Close of the polling in Antarctica
`43. The procedure on and after the close of the poll in Antarctica is the same for the referendum as for the election.
General offences
`44. (1) The provisions of the Electoral Act creating offences in relation to the election apply in the same way, subject to paragraph (2) (b), in relation to the referendum.
`(2) For the purposes of subsection (1):
(a) the relevant period defined in section 322 of that Act is the same period for the referendum as for the election; and

(b) ``electoral matter'' means matter that is intended or likely to affect voting in the referendum, and includes any matter that contains an express or implied reference to the referendum or to either of the options.
Bribery
`45. (1) A person must not give or confer, or promise or offer to give or confer, any property or benefit of any kind to another person:
(a) in order to influence the vote of any person at the referendum; or
(b) in order to induce any person not to vote at the referendum.
Penalty: Imprisonment for two years.
`(2) Subsection (1) does not apply in relation to a declaration of public policy or a promise of public action.
Badges or emblems in polling booths

`46. An officer or scrutineer who wears or displays in a polling booth on voting day any badge or emblem in support of or in opposition to either of the options is guilty of an offence. Penalty: $1,000.
Errors, etc.

`47. The provisions of the Electoral Act providing for the correction of delays, errors and omissions, and the extension of times, in relation to the election apply in the same way in relation to the referendum.
Disputed Returns
`48. (1) The validity of the referendum or of any statement showing the voting at the referendum may be disputed in accordance with this section and not otherwise.

`(2) The validity of the referendum or of any statement showing the voting at the referendum may be disputed by a person who was qualified to vote at the referendum by petition addressed to the Supreme Court of the Australian Capital Territory.
`(3) For the purposes of such a dispute, Part VIII of the Referendum (Machinery Provisions) Act 1984 applies with the necessary changes.
`(4) In particular, that Act applies for the purposes of this section as if:
(a) references to the High Court were references to the Australian Capital Territory Supreme Court; and
(b) the reference in paragraph 101 (1) (c) of that Act to the various Attorneys-General were a reference to the petitioner; and
(c) references to the Electoral Commissioner or to an Electoral Officer were references to the Australian Capital Territory Electoral Officer; and
(d) section 105 of that Act were omitted; and
(e) the reference in section 106 of that Act to the Commonwealth, a State or the Northern Territory were omitted; and
(f) the reference in paragraph 107a (a) of that Act to Schedule 4 were a reference to Schedule 3 to the Electoral Act; and
(g) the references to that Act and the regulations were references to the law relating to the referendum.
`(5) The referendum or any statement showing the voting at the referendum is not invalidated merely because the Electoral Commissioner may not have strictly complied with a provision of section 33.
Regulations

`49. The regulations may prescribe all matters necessary or convenient to be prescribed for carrying out or giving effect to this Part and, in particular, prescribe penalties not exceeding $500 for offences against those regulations.'.''.

REFERENDUM OPTIONS DESCRIPTION SHEET
COMMONWEALTH OF AUSTRALIA
Referendum Options Description Sheet

The following brief descriptions of a model single member electorates system and a model proportional representation (Hare-Clark) system have been prepared to assist ACT electors to determine their preferred electoral system.
MODEL SINGLE MEMBER ELECTORATES SYSTEM
* The ACT will be divided into 17 separate electorates. Each electorate will elect one member to the Legislative Assembly.
* No candidate will be allowed to stand in more than one electorate at a general election.
* The ballot paper used will look like this:
[THE DIAGRAM IS OMITTED FROM THE DATABASE; SEE HARDCOPY PAGE 4745]
* Voting will take place in each electorate in accordance with the system of voting used to elect members of the House of Representatives.
- Instructions on the ballot paper will require voters to show preferences (1, 2 and so on) for all of the candidates standing in the electorate.
- Candidates to be elected will have to receive a majority (ie 50% plus 1) of the formal votes in the electorate.

- If no candidate has obtained a majority of votes after first preference votes have been counted, the candidate with the fewest votes will be excluded and his or her votes will be transferred to the remaining candidates who stood next highest in the relevant voters' preferences.
- This process of excluding candidates with the fewest votes will continue until one candidate has obtained a majority of the votes still in the count.
* If a member dies, or resigns, or otherwise vacates his or her seat, the vacancy will be filled by a by-election in his or her electorate.

* The boundaries of electorates will be drawn by bodies independent of the Commonwealth and ACT governments. The criteria which govern the drawing of the boundaries of House of Representatives divisions will apply as nearly as practicable to the drawing of the boundaries of Legislative Assembly electorates.
* A redrawing of boundaries should take place in the first 12 months after each general election of members of the Legislative Assembly.
MODEL PROPORTIONAL REPRESENTATION (HARE-CLARK) SYSTEM
* The ACT will be divided into 3 separate electorates, of which two will elect 5 members each, and one will elect 7 members, to the Legislative Assembly.
* No candidate will be allowed to stand in more than one electorate at a general election.
* The ballot paper used will look like this:
[THE DIAGRAM IS OMITTED FROM THE DATABASE; SEE HARDCOPY PAGE 4746]

* The names of candidates within party groups will not be printed in the same position within the group on every ballot paper. Instead, a particular candidate's name will be printed at the top of the group on some ballot papers, in the second position within the group on other ballot papers and so on, so as to share out the positions.
* The same principle will apply to the printing of independent candidates' names in the column for independents on the ballot paper.

* Instructions on the ballot paper will require voters to show preferences (1, 2 and so on) for as many candidates as there are vacancies to be filled in the electorate concerned. Voters will have the option of showing as many further preferences as they wish. Seats will then be allocated to the candidates using the Hare-Clark system of proportional representation, as used at elections for the Tasmanian House of Assembly:

- Candidates will have to achieve a quota of votes in order to be elected. The quota will be determined by dividing the number of formal votes by 1 more than the number of vacancies to be filled, and adding 1 to the number so obtained (disregarding any remainder).
- If an elected candidate obtains surplus votes (ie votes in excess of the quota), the votes will be transferred to other candidates in the count.

- If vacancies remain to be filled after surplus votes have been transferred, the candidates standing lowest on the count will be excluded and their votes transferred to the remaining candidates who stood next highest in the relevant voters' preferences.
- This process of distributing the surplus votes of elected candidates and of excluding candidates will continue until all the vacancies have been filled.

* If a member dies, resigns, or otherwise vacates his or her seat, the vacancy will be filled by a fresh examination of the ballot papers bearing the votes which elected him or her, to determine which of the available candidates who failed to be elected was most preferred by the voters who chose the former member.

* The boundaries of electorate(s) will be drawn by bodies independent of the Commonwealth and ACT governments. The criteria which govern the drawing of the boundaries of House of Representatives divisions will apply as nearly as practicable to the drawing of the boundaries of Legislative Assembly electorates.
* A redrawing of boundaries should take place in the first 12 months after each general election of members of the Legislative Assembly.

DEBATE.TITLE: FISHERIES ADMINISTRATION BILL 1991[COGNATE BILLS:FISHERIES MANAGEMENT BILL 1991FISHING LEVY BILL 1991STATUTORY FISHING RIGHTS CHARGE BILL 1991FOREIGN FISHING LICENCES LEVY BILL 1991FISHERIES AGREEMENTS (PAYMENTS) BILL 1991FISHERIES LEGISLATION (CONSEQUENTIAL PROVISIONS) BILL 1991]FISHERIES ADMINISTRATION BILL 1991

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 6 December 1990, on motion by Mr Kerin:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I understand that it is the wish of the House to debate this order of the day concurrently with orders of the day Nos 2 and 7--

INTERJECT.PARA: Mr Lloyd-It is still not our wish, but we will accept it.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Deputy Leader of the National Party seems destined to lead a happy but quick life. There being no real objection, the Chair will allow that course to be followed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lloyd Mr B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome the new Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Crean) to the table and point out to him that we have another disgraceful situation here with seven Bills for a major restructuring of the fishing industry, six of which were introduced in the early hours of Friday morning. There has been absolutely no time for either the industry or the Parliament, including members of the Opposition, to study the full detail and implications of these Bills. While the fishing industry is anxious to get out from under the wing of the Australian Fisheries Service because of staffing problems, a degree of inefficiency, and inability to manage the industry properly, it must be an affordable and better arrangement. The Fisheries Administration Bill and cognate Bills do not give that guarantee.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition is not prepared to put the fishing industry into a situation where its costs may well increase instead of diminish. For that reason, we are not prepared to support the Bills at this time. We will move in the Senate for the Bills to be sent to a Senate committee to give both the industry and the Parliament the time to consider this massive amount of legislation.

It is clear that the Australian Fisheries Service has failed to manage the fisheries or even to prepare adequate legislation-this may not have been the fault of the Service; there may have been drafting problems. The industry is in a very depressed state, with most fisheries subject to gear restrictions, quotas or buy-back schemes. There are increasing restrictions, as I indicated, and that means less income for fishermen.

I will give the House some examples. The northern prawn fishery is to be halved by 1993. In the last four months, the fishery has been reduced by 20 per cent as a result of the government assisted buy-back program, which is mainly paid for by a levy on the remaining fishermen. The southern shark fishery has been reduced from 3,000 tonnes to 800 tonnes-this is being achieved by reducing the number of nets on each boat. The gem fish quota has been abolished, as scientists are concerned for the future of the species. Total allowable catches have been put in place for orange roughie, and individual quotas are to be placed on at least another two species. Tuna quotas have been tightened.

The Government has been working on this package of Bills for almost two years, but only the Australian Fisheries Management Authority (AFMA) legislation was introduced in reasonable time. I admit it was in very good time-it was introduced late last year. But in spite of no legislation, including the AFMA legislation, being passed until this package goes through the Parliament-and if it is diverted to a Senate committee, it will be some considerable time before it finally is enacted by the Parliament-the Government went ahead and appointed a chairman of the selection committee to select members for the board for the proposed Authority. It has even appointed the Chairman of AFMA, Jim McColl-I acknowledge that would be a good appointment-and is employing him as a consultant for $48,000 for 60 days work. It is requiring the fishermen to pay 90 per cent of that. It has also placed advertisements calling for board members-all with no legislation through Parliament.

TALK.START.PARA: —Disgraceful!
—The honourable member is right. What an arrogant disregard of the Parliament by this Government!

SPEECH.PARA: The Fisheries Administration Bill, the Fisheries Management Bill, the Fishing Levy Bill, the Fisheries Agreements (Payments) Bill, the Fisheries Legislation (Consequential Provisions) Bill, the Foreign Fishing Licences Levy Bill, and the Statutory Fishing Rights Charge Bill make up the package. Included in the detail of those Bills is the dangerous precedent of the introduction of resource rent tax in an industry in which there is declining income and which is overtaxed already. One can understand, with all of that happening, that the industry would prefer some management body outside the Public Service to ensure greater efficiency and accountability. But all the Bills before us now are not enough for that to be completely done. An Industries Commission inquiry into what the cost sharing arrangements should be is presently under way; it is due to report later this year.

If the industry and the Parliament had to wait almost two years for the Government to produce a package, why not wait a little bit longer to see and hear what the Industry Commission has to say-particularly on cost sharing. That is why the referral to a Senate committee is an even better idea, because that will allow time for the Industry Commission report to be included as well.

We are told that the legislation is needed to ensure that fisheries resources are not overexploited; to enable commercial fishing operations to make money by using the best technology to achieve the greatest net returns; to make fishermen profitable so that the Government can introduce a resource rent tax-interesting; to increase industry and community involvement in decision making; to increase flexibility of operations by being outside the Department; to increase independence in day to day decision making with the Minister involved at a strategic level, rather than in operational matters; and to increase incentives to ensure that the AFMA operations are cost efficient.

The Australian Fisheries Management Authority will develop and implement fishery specific management plans; set sustainable catch quotas; grant ongoing or temporary access to fish resources; monitor the activities of fishermen; monitor the performance of each fishery; and, where necessary, restructure programs.

The other legislation will include the provision for plans of management for all of the fisheries; introduce new arrangements for Commonwealth fishing licences; make important changes to fishing boat licences to gain greater control over fishing operations in Commonwealth waters, including a formal fishing rights register which will give fishermen greater security; establish the rights as an asset against which they can borrow; and existing boat licences will be phased out and replaced with fishery specific entitlements. The Government claims that licences are now issued for only 12 months at a time but under the new scheme they will be ongoing, provided fees are paid.

The legislation will also place a ban on driftnet fishing; provide for a resource rent tax on superprofits-and the northern prawn fishery has been named as the most likely first fishery to pay this tax; provide for foreign fishing licences to be fishery specific and valid up to one year and subject to the payment of fees and levies; and establish a research and development corporation. Obviously, there are many very good aims within those points or objectives that have just been read.

But there are considerable problems with this legislation. First of all, as I said, there is the point that there has been no time to look at the major Bills. Although we have had a chance to look at the AFMA Bill and have tried to obtain answers, we are no happier with it than we are with the Bills that have just been introduced. For example, there is not even a proposed budget for the new Authority and we are told that fishermen must still pay for the fisheries section of the Department, as well as the new Authority; that is double taxation if ever there was.

The legislation does not allow the proposed Authority to undertake broad policy functions. These will continue to be undertaken by the Australian Fisheries Service section of the Department because it is planned to have a branch remaining within the Department of Primary Industries and Energy (DPIE) to handle policy. Therefore, that branch will retain responsibility for the development of resource use and environmental policies; policy matters concerning foreign access; policy on fisheries access rights; the collection of community returns, that is resource rent tax, from the industry; monitoring the effect of taxation rulings on fisheries management; developing policy that will reduce domestic and international marketing impediments for Australian fish products; and monitoring the Authority to ensure that it carries out government objectives.

What are government objectives? Are they government wishes? What is the point of having an authority if it is going to be subject to the government all the time? The branch will also monitor the general performance and profitability of the fishing industry. Surely this is not a government function unless it is doing this to see whether it can raise taxes on the industry.

Concern has also been expressed about staffing. The staff at the Fisheries Service have already been divided as though the new body were in operation, even though no legislation has passed through the Parliament to authorise that. So some staff are classified as DPIE and others as Authority staff. While the Authority will have the power to remove staff it does not want, it will have to pay out Public Service level superannuation, long service and other leave entitlements. Of the approximately 90 positions, there are already 48 acting positions.

The industry has expressed concern about the lack of power for the Authority and the Authority's being used to move people out of the Department with no thought of the costs, efficiency or impact on the industry. Even the previous Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, now Treasurer (Mr Kerin), has expressed some concern about the industry's ability to pay. I ask the new Minister, as one of his priorities, to consider this real problem of whether the industry has been saddled with something that is just adding greater cost to it rather than creating greater efficiency.

It is not only the Opposition that believes that there are major problems with this legislation. In a letter dated 24 May to the Executive Director of the Minerals and Fisheries Group within the Department, Mr Doug Walker, the Manager of Legal Services within the Australian Fisheries Service, said among other things-and I want to make the point that somebody within the Fisheries Service itself is expressing great concern about the proposal:

The purpose of this minute is to place on record my concerns with several aspects of the Fisheries Management Bill 1991, which I believe may have a detrimental impact on the effectiveness of management of fisheries if the Bill proceeds with the following deficiencies.
He goes on:

The best way that I can describe the Bill is that it is like a dog with three legs with a ball and chain attached to a leg-it will get there. With the time available between now and the Budget Sittings the Bill could be refined to provide a sound basis for fisheries management.

He then goes on to list the major problems with the drafting of the Bill. Mr Walker expresses his concern about the effectiveness of the management plan provisions and whether it would be possible for a plan to include all the tools necessary for the management of a fishery.
He says:

As it is unlikely that the fisheries bills will be passed by the Parliament in the current sittings, I believe it would be more productive to make use of the time up until the commencement of the Budget Sittings to critically examine these points in order to provide to the Minister a Fisheries Management Bill which aims at providing a sound basis for AFMA to successfully perform its functions and responsibilities rather than one which will allow AFMA to get by.

To this I would say amen. The Opposition agrees with those comments and agrees that there should be more time to consider properly all the detail and the implications of this far reaching legislation, particularly as it relates to the future of fishermen, who are already in a depressed economic situation. That is why we are opposed to the Bills at this time and why we believe it is absolutely essential for all of this legislation, including the report of the Industry Commission, to be considered by a Senate committee. If it means that the new Authority, or whatever will come out of that Senate inquiry and then back through Parliament, is not constituted until 1 January next year or even some time later, at least we will have had a more properly thought through proposal for the future of this industry.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Snow Mr J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have decided to support the Fisheries Administration Bill, the Fisheries Management Bill, the Fishing Levy Bill, the Statutory Fishing Rights Charge Bill, the Foreign Fishing Licences Levy Bill, the Fisheries Agreements (Payments) Bill, and the Fisheries Legislation (Consequential Provisions) Bill. This is not to deny that there are a whole lot of problems in the industry, but I see the Bill as a definite attempt to look at some of those problems and to respond to industry requests that a management authority be set up. Whether the setting up of the Australian Fisheries Management Authority is going to solve a lot of problems that exist one cannot be sure. In fact, I am not very confident that this is entirely the answer. But what I am confident of is that it is another step forward.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government has maintained a very good record on fisheries management during its eight years in office. The honourable member for Murray (Mr Lloyd), who has just spoken, told us that the Senate will appoint a committee to consider the legislation. There is nothing wrong with that. I welcome that because I think that it needs to be talked out well. It has been talked out heavily through the industry for some years. I see nothing wrong with a Senate committee considering the legislation, examining it closely in detail, and perhaps sending some points back to this House.

In response to some of the honourable member's points, I would say, first, in relation to the extra costs which he has alleged will occur as a result of the setting up of the Australian Fisheries Management Authority, that we ought to make it completely clear to the industry that the Authority is established on a viable basis. The Government has clearly stated that it will provide a guarantee that the industry will not pay more in real terms for fisheries management than it does currently until the Government has announced its response to the Industry Commission report on fisheries management costs. It is clear that there is no intention on the part of the Government to see an increase in costs as a result of the setting up of the Authority.

The honourable member for Murray mentioned also that there is likely to be a tax on the industry. He is saying that the Government is going to monitor the industry, possibly to ensure that it will be able to obtain a tax from the industry. Of course, he is sidestepping what the Government is really about, which is to ensure that we have a more profitable industry. Of course, the industry will pay more tax if it becomes more profitable. There is nothing wrong with that. It is the same as our motive for getting people off unemployment benefits and into the work force. It is mostly so that we can help the people themselves and partly so that we can alleviate the burden on taxpayers through reducing the unemployment benefits being paid out through turning those people into taxpayers. If we can turn more people in the fishing industry into higher taxpayers, well and good, but the aim is certainly not to set up some new tax in an industry which will not be particularly profitable-perhaps with the exception of the northern prawn fishery-in the foreseeable future anyway.

It is quite clear to me that there is no intention by the Government to reap a sort of super tax from an industry which is already depressed and which will be depressed for some time. The aim of the Authority is to bring everything together so that we will not have those problems.

There are also some ongoing problems in the industry itself which have become quite clear to me in my 10-year association with the industry as a political activist and as the local member. One problem is the lack of unity in the industry. One can get entirely different points of view from different geographic regions of Australia and even from one port. There is a lack of unity. I can recall taking the former New South Wales Minister for Agriculture, now shadow Minister, Jack Hallam to a meeting of fishermen. They began by presenting him with a united approach, but within 10 or 15 minutes they were disputing among themselves the point that they wanted to make to the Minister.

The unity within the industry has increased substantially since those days. There is less disunity within ports and there is much greater unity in the south-east trawl, for instance, than I have seen for many years. People are getting together and coming to the Government with one voice much more than they did.

Large firms in some parts of Australia still have more power than people in the industry. This is because people from large firms have more time to put into attending meetings and more funds with which to pay people to look after their fleet while they are at meetings. But for small firms it is much more difficult. People might intend to turn up at a critical meeting organised in an area, but if it turns out to be a good day they will go out fishing because they need the funds.

It is interesting that one day when I had organised to have a critical meeting between fishing industry representatives, fishermen and the Deputy Commissioner of Taxation, the fishermen suddenly all had to go out. The matter was so desperate that they sent their wives to meet me and to see the Deputy Commissioner. The case put by those spouses made it very clear to me that they were the real business managers in the industry. I have said to the industry before, and I will say it again now, that it is about time the people managing the businesses-it is the case on farms as well that quite often the women in the partnership are the business managers-were given an increased role in representation at meetings, because some of them are extremely capable and they have been able to put a very strong point of view to government. The industry ought to persevere with that attitude and give the women in the industry more power to make representations to government, because they do it particularly well.

I think what we do see in this legislation is a formal management plan to regulate fisheries on a consistent and clear basis. The Government developed management advisory committees and made those committees more effective and widespread. It took an initiative in fisheries restructuring and provided financial assistance for restructuring. Prior to 1983 there were no restructuring programs to reduce excess fishing capacity.

Since 1983 the Government has taken a number of initiatives to reduce capacity. In particular, it established the national fisheries adjustment program in 1985. Perhaps most importantly, in 1989 the Government produced the first clearly articulated policy document in Australia on fisheries management, which sets out exactly what the Government's policy objectives for fisheries are.

The legislation which we have before us flows from the New Directions for Commonwealth Fisheries Management in the 1990s policy document. I was pleased to be associated with the Treasurer (Mr Kerin) when, as Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, he launched the New Directions policy at Ulladulla. In a very moving ceremony, he presented it not only to industry representatives and the local government in the area which benefits from the existence of the fishing industry but also to one of the children of a great three-generation fisheries family. He indicated the Government's wish that the new directions policy will lead to a long term sustainable industry.

The sad facts are that fisheries throughout the world are being over exploited and do not offer assurances to the people that want to come into the industry. That is what this management authority and the agenda are all about. Nations throughout the world are putting too much pressure on our planet's fragile fisheries resources and the marine environment which supports them.

At least the Government has the intestinal fortitude to do something about it. I know that one of the greatest challenges facing the new Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Crean) in understanding the particular sectors of the primary industry portfolio will be to keep up with the fishing industry. I have found that this is not all that easy to do. One can be away from the industry for six months because it has been going well; but problems will suddenly come up again. One needs to keep up with the intricate problems faced by the industry. I really wish the Minister well as he makes that attempt. I know that he will succeed because of his tremendous ability. I look forward to taking the Minister down to Eden, Ulladulla and Bermagui to meet those in the local industry.

The legislation before us, which follows on from the New Directions policy, indicates that a ban will be placed on driftnet fishing in the Australian fishing zone. It will also enable Australia to ratify the convention concerning the prohibition of fishing with long driftnets in the South Pacific. I can recall asking the leader of a delegation to the South Pacific Conference, the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Mr Humphreys), whether he would allow me to make a speech on the matter. He did allow me to make a speech in which I said that although I did not intend to ask the conference to ban driftnet fishing, I did want us to be aware of it.

Someone from one of the South Pacific countries came up to me and said, `Why don't we do it here and now?' And that actually happened. The South Pacific Conference held in Guam two years ago resolved to move on a ban for driftnet fishing. It took some time to persuade the United States and the United Kingdom representatives. That evening the United States representatives rang Washington. Washington, which wanted a moratorium, at last agreed on a ban. That very important ban on driftnet fishing is being implemented by this legislation.

The legislation provides for a range of things and I expect later speakers to deal with them. One important aspect of the legislation is that it sets up a new statutory authority, the Australian Fisheries Management Authority, to run Commonwealth fisheries. The Authority is going to have close links with industry through its board and management advisory committees. It will be accountable not just to the Government but also to the fishing industry and to the wider community. The industry has been arguing for this for a long time.

The legislation has been framed in a sensible and balanced way. By all means let us have comments from the Senate. But I look forward to the passage of the legislation so that we can have an authority which clearly indicates that we can manage the fisheries in a sensible and balanced way.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Broadbent Mr R.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the House for the opportunity to speak on this matter. The honourable member for Eden-Monaro (Mr Snow), who has just finished his speech, mentioned the need for unity. When people in his electorate and mine, who work in the southern shark and related fisheries, have their backs to the wall, it is amazing how quickly they are forced to become unified. Business managers-and they are not only women-and fishermen right across Victoria have found that they need to do this.

SPEECH.PARA: I also look forward to taking our new Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Crean) to my electorate. I dare say that, as a Victorian, he would know the San Remo fishing village very well. I put to him that unless we look very closely at the Fisheries Management Bill 1991 and allow it to go to a Senate select committee, it might not be very long before there is not a San Remo for us to go and look at.

I draw to the attention of the Minister, who is sitting at the table, the fact that this far-reaching legislation was introduced at 2 a.m. last Friday morning, 31 May. The Government has guillotined most of the legislation that has come before us this session. Indeed, 36 Bills will be passed by this House before we rise late on Thursday evening.

We are advised that the purpose of the Fisheries Management Bill and cognate Bills is to restructure Australia's fishing industry by establishing a new statutory authority, the Australian Fisheries Management Authority, to ensure that the fisheries resources are not overexploited. That will be of benefit not only to fishermen in my electorate of Corinella but also to every fisherman in Australia. The legislation will enable commercial fishing operations to be profitable by encouraging the use of the best technology to achieve the greatest net returns. This will enable the Government to introduce a resources rent tax-a new tax for people in a struggling industry.

The legislation seeks to establish the Australian Fisheries Management Authority to undertake the Government's fisheries management responsibilities; it seeks to establish a national fishing industry policy council to provide advice to the Government and the Australian Fisheries Management Authority; and it seeks to establish an Australian Fisheries Management Authority selection committee.

The Government argues that the Australian Fisheries Management Authority will increase industry and community involvement in decision making, increase flexibility of operations by being outside the Department and increase independence in the day to day decision making with the Minister involved at a strategic level rather than an operational level. The legislation will also increase incentives to ensure that the Australian Fisheries Management Authority's operations are efficient. The Government argues that the Authority will develop and implement fishery specific management plans, set sustainable catch quotas, grant ongoing or temporary access to fishery resources, monitor the activities of fishermen, monitor the performance of each fishery and, where necessary, restructure programs.

Other parts of the legislation allow for plans of management of all fisheries, introduce new arrangements for Commonwealth fishing licences and make important changes to fishing boat licences to gain greater control over fishing operations in Commonwealth waters, including a formal fishing rights register which will give fishermen greater security and will establish the rights as an asset against which they can borrow. Existing boat licences will be phased out and replaced with fishery specific entitlements. The Government claims that licences are now issued for only 12 months at a time, which is true, but under the new scheme they will be ongoing, provided the fees are paid.

The legislation seeks to place a ban on driftnet fishing, which will be of benefit to the world and Australia. It provides for a resources rent tax to be placed on super profits. The northern prawn industry has been named as the most likely fishery to pay this tax in the first instance. The legislation provides for foreign fishing licences to the specific fishery, valid up to one year and subject to the payment of fees and levies. It also proposes the establishment of a Fisheries Research and Development Corporation.

There are problems with the legislation. The first I would draw to the Minister's attention is that too little time has been allotted for our shadow Minister, the honourable member for Murray (Mr Lloyd), and for our Party members to really address this issue. That is why we are requesting the Government's support in sending this off to a Senate select committee for further investigation. Given the expanse of this legislation, from 2 a.m. last Friday, 31 May, until today will not allow the Opposition to give it the full coverage that it should, especially having regard to the fact that there are people in my electorate that are specifically concerned about this issue.

The Opposition doubts that the industry can continue to pay for people in the Department as well as in a new authority, which it is doing at the moment. I draw the Minister's attention to the very depressed state of most fisheries that are now going to be subject to further gear restrictions-I hope that has been brought to the Minister's attention-and quotas or buy-back schemes. My office is full of letters from these fishermen describing their plight and I am going to draw one of them to the Minister's attention in just a few moments.

In recent months we have seen the restructuring and the introduction of quotas or restrictions on many of the fisheries due to many boats chasing too few fish. I have a number of fishermen that will argue that this is an incorrect statement. The southern shark fishery has been reduced from 3,000 tonnes to 800 tonnes, and this is being achieved by reducing the number of nets on each boat.

I put to the Government that we made a few mistakes with some fishermen. We asked them to do some things and we have now really changed our minds and put many of them in a very difficult position. This is at a time in Victoria when we have tragic economic circumstances which, Mr Deputy Speaker, you would be well aware of, and I am sure the Minister is; at a time when we have a disgraced former Treasurer, the honourable member for Blaxland (Mr Keating), still sitting on the back bench of this House and at a time when we have a disgraced Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). We are now wanting to change people's lives in the fishing industry at a time when they can least afford it. This is a letter to the former Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, now Treasurer (Mr Kerin):
We write to you as parents who have followed recent events and ask you to please consider our concerns.

It is with dismay that we hear the terms ``scientific evidence'' continually being used as the be all and end all for decision making. The older we get and the more knowledge we gain convinces us that scientific evidence is often open to question.

You will note through all this that the fishermen are being reasonable. Through this whole exercise the southern shark fishermen that I know have been totally reasonable in their approach and they agree that there is a need for parts of this legislation. But there is also a time here for patience, and we need to be patient in government circles as well as they need to be patient as we ascertain the facts.

Our concern is for our son and his family. Our son's involvement covers 25 years from deckhand to owner operator. His confidence in the industry and his love of it led he and his wife (both very well educated) to commit themselves to large financial borrowings with the Rural Finance Corporation for the purchase of a 1st class 18 metre vessel. Their sound business practices allowed them to cover expenses and have a reasonable, but not generous standard of living for their family.

What worries us is that as little as 18 months ago the advice of the Australian Fishery Service southern shark management made it almost mandatory for them to purchase another licence in order to survive after net cut backs. This involved further heavy borrowing from the Rural Finance Corporation. This was only undertaken after consultation with the (previous) Minister's Department.

Surely it is inhuman that these who acted on this advice are now threatened with further drastic net cut reductions so that their very existence is in jeopardy. As our son's catches have remained the same over the last 2-3 years suggests that something is wrong somewhere.
Please Minister, consider those who took the advice to buy a 2nd licence in order to survive are now given a chance to do just that.
I have got letter after letter. That one was from the Gair family, from Jan and Sandy Gair, down at San Remo. They are involved, their children are involved and their friends are involved.

The letters go on, but I am sure that I am about to run out of time. But we are not talking about small amounts of money here; we are talking about a few hundreds of thousands of dollars-which are not the sorts of funds that one can come up with in five minutes overnight. The shark fishermen have concerns that they would like to see this Government address itself to. They would like to see this move to a Senate select committee so that there can be a full investigation of all the problems we face in our fishing industry and in other parts of our rural sector. When Victoria is having its toughest time since the 1930s, we need now to address specifically the individual needs of people.

I happen to care about the township of San Remo because a lot of my boyhood was spent in and around that township. I had a cousin working there as an owner of one of these boats, so I have a particular interest in that area-it is not just that is in my electorate. I have a personal interest in these people, their schools, the traders in the area, the San Remo fishermen's cooperative and all the allied industries that are affected by what is happening with those boats.

This is probably one of the most serious issues that I, unlike the Minister in the last few days, have had to face; one that has severely affected a large group of people in my electorate. Because of that, I have taken a couple of minutes more than I should have, Mr Deputy Speaker, but I thank you for the time that I have been given to speak on this matter and I pray that the Minister will make further investigations.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Edwards Mr R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, may I thank you for your assistance in making it possible for me to speak this morning. I heard the speech of the honourable member for Corinella (Mr Broadbent). After he reflects upon his remarks about fishing, he should go back and say to the people of San Remo that the current predicament they face is the result of a failure of fisheries management in the past, and that is what this legislation is designed to deal with. As long as fishing is seen as an exploitable resource and a sustainable yield is not established, people are going to have those problems. But what we have to say to those people is that they simply cannot continue to over-fish an industry and drive it out of existence. We have problems in fishing in the same way that we have problems in the grain industry and in the wool industry; that is, we have had excessive levels of entry to the industry. We have not had a proper management policy in terms of fishing, in particular, and that is what this legislation aims for. It is very important.

SPEECH.PARA: I sympathise with the honourable member's concern about his local community. It is a very serious issue. It is not a question of party politics-and I say that very seriously. What members of Parliament have to do is talk to our local communities about properly managed fisheries.

I am fortunate, in a sense, that in Western Australia we have the crayfish or western rock lobster industry, which is one of the model industries in terms of sustainable yield and proper management. But that needs to be replicated in every fishery around Australia because, as the honourable member quite correctly identified, we find that fishing can be a very localised business and a whole town can be dependent upon it. But the future lies in having properly managed fisheries and the Australian Fisheries Management Authority that is being set up is designed to do just that. It is a very important step and that is why I want to support this legislation.

I have a couple of points to make. I want to commend warmly the previous Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, now the Treasurer (Mr Kerin), because he has really taken a global view of fishing and this needed to be done. I note that Alan Newton and Dave Wesney from the Department of Primary Industries and Energy have provided considerable expertise in this area. It is important that we have a thoroughly expert background at departmental level.

This does afford me the opportunity to say that we saw in the media in the last 24 hours comments about the new Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Crean), whom I want to endorse as the new Minister. The thing that cannot be said about the Minister is that he does not know the way the world works. He does. He has had lots of experience and he has support in the community. What he inherits from the previous Minister is a properly structured approach to a series of industries and fishing is one of them. I have no doubts about the Minister's ability to handle the job and I think that we now have to move ahead in relation to managing these fisheries. These sorts of debates are very important from that point of view. But I want to refute the nonsense that has been put around about the new Minister not being capable of doing the job. He has the support of all members of the parliamentary Australian Labor Party in that respect; he certainly has my support.

I have a couple of points to make about the legislation. That very important fisheries management statement that was issued makes it clear that we are looking now at objectives in terms of fisheries management. I think that these are very important to ensure that fisheries resources are not over-exploited and that any exploitation is at a level which can be sustained while maintaining the surrounding environment. This is a very important statement, because we have to say that to all fisheries. We have problems wherever we look in fisheries where there has not been a proper management regime. Certainly, the northern prawn fishery is one example of that in that it has had to have fleet reductions.

I go back to this question of the management of the western rock lobster industry. We need the research and the levies to support research, so we can come up with a properly biologically based model which will enable us to say what is the level of yield. Then, quite correctly, we can look at the entry numbers and the sorts of licences that are paid for. We can then restrict entry so that we get a sustainable yield and avoid the extraordinary catastrophes that occur. That is the first thing.

The second point is that we must enable commercial fishing operations to be as economically efficient as possible, because at the end of it people are not going to go out there and run commercial risks and take those basically environmental and hazardous risks of running a fishing operation, unless of course there is money in it. This says what should be done, incidentally using the most appropriate technology to achieve the greatest net returns.

The third point concerns creating conditions where fishermen are able to make a payment to the community for the right to exploit a public resource for private gain; that is a very important thing to consider. We see in near coastal fisheries, which are under State control, that there is overexploitation at the commercial level and then the recreational fishing suffers. I say to everyone who looks at fishing that one of the largest industries in terms of activity in Australia is recreational fishing when one looks at the total activity in terms of rods, lines, bait and so on. It happens to be decentralised because it is based around tourism and recreational activity, so we have to recognise that. Such a payment should not reduce the profitability of fishing operations to less than their current levels; that is a sensible statement to include.

The fourth point is that we have to ensure that the administration of Commonwealth fisheries is conducted on the most efficient and effective basis. I put to the House that I think this legislation does that, and it is very significant.

I now want to move to another matter which I think is important, and that is the question of access rights. The second reading speech on the Fisheries Management Bill 1991 states that the Government would not auction the access rights of existing fishermen in developed fisheries. It also clearly states that, while an auction or tender may be used to allocate new fishing rights, the Government would ensure that appropriate incentives were provided so that exploration for and development of new fisheries would continue. This statement is very important. We cannot expect fishing operations to go out there and put in substantial amounts of money to develop a fishery unless they are given some guarantee that they will get some reward for that effort.

Obviously, I would not want to confer a monopoly right on people who undertake the research and development of a fishery. But I do believe they need an economic return to encourage them to undertake that because, if not, all that happens is that overseas entrants who have got large amounts of capital are encouraged and we in Australia suffer a net loss in terms of our fishing stock.

This legislation does deal with driftnet fishing. There is not a more obscene example of overexploitation and bad exploitation of a resource than driftnet fishing and we in Australia, fortunately, are taking a lead in our region. I must say that some of our regional partners have not got the same level of concern; Taiwan, Japan and South Korea do not show that level of concern and they ought to be put on notice about it.

I am tired of being basically misled by the Japanese about their activities in whaling. They do take whales for commercial purposes and they should stop misleading us. There is a delegation here in Australia at the moment and I hope that it takes that message back to Japan. The Japanese should not try to lie to us about this. The fact is that they do take minke whales; they are in breach of the international conventions on it and they ought to understand that. They should not try to smooth it over with some rhetoric about it, because we know the bottom line. What we have seen in our region is exploitation of fishing resources-and that cannot be accepted by countries such as ours.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Downer Mr A.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is disappointing that so much of the fisheries legislation has been hurried through the House. It does not really show a great deal of what I would have regarded as appropriate respect for the institution of the Parliament for legislation to be introduced at 2 a.m. on a Friday morning and to be brought on for debate so soon the following week without the Opposition, or indeed members generally, having sufficient time to work through that legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: Nevertheless, it is legislation that is of some concern to me in the electorate of Mayo because there are a large number of fishermen both on Kangaroo Island and in the Fleurieu Peninsula who have a great deal of concern for their future livelihoods. They see their living standards falling and their livelihoods are in some difficulty at the present time. The legislation package introduced by the Government is not legislation which would give them any particular pleasure and certainly provides no assistance to them in this difficult time.

I think we all understand the need for some regulation of the fishing industry-the fact that stocks have to be conserved at appropriate levels, otherwise the industry will no longer be sustainable. In order to ensure the conservation of stocks and the proper management of the resource, there inevitably has to be some bureaucratic structure put in place. That is something we all accept.

What this package of legislation effectively does is establish a completely new bureaucracy-the Australian Fisheries Management Authority (AFMA). On the face of it, this new bureaucracy will increase the overall cost to the industry and not necessarily provide for an improvement in the management of that industry. When I looked at what I think is one of the critical questions-the role that would be retained by the Department of Primary Industries and Energy's policy branch over fisheries issues-and compared that with the various issues which will be transferred to the Australian Fisheries Management Authority, I was struck by the fact that although the theory is that the Australian Fisheries Service in the Department is meant to be transferred to a statutory authority, the reality is that two bureaucracies will be established whereas in the past there was just one.

The Department of Primary Industries and Energy is going to retain responsibility for the development of resource use and environmental policies for policy matters concerning foreign access; policy on fisheries access rights; the collection of community returns from the industry; monitoring the effect of taxation rulings on fisheries management; developing policy to reduce domestic and international marketing impediments; monitoring the Australian Fisheries Management Authority to ensure it carries out government objectives; and so the list goes on. The list of functions that the Department is going to retain simply underlines the point that two bureaucracies are being established, whereas in the past one did the job.

From the point of view of the fishing industry, the problem that arises from that simple fact is that it is being asked to cover the costs of the AFMA bureaucracy and arguably those of the bureaucracy within the Department. Perhaps this matter could be clarified by the Minister later. An industry already faced with substantial cost problems through licences, taxes and the like, understandably feels miffed that these additional costs are to be imposed on it.

I note in the second reading speech of the then Minister that the Government is now seriously working on the introduction of a resource rent tax for the fishing industry. I want to make a couple of points about that. First, the most obvious point is that this is yet another potential cost burden being imposed on the fishing industry. That is a matter of real concern when that industry is carrying the range of costs I have already described, particularly in these difficult economic times. On top of that we need to address the conceptual question of whether the resource rent tax is an appropriate type of tax to place on an industry of this kind. The argument in favour of a resource rent tax in the mining industry revolves around the fact that minerals are a non-renewable resource. That is clearly not the case for the fishing industry, provided that stocks are properly managed. It is a renewable resource and therefore the argument for a resource rent tax-if you like, the economic rationalist's argument-is substantially weakened on that point.

I think the industry can take no comfort from the fact that the Government is proposing to introduce a resources rent tax. I gather the Government intends to start that tax on the northern prawn fisheries, which implies that it will then introduce the tax progressively on other areas of the fishing industry. Consequently I think we have every reason to be concerned that this additional cost burden will affect the fishing industry in particular, on the basis of the plans the Opposition has so far been able to obtain for this tax, in years when the industry may be doing well. After all, in an industry whose performance is very much cyclical, the good years help it survive in the bad years. If the Government is seriously proposing a secondary tax during the good years, that will simply make it more difficult for people in the industry to survive the poorer years.

My final point relates to the importance of the fishing industry as a contributor to Australian exports. For a long time I have felt that this industry could make an even bigger contribution to exports than is currently the case. That is particularly true if our fishing industry is to extend in a more progressive and productive way beyond the 200-mile effective economic zone into international waters. However, we will have to do a couple of things to ensure that the industry becomes a bigger contributor to exports. First, we have to ensure that we have better air links with other parts of the world and with relevant market places.

I was in Taiwan recently with the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) and Senator Hill, and one message we received from the Taiwanese was that they have a great deal of interest in Australian fisheries products, but lack of direct air links between Australia and Taiwan mean that the market is limited. We know there is a prospect of those direct air links coming into effect next month, which should open up the Taiwanese market more effectively to the Australian fishing industry.

I use Taiwan only as an example because there is a range of other markets around north-east and south-east Asia that could be very important to our fishing industries. The United States market is also a very important one for those industries. We need to ensure that we have proper air links and freight services into those markets if we are to exploit their full potential.

The second aspect of the argument about the export potential of the industry relates to our old friend, competitiveness. I was never a great enthusiast for the idea of the Soviet fishing fleet using an Australian port-it was generally felt that Hobart would be the appropriate port-as a regional base for that fleet. But things have changed very much in the Soviet Union since the days when there were security concerns about that matter. As time has gone on, the argument for the Soviet Union using Hobart or some other Australian port as a potential base has strengthened.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Downer Mr A.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Fishing Levy Bill is a mechanical piece of legislation that, in terms of the collection of the levy, is relevant to the whole issue of the competitiveness of the fisheries industries in Australia. This brings me to the point I was making earlier about the home basing of a Soviet fishing fleet in an Australian port. One of my concerns about that proposal, given that the security issues have been largely overcome by political developments in the Soviet Union over the past few years, is that the Soviet Union eventually decided to use Singapore as the base rather than an Australian fishing port.

SPEECH.PARA: That had two consequences: first, the maintenance work that would have gone to Australian companies and employees was lost to Singapore; and, secondly, the fishing industry was very hopeful that if the Soviets were to use an Australian port as a base for their fishing industry there would be the opportunity for what is known in other industries as technology transfers-that is, the Australian fishing industry would have some access to the very sophisticated Soviet fishing technology. That was part of the negotiations between the Government and the Soviet Union on that proposition. The Soviet Union, however, decided on the basis of cost to go to Singapore, and Australia lost the opportunity to benefit from the technology transfer.

I do not think that was ever a black and white issue. As I said earlier, there were always concerns about the security issues involved, at least in some Australian ports. It must also be said that, because of political changes in the Soviet Union, the arguments for basing the regional Soviet fishing fleet in Hobart or perhaps in Port Lincoln were a lot stronger than previously was the case.

In conclusion, these Bills, which have been debated in cognate form, are not good news for the fishing industry or for fishermen on Kangaroo Island or on the south coast of South Australia. I regret this legislation and that the Government continues to feel driven by the need to introduce additional bureaucracies, costs and taxes. The Government's rhetoric is often quite right on a lot of these issues: we need to make our country more competitive and we need to undertake micro-economic reform and all those sorts of things. But the simple reality is that this type of legislation does not achieve the objectives that are part and parcel of the Government's rhetoric.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crean The Hon S.F.

TALKER.NAME: Mr CREAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —A number of issues have been raised and I will try to deal with them quickly in the time available. First, it is important to understand that the Government is guaranteeing that fishermen will not have to pay more in real terms for fisheries management costs than they did in 1990-91. The Government has made that commitment and will hold to it until it reviews that position consequent upon receiving the report on this issue from the Industry Commission. Once it has that report the Government, in arriving at its decision, will involve itself in full consultation with the industry before it makes a decision. I make that commitment.

SPEECH.PARA: On the question of additional costs, it is important to recognise that the Government has committed itself to make one-off payments for the establishment cost of the Australian Fisheries Management Authority (AFMA), which will total some millions of dollars. We will ensure that they cover the issue of retrenchment, and that cost will be borne not by AFMA but through the Public Service Act transfer. The cost of furniture, equipment and other current assets being used in fishermen's management work will also be met.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crean The Hon S.F.

TALKER.NAME: Mr CREAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —Whilst we have the time, I should also go to this issue of the resource rent tax because it has been raised by a number of members from the Opposition. They have suggested that the passage of these Bills constitutes some sort of Government plot to impose a resource rent tax on fisheries.

SPEECH.PARA: The simple facts of the matter are that the resource rent tax can apply only in circumstances in which supernormal profits are being made. Quite frankly, I think both sides of the House would be pretty happy if we were operating in such an environment in relation to this industry. Unfortunately, the reason for the development of this Bill is that the industry is suffering from past management practices. The fact is that we have seen excessive pressure on resources, overfishing and declining profitability of the industry; and there is a need for the Government to bite the bullet and introduce a strategy for sensible management of our fisheries industry. In that regard, I agree entirely with the comments made by my colleague the honourable member for Stirling (Mr Ronald Edwards) and also draw on his analogy of the successful strategy that has been developed in relation to the western rock lobster.

The fact that we have this decline in stocks and the fact that we have got this pressure on the fishing industry means that the resource rent tax is completely out of the issue so far as this industry is concerned, and I think is out of the issue for the time being. In any event, my predecessor has given a guarantee that, if there is to be a resource rent tax considered, it will apply only in relation to new fisheries or existing ones after they have been restructured, and only after there has been full consultation by the industry.

TALK.START.PARA: —For example, the northern prawn fishery would be the most likely one in that regard.

—In relation to the northern prawn fishery, we have to recognise that there has been a great effort to restructure that industry. We have seen a reduction in the number of vessels and the fishing effort and, as I understand it, the restructuring program will conclude in 1993. Only after that, if there are supernormal profits-and again one has to look at the principle upon which the resource rent tax is levied, and the honourable member for Mayo (Mr Downer) did go to that point in his speech-can we even start contemplating the issue of the resource rent tax.

SPEECH.PARA: I make the point, and I commit myself to the same basis of approach as my predecessor: that is, we are not looking at the issue at the moment. If we do get to a situation, after restructuring and in relation to new fisheries areas, in which we do have this supernormal profit circumstance, then the Government will not proceed in relation to the resource rent tax issue until it has had full consultation with the industry. I simply make the point that, in terms of the fishing industries debate, the resource rent tax is something of a red herring, and I hope that the comments that I have made will help to reassure the industry.

In the brief time available, I reiterate the point that it is essential, in our view, that this legislation proceed. I understand the issues that have been raised on the other side, but we have to get this strategy in place. The strategy will not proceed properly if we put it to a committee in the Senate and defer implementation until the beginning of next year. We have to act now. We have to act sensibly and we have to act in the spirit of cooperation with the industry.
