SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fischer Mr T.A.

TALKER.NAME: Mr TIM FISCHER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —The House is now considering this additional Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Bill, and I advise that the Liberal and National parties are not opposed to this legislation. We in fact support what represents a steal from the coalition policy on veterans' affairs embraced by this Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: In turning to the detail of the legislation, one of the interesting things is that, with the passage of time, elements in the veterans' legislation relating to the Boer war-which, I am sure the boys and girls in the gallery would know, took place towards the end of the last century in South Africa and involved many Australian troops, mainly as individuals but others in units-are being removed from the legislation because they are no longer required as, sadly, there are no longer directly entitled Boer war veterans alive in Australia today.

However, it does not completely remove the responsibility of the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Mr Humphreys), the Department of Veterans' Affairs, the Repatriation Commission and, more particularly, the Australian War Graves Office, because there are many war graves in South Africa that still need to be maintained and cared for as part of the apparatus which operates elsewhere in the world through the Commonwealth War Graves Commission.

The honourable member for Pearce (Mr Chaney), I and many others take a deep interest in visiting war graves around the world-especially Australian war graves-when the opportunity arises. In my case, on the limited opportunities I have had to travel beyond Asia-or would want to travel beyond Asia-I visit war cemeteries. I had the privilege two weeks ago of visiting Crete for the fiftieth anniversary of the Battle of Crete.

The occasion was a credit to the Government of Greece and to all participants. It was a very successful anniversary commemoration of that horrific and important battle on the island of Crete. A number of moving services were conducted at many war cemeteries, especially along the northern coast of Crete. Chancellor Kohl of West Germany also attended and made a speech of atonement. He participated and laid wreaths, as did representatives from the United Kingdom, New Zealand, Australia and Greece, along with many others.

A highlight of the visit was the very warm welcome given to Australian diggers and the New Zealand contingent as they marched through the streets of towns such as Khania. A very warm reception was given. Many links of yesteryear were re-established between the locals and individual veterans who had not been back to the island of Crete. It was a privilege to see and to participate in that service, together with the Minister for Veterans' Affairs; the Minister for Administrative Services (Senator Bolkus); the shadow Minister for immigration, the honourable member for Dundas (Mr Ruddock); and many others.

In the context of this legislation, whether it is war graves in Greece or in Bangladesh, I have been to two areas of great tranquillity in Bangladesh at Chittagong and Comilla, where the magnificent war cemeteries are maintained directly by the Commonwealth War Graves Commission. It is perhaps the only area in Bangladesh where there is peace and tranquillity. The gardens associated with the war cemetery are magnificent and well maintained.

In South Africa, I visited the grave of Breaker Morant and the adjoining grave of Handcock in Pretoria. They were two Australians who lost their lives as a consequence of a court martial, which has been the subject of considerable controversy. I wanted to see the condition of those two war graves. They were veterans of the Boer War. Those two war graves are only two of the many war graves in South Africa.

I ask the Minister for Veterans' Affairs to give an assurance that, whilst this legislation repeals the Boer War provisions of the underlying parent legislation, there will be a continuing commitment by the Australian Government and the Australian War Graves office to the Australian graves which exist in South Africa, notably, just near Pretoria.

On my visit to the grave of Breaker Morant at the end of an extremely busy day, at sunset, I drew out my camera, stepped back to get a better angle to take a photo, and managed to trip on a rock alongside the war grave. I crashed to the ground into a pile of dust. The camera went one way and my shoe flew off the other way. I ended up leaning across the end of the war grave, lying on the ground, looking up at Breaker Morant's cross and the statement underneath it, `Rest in peace'. I am quite sure that Breaker would be delighted that, 90 years after his death, he is still tripping up figures of authority, because he brought me crashing to the earth on that particular occasion.

I note that the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans) is in South Africa as I speak, and that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) is contemplating going there later this year, should he be Prime Minister at the time. Other members of the Government at long last are contemplating returning to South Africa, following in the footsteps of many members of the Liberal and National parties, including the honourable member for Mallee (Mr Fisher). When they visit Pretoria, I recommend that they take the opportunity to visit Breaker Morant's war grave and other war graves in South Africa.

The second part of the legislation provides that the dependants of female veterans have similar conditions to the dependants of male veterans. This arises from the fact that service women were part of the crews which were sent to the Persian Gulf during the recent Gulf war. Service women in the Royal Australian Navy, Australian Army and Royal Australian Air Force are playing an enhanced role in their service, and this is as it should be, within logical constraints. The legislation should not discriminate against service women. I know it would be of particular interest to you, Madam Deputy Speaker, that this legislation moves to correct, to provide for, and to close off a number of areas of anomaly between servicemen and their dependants and female veteran service women and their dependants.

The Liberal and National parties have a specific policy commitment, which has been longstanding. As the then shadow Minister for veterans' affairs, I helped formulate the policy, and it has continued to be pursued by Senator Newman. It states:
The Liberal and National Parties will remove anomalies and forms of discrimination on the grounds of a veteran's gender.

So we welcome the step this legislation takes to make further progress down that path and to provide assistance on a more even-handed basis. The armed forces of the 1990s are quite different from the structure and modus operandi of the armed forces in World War II, World War I and the Boer War. Circumstances will continue to change with regard to the armed forces. We know the world is unstable and that events can suddenly arise. Twelve months ago there was no contemplation that this Parliament would be committing Australian service personnel to battle. A couple of months later this Parliament had to do just that and our contingent went to the Gulf. It included ships, a large naval contingent, members of the Army and some members of the Air Force.

I take this opportunity to say again that this contingent served Australia well in the best traditions of Anzac. It maintained the entirely professional standards of the Australian armed forces generated over decades. Australians can be proud of the contribution they made. It is entirely proper that the Parliament, as quickly as possible, corrects those anomalies which relate to service women who went to the Gulf. They were at a disadvantage in terms of veterans' entitlements compared with service men. I welcome those aspects of the legislation.

I wish to refer to two other aspects that relate to and arise from this legislation. As Australia goes through this horrific economic recession, which in many parts of Australia is more of a depression than a recession, the well-being and value of entitlements of veterans, ex-service men and women, war widows and, indeed, pensioners generally are very much related to the existing general standard of living. They are, however, also very much related to the real purchasing power of the Australian dollar and to the general Australian economic climate. We cannot divorce the two.

In one sense, it is absurd to argue for a particular variation of entitlement-for example, an increase of a couple of dollars a week-if, at the same time, elsewhere the policies of the Government and the economic circumstances of Australia are such that the real value of those extra dollars has been completely whittled away and other cost burdens have been created by the plunging economy, by the recession we `had to have'.

It is very much in the interests of veterans and elderly citizens in general that Australia enjoy circumstances of economic viability, a growth economy, one which is properly balanced and internationally competitive. Unless all those things are arrived at, the plunging economic circumstances which will prevail as Australia misses the boat throughout this decade of the 1990s will ultimately take away from the actual standard of living of veterans and pensioners, no matter what the particular value and rate of pension might be.

In this context I put to the House very seriously, in response to comments made by the Minister for Veterans' Affairs and others in debates on related legislation, that the veterans should be arguing just as strongly for taxation reform, industrial relations reform, protection reform and micro-economic reform, because those four areas of reform are essential to the maintenance of the wherewithal of the Australian economy in the 1990s. Unless the economy is brought back on the rails, the lot of veterans and of pensioners generally is going to be horrific throughout the rest of the 1990s, no matter what the actual level of pension payment received, partly pertaining to and provided for in this legislation, is.

So very clearly, in the context of this Bill, which deals with a particular range of entitlements, the veterans' constituency cannot divorce itself from the more general economic arguments if it is to provide the best framework for value in the pension dollar and in the pension entitlement and, therefore, its members' best standard of living and quality of life. These people so richly deserve to have a fair go and deserve to be properly catered for in their senior years in a way which it is the absolute obligation of this Parliament and of the government of the day to ensure.

In those terms, as a positive step for veterans and pensioners, the coalition has a commitment, as part of its taxation reform, to abolish sales tax and to reduce fuel taxation as a rebate on all business inputs as part of our goods and services tax package. They are central to the well-being and future standard of living and quality of life of veterans and pensioners. It is about time that we had some balance and sanity in the debate on the goods and services tax, and it is seen as part of the reform agenda so essential to getting this country back on the rails and putting real value into those entitlement dollars and those pensioner dollars which are provided for, in part, by the legislation before the Chair.

I will not dwell on this point as I can see, Madam Deputy Speaker, from your body language and from your further examination of the Bill before you, that you might have some concern. So in anticipation of that concern, let me take the opportunity to add that no doubt this is one of the related issues that are being discussed by delegates at the Seventy-fifth Anniversary National Conference of the Returned Services League of Australia (RSL) in Melbourne, which a number of members of this Parliament are attending. In fairness to the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, I should point out that he is at that conference this morning. The Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) is also addressing that conference this morning and, subject to fog, I propose to take up my invitation to speak at that conference tomorrow morning in Melbourne. I am sorry that the conference is not being held in Canberra, this being a parliamentary sitting week.

However, Madam Deputy Speaker, I am sure that you would allow me to salute the work of the RSL over 75 years. Indeed, the Minister at the table, the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Tickner), indicates that he would agree with that sentiment. That organisation has made a powerful and important contribution to Australia and to the well-being of veterans, ex-service men and women and war widows. I congratulate that organisation on its seventy-fifth anniversary and wish it well in the difficult role it has to play in an increasingly competitive Australia and also in resolving the inevitable conflicts which will emerge in such a large organisation as the RSL. I wish that organisation well and I congratulate it.

Therefore, in respect of this legislation, I signify that the Liberal and National parties support it in the knowledge that since the end of the Boer war more than nine decades have elapsed, and this legislation reflects that fact. The shadow Minister for veterans' affairs, Senator Jocelyn Newman, in another place will dwell on further details associated with this quite important legislation.

I also commend the legislation for the way in which it continues the progress towards plain-English drafting of legislation. The need does exist in this increasingly complicated and bureaucratic society to make every effort to communicate in layman's language and to provide a basis for legislation concerning entitlements for veterans which the client community involved can readily understand. In that regard, the plain-English initiatives, with regard to both social security legislation and veterans' affairs legislation, is welcomed by the coalition.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McHugh Ms J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is quite fitting that a woman should be in the chair while this House abolishes, at last, one of the most unjust discriminatory measures which has ever existed in Australian legislation. I, as a woman, am very glad to be speaking on this Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Bill, because it brings into law, at last, a commitment to remove from the Veterans Entitlement Act a totally unjust and unjustifiable discrimination relating to the payment of benefits to dependants of eligible female service and ex-service women.

SPEECH.PARA: Ex-servicewomen have been fighting for years to remove this discrimination, which has existed since their time of service in World War II. I am going to claim the removal of this discrimination as a victory for Mrs June Stone and the Council of Ex-service Women's Associations of New South Wales, for the women of the Government Status of Women Committee and the Welfare Committee women, who took up this challenge some years ago when Mrs Stone first brought it to our attention. But it took a long time for it actually to become law, and I cannot help noticing, as everyone does, that, despite the work done by Mrs Stone and the women of the Caucus, it was actually the Gulf war which made it impossible for any government to allow this discrimination to continue, because women are now currently serving in our forces and cannot be discriminated against as were the women who served in World War II. Nevertheless, government attention has been forced to this issue at the moment and the anomaly is removed in relation not just to women currently serving but also to those women still with us who served in World War II and wars since. The changes that are being made will allow the provision of a war widower's pension to the widowers of entitled servicewomen and ex-servicewomen on the same terms and conditions as those applying to the widows of servicemen and male veterans. Widowers of eligible servicewomen will be entitled to apply for a defence service homes loan and male spouses will be eligible to apply for a service pension. The total upper limit cost of these measures is probably about $1.7m in the first full year.

Honourable members will have noticed that I struggled with the words `widow' and `widower' and all the convoluted sexist language used. Had we used the word `spouse' all along, perhaps some of these legislative difficulties would not have arisen and legislators would have been forced to realise that women as well as men were serving their country overseas, and the entitlements would have extended to all their dependants.

Section 11(1) (b) of the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986 discriminates against the dependants of female veterans and the veterans themselves. It provides that in respect of a female veteran a child of the veteran is a dependant of the veteran, whereas section 11 (1) (a) states that a male veteran's dependants include his wife, widow, de facto partner and child. As a consequence, the dependants of female veterans could not receive service pensions or widowers' pensions when female veterans died due to service-related causes and they were not eligible for defence service home loans.

When Mrs June Stone brought this matter to our attention-she has been fighting this battle for years-we were astonished to find that it had been Australian Labor Party policy in 1984 to get rid of this discrimination and that former Senator Arthur Gietzelt, the then Minister for Veterans' Affairs, had fought, but unfortunately not succeeded, to get this anomaly removed. So we set about trying to find out from the Department exactly how many women's dependants would be affected. We asked: how many women enlisted as servicewomen, how many women served overseas, how many women married and have now outlived their husbands, how many women would seek assistance due to the take-up rate of people at that stage, and so on.

We knew all the information was there, but, with the best will in the world, when bureaucrats are faced with a determined group of women absolutely intent on amending the legislation, all the barriers come up: it would cost too much, there are too many, and so on. It was really quite extraordinary to imagine that there were too many remaining spouses of ex-servicewomen who had fought overseas.

It took a long time to get the figures, but it was a great exercise for us all. I again congratulate Mrs June Stone and all the women of her council on having this anomaly removed at last. The Government was finally forced to focus on it because of the women currently serving overseas as a result of the Gulf war. Let us hope that there will be no more wars to give women the privilege of serving their country overseas.

In conclusion, this is not the only thing that Mrs Stone and her Council of Ex-servicewomen's Associations are fighting for. They constantly remind us-recently Mrs Stone appeared before the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs Committee inquiry into the status of women-that women who have served their country in a time of war have constantly been discriminated against.

Mrs Stone claims, and I think her claim is very well based, that women who thought they may have to go overseas once they enlisted but who did not go overseas, should be entitled to the full benefits received by those who went overseas. This is, of course, a less clear discrimination, because men who did not go to theatres of war are also not entitled to some of the benefits received by those who went overseas. Mrs Stone makes a very good case for the way in which women were discriminated against at the time.

For instance, it was the very discrimination against women which prevented them from going overseas. The reluctance of the armed forces to allow women to join them overseas prevented them going, no matter how much they were willing and no matter how much they actually expected to be sent overseas. Mrs Stone states:
. . . comparatively few of the women of Australia's Defence Forces served overseas in theatres of war during World War II-
that is why this anomaly should have been removed many years ago; it certainly was not going to cost the Government much-
and therefore not many receive the recognition and the benefits accorded to returned personnel.

Thousands of women replaced men in Australia's Navy, Army and Air Force freeing them for overseas service and these women made up the bulk of home service personnel in 1944. Their voluntary enlistment meant for many immense psychological and physical strain for some years as they worked on chemical warfare units; with searchlight and gunnery units; plotting enemy shipping along Australia's coastline; in intelligence work; maintaining and servicing aircraft and some became experts in the various trades they learned within the Service in which they had enlisted. Servicewomen were posted to remote areas totally alien to their prewar background and, together with the men with whom they worked, they suffered through the hazards they encountered and the hardships they experienced because of poor diet, lack of facilities and vagaries of the climate.

I could go on for some time about the hardships suffered by those women. Mrs Stone points out that the men alongside whom the women worked were entitled to benefits even though they did not go overseas. The women were not entitled to these benefits. She points out that any man who enlisted or who was appointed for service to go overseas was entitled to a defence service home loan, which is one of the areas of discrimination. A woman could have been working on aircraft or building aircraft-she could have been doing all the things the men were doing next to her. She could have worked beside a man who received a loan to which she was not entitled. In fact, Mrs Stone points out that that was the case within her own family. That is not the basis of this Bill. We are at last removing an anomaly-a totally obvious discrimination against women-which no government since World War II has sought to remove. On behalf of Mrs Stone and her council, and the women in the Government who support her, I point out that there are still discriminations to be removed against the women who fought and served our country so well in previous wars, and who are still doing that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ronaldson Mr M.J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to take up some of the comments made by the honourable member for Phillip (Ms McHugh). I appreciate that a large number of groups have been working on this matter for a long time, and she has rightly mentioned and congratulated them in her speech. I find it quite extraordinary that the so-called social justice party has been looking at this issue since 1984, yet nothing whatsoever has been done. It is amazing that it took the Gulf war conflict-which I note the honourable member for Phillip did not support, in any event-to raise this matter and bring it to a head.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member may not be aware that others apart from a large number of groups which she has mentioned have assisted in this matter. She failed to mention my colleague, Senator Jocelyn Newman, the shadow Minister for veterans' affairs and defence personnel who, single-handedly, got this issue to the table today. She deserves the congratulations of the honourable member for Phillip, the congratulations of this House, and the congratulations of the whole veteran community. I am surprised that it was not mentioned in the honourable member's speech today. Senator Newman has single-handedly been responsible for this legislation. On behalf of the veteran community, I pass on my thanks to her. The shadow Minister is quite rightly acquiring an excellent reputation in this area. She is very widely respected amongst the veteran community, and I have no doubt she will make an excellent Minister after the next election. On 9 January this year Senator Newman put out a press release, which states:
Australian servicewomen serving in the Gulf war zone are being unlawfully denied equality of veterans entitlements, because of defective legislation and a lack of concern by the Federal Government.
It appears that this lack of concern goes back to 1984, and not sooner, which was my initial understanding. It continues:

Yet the Federal Minister responsible, Mr. Ben Humphreys has today wrongly claimed that full repatriation benefits will be available to Australian Defence Force Personnel on active service in the Gulf.

On the one hand the honourable member for Phillip tells us that the Australian Labor Party's so-called concern about this goes back to 1984, yet in January of this year the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Mr Humphreys) apparently had no idea what the entitlements were and what they were not.

TALK.START.PARA: —Rubbish.

—The honourable member says, `Rubbish'. The simple fact is that he did not know. If she wants to stick up for him, as she stuck up for her Party today, that is her concern; but I think she would be extremely wise to discontinue interjections along those lines because she is clearly incorrect.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Newman also revealed that the Veterans' Entitlements Act provided only for the wife of a veteran, not the husband of a veteran, in the granting of service pensions. She also drew attention to the fact that a war widow's pension can be granted to the spouse of an eligible ex-serviceman but that there is no equal entitlement for a war widower's pension for the spouse of an eligible ex-servicewoman.
The concern of my Party goes further than that. Our veterans' affairs policy statement of August 1988-before the last election-stated:
The Liberal and National Parties will remove anomalies and forms of discrimination on the grounds of a veterans' gender, such as discrimination against the widower of an ex-servicewoman.

In the light of the Gulf war, this issue assumed even greater prominence. I find it quite extraordinary-it is a shame the honourable member for Phillip has now left the chamber-that the Johnny-come-latelies in the Labor Party are now jumping up and down about this. I reiterate that it is only because of the work done by Senator Jocelyn Newman and other women's groups around this country that this issue has finally been addressed by this Parliament. It has been a long time coming and, quite obviously, it should have happened far earlier. It makes a great mockery of this social justice Party.

We have had grubby politics over the last six months, the classic example being the proposed ban on political advertising. That is a real doozey. I honestly do not believe that the honourable member for Phillip could possibly support the attack on freedom of speech contained in that legislation. I am sure that in her heart of hearts, even if she put her hand up for it, deep down she thought it was a gross interference with and attack on freedom of speech, probably the greatest in this country's history. She may send me a letter supporting what I am saying after I leave the chamber.
It got worse after that. We then had the second doozey, the daddy of all doozies, when the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) told us this week that he blatantly lied to the Australian people for their good.

TALK.START.PARA: —On a point of order, Madam Deputy Speaker--
—I think the honourable member for Ballarat is drawing a rather long bow at the moment.

—I may well be, but I am a little disappointed. The honourable member for Phillip said herself that she was straying from the Bill, but now she has the gall to stand up and attack me for introducing another matter of serious concern to the veterans in this country.

— I point out to the honourable member for Ballarat that the question of relevance is in the hands of the Chair, not of honourable members either speaking or objecting to what is being said. I was listening to what the honourable member for Phillip said, and I gently remind the honourable member for Ballarat that he should not challenge the ruling of the Chair.
—I accept that, Madam Deputy Speaker, but I also indicate to you that it was initiated--
—On a point of order, Madam Deputy Speaker. I would not want the moment to pass without picking up the use of the word `lied', and I ask that that be withdrawn.
— I am sorry; I did not catch that. I ask the honourable member, if he used the word `lied', to withdraw that unparliamentary language.

—I will, Madam Deputy Speaker-the excessive stretching of the truth by the Prime Minister during the election campaign. I might say that the point of order in relation to relevance was not initiated by you, Madam Deputy Speaker; it was initiated by the honourable member for Phillip, and I remind her of her comments.

SPEECH.PARA: The issue went further than that. What we have also seen in relation to veterans recently is the matter of the repatriation private patients scheme. You may have seen this brochure, Madam Deputy Speaker, and other members may have seen it. It was put out by the Minister at extraordinary expense to Australian taxpayers. He also used an excessive stretching of the truth in relation to support for this scheme. He wrote to veterans and said that it had been supported by major veterans' organisations all over Australia. The simple fact is that that is again stretching the truth. It is not true. It is vehemently opposed by the Returned Services League of Australia (RSL). This glossy brochure has been produced telling people what the benefits are going to be. The RSL has been pursuing this matter for some considerable time, and it is simply not getting the answers. I quote from a media release of 26 May by Alf Garland, the National President of the RSL, which says:
. . . condemned the distribution of the leaflet sent out on 13 May to over 350,000 war veterans and war widows as a deceptive exercise of misinformation and omission.
It cost, conservatively, about $200,000 to mail out incomplete and misleading information. All it did was to create uncertainty about the Government's health care commitment to veterans.

The RSL does not support the Scheme because the proposed arrangements after the handover of Repatriation Hospitals to state government control, do not offer the same quality of health care with priority of access as promised by Prime Minister Hawke.

This is a matter of extreme concern to veterans. I took the opportunity to speak about this to the President of the Ballarat branch of the RSL, Mr Athol Pacey, and the Secretary, Rita Middling. I point out to the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Tickner), who is at the table, that Mr Pacey is a long time supporter of the Labor Party, but he is a man whom I trust implicitly and for whom I have enormous respect. The work he has done for the veterans in Ballarat over many years has not gone unnoticed by them. But he has expressed concern and he wants clarification of these matters, as do a large number of veterans.

The key issue appears to be the accessibility question. If that is addressed, some of the problems will go. I remind the House that the Ballarat Base Hospital, for example, has a waiting list of 1,300 to 1,500 people. If this scheme comes in, there has been no guarantee yet that the St John of God Hospital, which presently does take some veterans, will be under the private scheme and will be approved. The other problem the veterans-Mr Pacey and his group-are concerned about is the accessibility of the general public to these public hospitals if this goes ahead. I would hate to see the situation where a division was created between the veterans and the general public in the Ballarat community. I am urging the Minister to ensure that that does not happen. The RSL obviously relies on considerable community support, and the risk is that those divisions will occur as a result of that.

If the problems can be sorted out, I am the first to admit that for country veterans there will be considerable benefits; but there are other problems about the core of the care that may be provided. There is cancer treatment provided in Melbourne and there is a tuberculosis ward in Melbourne. I think the general view is that this move is extremely premature, given the rapid ageing of the veterans. Despite the Government's rhetoric, we need some firm guarantees for veterans that the standard, quality and accessibility of care will continue under the Minister's scheme.

Rather than sending out glossy brochures telling people that his proposal has the support of the major organisations around Australia, I urge him to sit down and clarify this matter with the veterans' affairs organisations so that it can be put behind us. It is causing enormous concern amongst what is now an ageing and elderly veterans' group. They do not need the sorts of problems that arise with these schemes. They need to know where they are going, and they need to know very shortly. My colleague the honourable member for Groom (Mr Taylor) is yet to speak. I do not want to take up any of his time. I thank the House for this opportunity.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Taylor Mr W.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome the opportunity to speak, albeit very briefly, on the Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Bill 1991. I am sure that most of us, if not all of us, on this side of the House would acknowledge that here is yet another example of Government policy being driven by an Opposition initiative. I very much welcome the comments made by the honourable member for Ballarat (Mr Ronaldson) about the shadow Minister for veterans' affairs and defence personnel, Senator Jocelyn Newman. I think Senator Newman has shown a tenacity and a sense of purpose without which legislation such as this would not be brought before us today.

SPEECH.PARA: I also agree with what the honourable member for Phillip (Ms McHugh) said about some of the women's groups, but I would add to what the honourable member for Ballarat said: that is, this very honourable lady who is saying these things about discrimination and the need to avoid discrimination-and it is unfortunate that she has now left the House-was publicly very much opposed to our commitment in the Gulf; yet several months later wants to support some of these very commendable initiatives.

I wish to put on the record in this House some of the comments that Senator Newman made in January this year. They were referred to very briefly by the honourable member for Ballarat. In her press release of 9 January Senator Newman said:
The Veterans Entitlements Act (1986) is not exempt from the requirements of the Sex Discrimination Act (1984) and the lack of equality for veterans benefits is thus unlawful.
That is a point that I do not think the honourable member for Phillip raised in her contribution to this debate. Senator Newman went on to say:
. . . I have received from the Minister for Veterans Affairs, the Government is aware of this breach, yet has been unwilling to correct the situation.
She quoted from one of the letters of the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Mr Humphreys), which said:
I have no power to waive the present provisions of the Veterans' Affairs legislation to enable widowers . . . to receive a war widows pension.

He went on to say that, when the Veterans Entitlements Act was drafted in 1986, the question of extending this benefit to the spouses of female veterans was considered but rejected on financial grounds. That is an important point to make: it was rejected by the Government on financial grounds. Senator Newman went on to say:

Yet the Sex Discrimination Act passed just two years earlier required equal treatment of males and females, unless specifically exempted by law. No such exemption was given to the Veterans Entitlements Act.

This was a point made very forcefully by Senator Newman. On 9 January the acting national Secretary of the Returned Services League of Australia, Mrs June Healy, said that the RSL would start negotiations immediately to rectify the anomaly. She said, in part:
Our conditions of service committee will roar like Mallee bulls when they hear of this.

She said that women in the Defence Force who wanted equality of opportunity would be upset to know that their husbands would not be treated in the same way as women spouses. She went on to say that, even if women on the Westralia, the ship deployed at that time, returned safely or were not married, the principle had to be established for other women who served in war zones. On 11 January, continuing and keeping up the fight, Senator Newman said in a press release:
The Minister's office today refused to put in writing a commitment to amend the Veterans Entitlements Act to give a widowers pension to the spouse of a servicewoman killed in the Gulf.
She went on to say:

While the Opposition has welcomed reports from the Minister's office that the Government will amend the Veterans Entitlements Act, I believe that the Government has `wimped' at dealing with other areas of discrimination against women veterans, which remain in breach of the Sex Discrimination Act.

That was conveniently omitted in the contribution by the honourable member for Phillip. On 21 January, as reported in the Hansard of that other place, Senator Newman made the following brief comments:

I have previously drawn to the Government's attention the fact that there are outstanding issues of concern to the Opposition which relate to the protection of our men and women on active service. To date I have not had any word from the Government that they have been resolved. The Opposition is dissatisfied and angry at this failure because these issues urgently need attention. It is not enough for us to sit for two days debating our commitment of our personnel-
if honourable members recall, we were debating the actual commitment at that time-
if they are not given fair and equitable treatment for their service.

There are three areas that need particular attention. I am glad that the Minister for Defence is in the chamber so I can emphasise the points to him. First of all, all inequality of treatment between male and female servicemen under the Veterans' Entitlements Act must be removed.
Senator Robert Ray, the Minister for Defence, said, `It will be'. In responding, Senator Newman said:

It was never fair but, now that women are on operational service in combat related positions, it is imperative that this inequality be rectified. I was going to say that the Government must give an undertaking to do so. I take it from the Minister's interjection that that is an undertaking from the Government and I welcome it.
It is now history that on 22 January the Minister announced the initiatives which are in the legislation before us today. The following day Senator Newman, speaking on behalf of the Opposition, said:

Whilst I am very pleased that at long last ex-servicewomen will receive the equal entitlements of ex-servicemen, it was regrettable that it has taken so long, and that it took the Gulf deployment to force the Government to eventually act.

TALK.START.PARA: —Shameful!
—It is absolutely shameful. She went on to say:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the Coalition's Veterans Affairs policy provides for the removal of anomalies and all forms of discrimination on the grounds of a veteran's gender.
For too long the Government has refused to correct what has been a blatant breach of the Sex Discrimination Act.

It just seems to me also that over and over again this Government acts only after a lot of push and shove. Here we have a classic example of that push and shove. As I said earlier, if it were not for the persistence, the tenacity and the purpose of our shadow Minister, that would not have happened. I am sure that we would have some disagreement with the Minister on that point. Nevertheless, it is clear from the chronology of events that Senator Newman's initiatives played a very large part in the development of this legislation.

I conclude by paying particular tribute to some of the local people involved in the Toowoomba RSL. They are very much at the back of some of these initiatives to do with women concerning war widows' pensions, et cetera. In particular, I would like to congratulate the local President of the Toowoomba RSL, Eric Grace, and two other gentlemen who are the powers behind a very commendable effort with ex-service men and women: a gentleman by the name of John Marsh, and Clive Brickhill, his assistant, without whose in-depth knowledge of some of these issues our ex-service men and women-a lot of them ageing very much now-would not be receiving the benefits that they deserve. I would like to finish by saying that I and the Opposition very much support what is in this legislation today, but it just seems to me that in many ways it has been too late and perhaps too little.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sullivan Mrs K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the seconds remaining before the conclusion of debate on the Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Bill, I feel that, as one of the women members of the Opposition, I should make a very brief contribution. I feel particularly keenly about this matter because I have a very large number of veterans, both men and women, in my electorate, which is based on the Gold Coast. I wanted to add a further dimension to the debate, whilst paying tribute to all those who have brought about the removal of this terrible anomaly from our legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: I think it is relevant in all the talk there has been in recent days about Australia's involvement in the battle for Crete, for example, that it be acknowledged that Australian women were involved in those engagements and were under fire. I refer particularly to those women who served as nurses and who looked after, as they called them, `the boys'. I know that the injustice has burned in their breasts ever since-that, having gone through that extremity for the sake of their country and Australian servicemen, they were not, for example, entitled to things such as defence service home loans and insurance. I think it will always be a matter of shame to this country that this has taken so long. Nevertheless, on the fiftieth anniversary of the battle of Crete, I am glad that it has been done at last.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Corporations Legislation Amendment Bill proposes amendments to the Corporations Act 1989 and the Corporations Law. On the whole, the proposed amendments will improve the legislation and the law, and for that reason the Opposition will support it as a whole. I regret to say, however, that this Bill has been introduced without adequate notice. It has been introduced without adequate opportunity for interested groups to peruse it and make submissions on it. It has been introduced without adequate opportunity for debate.

SPEECH.PARA: Even as late as this morning, I was in contact with the Law Council of Australia to find out its position on this Bill. The Law Council informed me that it did not have a final position because it had not had the opportunity to peruse the Bill. I also note in passing that, under the Corporations Law and the legislation as it stands, the Companies and Securities Advisory Committee is to have an advisory role in relation to amendments to the Corporations Law. I have been unable to find any advice that that committee has made in relation to this. Indeed, it appears as if the legal subcommittee of that advisory committee is not yet operating. So this Bill comes into the Parliament without an adequate opportunity even for the advisory committee proposed under the legislation to have a careful look at and make comment upon this Bill.

Of course, we know that the legislative program of the Government is in crisis, and this is but another example of the severe crisis that it is in. This Bill was introduced into the House on Wednesday, 29 May 1991. On Monday, 3 June 1991 the Government declared 33 Bills urgent and provided for them to be guillotined through the Parliament over Monday, Tuesday and Wednesday of this week. The Bill having been introduced on 29 May 1991, it is brought on for debate on Wednesday, 5 June. The time allowed for debate under the guillotine is 40 minutes, including time for amendments. Clearly, this is inadequate. Clearly, this is reprehensible in relation to the legislative program of this Government.

If honourable members believe that the legislation on this matter is simple, they should look at the corporations legislation and law. These documents stand about three inches thick. That legislation affects every company in Australia. It is a complicated piece of legislation and to amend it at such short notice without proper consultation is reprehensible. That is indicative of the way in which the Government treats the Parliament with contempt. Of course, the Government has not been merely guillotining Bills this week; it has been guillotining the former Treasurer and Deputy Prime Minister, the honourable member for Blaxland (Mr Keating)-and, indeed, 44 members of the Caucus tried to guillotine the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) himself. However, the problem with instability in the leadership of a government is that it leads to a crisis in the legislative program.

This Parliament is here to pass legislation, to consult with the community, and to ensure that the legislation that is passed improves the way in which commercial arrangements in Australia are structured and improves the way in which this country is administered. On that kind of program, it is clear that this Parliament is, to a large degree, punting in the dark. It is indicative of a government which is in crisis producing a legislative program which is putting the administration of commercial and other relationships in crisis. Also, it is indicative of how bad things have become under the administration of the Hawke Government.

This continues a sorry pattern in relation to the amendment of corporations legislation and the Corporations Law. The original Bill, introducing the new national scheme, was introduced on Thursday, 8 November 1990. It had to be debated less than one week later, on Wednesday, 14 November 1990. It was guillotined through with 39 other Bills, and 60 minutes was allowed for its debate.

I am pleased that the Attorney-General (Mr Duffy) has entered the chamber because he ought to think much more carefully about how corporations legislation will be amended in this country and the procedure which he is to engage to do that. He must stand up to the Government and ensure that, at least in his portfolio, there is some semblance of responsibility in the way in which his legislative program is conducted.

To a large degree, this Bill fixes errors in the original legislation, errors that could have been avoided if the Government had managed its legislative program better in relation to the original legislation. For example, this Bill partially fixes some of the jurisdictional questions omitted from proper consideration in the Act. Prior to the introduction of the Corporations Law, the Family Court of Australia and the Family Court of Western Australia had jurisdiction to deal with matters under the cooperative scheme of companies and securities legislation by virtue of the general cross-vesting scheme for the jurisdiction of courts established by the Jurisdiction of Courts (Cross-vesting) Act 1987.

Under the Corporations Law, a special cross-vesting regime has been adopted rather than relying on the general cross-vesting scheme to take account of the unique character of the jurisdictional apparatus under the applied law regime of the national companies scheme. Under that regime, the Federal Court of Australia and State Supreme Courts have full coordinate jurisdiction in respect of civil matters arising under the Corporations Law of each jurisdiction.

Even in its explanatory memorandum, the Government concedes that the Corporations Law cross-vesting scheme currently does not extend to the Family Courts `largely because, in the time available, it was not possible to draft separate satisfactory arrangements'. That is an indictment of the Government's own legislative program.

So we have to come back with this Bill to fix up an error that the Government itself concedes. The same might be said in relation to proposed new section 68a, the preservation of certain exemptions in relation to the State of Western Australia. Again, as the explanatory memorandum makes clear, it is necessary to insert this exemption to pick up exemptions already provided under the old cooperative scheme. When the Government raced its Bill through, again it omitted to make proper provision for that; so this House has to come back and fix it up.

I urge the Government to make sure that it extends every effort to get its legislation right in the first place. By rushing through legislation, time for debate in this House is not necessarily shortened; it just creates problems further down the track. Also, this Bill attempts to come to terms with errors in the original legislation which I pointed out in my speech on the second reading in relation to the original legislation. I pointed out that section 66a, which exempts corporate bodies formed under State laws, such as incorporated associations, cooperative societies and building societies, made no provision for bodies formed under Victorian statutes. The Attorney-General gave a lame explanation during the course of the debate on that Bill as to why that was not done. He said that it had been adequately provided for under State legislation, and so it has; but it was not clear, as I pointed out in the debate, from the face of the record that the provisions had been extended to Victoria. Now we have to come back with an amending Bill to remedy that problem.

Again, in my speech in the second reading debate on the original legislation, I pointed out that the provisions in relation to the Australian company number were ridiculous-provisions requiring a nine digit number on all business letters, statements of account, invoices, receipts, orders for goods, official notices or publications. I said that they were an overkill, that the Australian company number was not needed in relation to each and every one of those documents. The Government has come back with this Bill to amend the requirement to ensure that the Australian company number is required only on public documents which are intended to be or which are lodged with the Australian Securities Commission up until 31 December 1991. That is good so far as it goes, but what will happen after 31 December 1991? The Australian company number will still be required on all receipts. I urge the Government now to reconsider its position on that proposal.

There is sense in requiring an Australian company number on public documents, formal legal documents and the like so that people know the particular corporate entity that they are trading with. But it is unreasonable to require it on all receipts; for example, in the retail industry a chain of supermarkets such as Coles or Safeway may operate different stores under different corporate structures. Under the requirement, even after the amendment of this Bill, as from 1 January 1992, every time one gets a receipt at the checkout for one's bottle of milk or whatever, the company that is operating that particular store will have to put the name of the company and the nine digit Australian company number on the receipt. It is a legislative overkill to require every milk bar which is operated by company structure, when it takes one's money and gives one a packet of lifesavers, to put an Australian company number on the receipt.

There is sense in ensuring that people know who they are trading with so that if it ever comes to a question of taking legal proceedings they are clear about the identity of the company. That could be facilitated by requiring companies to exhibit in places where they trade the name of the company, the place of incorporation and the Australian company number. It is a legislative overkill to require the insertion of a nine digit company number on all receipts.

Again, it is a legislative overkill to require a nine digit Australian company number on all publications from companies. This means that, if a company advertises in a newspaper, not only does it have to put its name, but it has to put a nine digit Australian company number. In relation to real estate sales, for example, under this legislation, real estate agents who place advertisements for houses are expected to put the Australian company number on the advertisement. The Real Estate Institute of Australia is justly concerned about this. I urge the Government, when it is considering the Australian company number, to take that into account.

The Opposition supports the amendments in relation to the Australian company number as far as they go, but they ought to go further. The Attorney-General (Mr Duffy) and other members of the Government did not listen when we made these pleas on the original legislation; we hope that they listen now.

We find, of course, that this Bill does not even deal with all outstanding matters. We have been promised another Bill to deal with the Australian company number and one to deal with fundraising. That is a matter for urgent consideration by this Parliament, particularly in relation to rights issues and dividend reinvestment schemes in relation to prospectus requirements. We have been promised a second Bill in relation to loans to directors, related party transactions and directors' duties.

I mention to the Attorney-General that the proposed Bill dealing with loans to directors is largely unintelligible. The exposure draft that has been put out ought to be reconsidered and it ought to be put in language that people can understand. Mr John Green of the firm Freehill Hollingdale and Page made some comments on it. He referred to a computer software program called `Right Writer', which is an objective intelligibility testing program, scoring text by the number of years of formal education a person needs to understand it. The acceptable scale ends at 16 years. He asked the Victorian Law Reform Commission to put the exposure draft of the Bill dealing with loans to directors through the program. It agreed. Do honourable members know what the conclusion was? One would need 27 years of formal education to understand the proposed Bill. I see in the Parliament some of my colleagues-men of great learning and education, no doubt-but I doubt whether anybody in this Parliament has the 27 years of education which would facilitate the understanding of that proposed Bill.

The other point I raise in relation to the way in which the Bill has come to the Parliament is that this is the first amending Bill under the new arrangement between the Commonwealth and the States under the heads of agreement signed in Alice Springs. They were just heads of agreement; there is still no formal agreement between the Commonwealth and the States in relation to company law. The Attorney-General has promised that, when the agreement comes, it will come into this Parliament. I urge the Attorney-General to bring it into the Parliament soon, because one of the provisions in relation to the heads of agreement was that, on legislative matters which were not national matters, the Ministerial Council would be consulted, there would be exposure of proposed legislation over a period of three months and the Attorney-General would table the advice of the Ministerial Council when introducing amendments.

Not only has this Bill in its entirety not been exposed for three months, but the Attorney-General has tabled no advice from the Ministerial Council, as would appear to be required under the Alice Springs heads of agreement in relation to this particular Bill. This is the first amending Bill, and already we see the Commonwealth apparently not complying with the heads of agreement which it has made with the States.

I turn now to the terms of the Bill itself. Section 1073 is a good amendment to the Corporations Law. It inserts a requirement to comply with covenants in deeds. This will give the Australian Securities Commission the power, through civil enforcement, to enforce trust deeds-a power which I believe is very necessary. If one looks at what has happened in the unit trust industry and a lot of the problems that have arisen as a result of the fall in asset values, as a result of the Government's economic mismanagement and as a result of the inherent weakness in the structure, there are a lot of investors in unit trusts who are now unable to get their money out. There may be cases where some of the asset values in unit trusts have been shaved off because managers or trustees have not observed the obligations that they have; therefore, it is welcome that there will now be power on the part of the Australian Securities Commission to enforce deeds.

Schedule 3 to this particular Bill introduces a requirement for consolidated profit and loss and consolidated balance sheets for various economic entities. Economic entities are to be defined by regulation and the regulations will be disallowable in accordance with the provisions of the Acts Interpretation Act. It is assumed that the regulations will pick up and rely on Accounting Standard No. 1024, which has been published by the Accounting Standards Review Board. Fortunately, that standard says that it will only apply to companies whose financial years end after 31 December 1991.

It is a good thing that economic entities will be defined in such a way that non-corporations such as trusts, partnerships and individuals can be taken into account, and there can be a requirement to have consolidated profit and loss and balance sheets in relation to those entities. No longer will consolidation be required only in relation to subsidiaries as defined, but they will be required in relation to entities controlled by-and `controlled' is the critical term-a parent. Control is defined to mean:

The capacity of an entity to dominate decision making directly or indirectly in relation to the financial and operating policies of another entity so as to enable that other entity to operate with it in achieving the objectives of the controlling entity.

Clearly, the definition is designed to catch situations where complex corporate structures are set up with the aim of keeping various assets and liabilities-particularly liabilities-off the balance sheet. We saw the shortcoming of the current requirements in relation to accounts in relation to the Adsteam collapse. I have spoken to the Australian Society of Certified Practising Accountants and the Institute of Chartered Accountants in Australia, both of which support the introduction of this new proposed standard. I congratulate the Accounting Standards Review Board for all the work that it has put in in relation to this standard.

But I must say to the Attorney-General that clearly there is still some disquiet about the matter. I understand that the Attorney-General will have received a letter from Arthur Andersen and Co. dated 27 May 1991, which raises some concerns about part of the definition of control in so far as it relates to the last requirement that control occurs where an economic entity is conducted in such a way that it operates with the parent in achieving the objectives of the controlling entity.

We cannot settle the question here as to whether or not the accounting standard is tight enough. That is a matter, I presume, for the accounting profession and the Australian Accounting Standards Board. But the Attorney ought to give close consideration to that before that regulation is made.

Arthur Andersen and Co. makes, I believe, a legitimate point that, under that definition, control would be exercised where one was effectively operating the subsidiary or the junior entity, as it were, in accordance with the objectives of the parent. Of course, no director should be operating one company in the interests of another. A director owes his or her duty to the company of which he or she is a director, and if the director is in fact operating that company only to conform to the objectives of another, that director may be breaching the directors' duty in any event.

To impose that test could effectively impose a test that one would only come in under the provisions requiring consolidated accounts if one was not operating the company properly in the first place; that is, not operating it for its own benefit but operating it for the benefit of another. That is a matter which will have to be looked at very carefully. It is something that we in the Opposition will scrutinise carefully when the regulations are finally drawn up and come before this House.

There is also a change in relation to the obligation to comply with accounting standards. At the moment it is not necessary to comply with prescribed requirements as to financial statements where the directors take the view that to do so would not give a true and fair account of the financial documents. The law will be changed so that it will be necessary to comply with the prescribed requirements and, if the directors form the view that complying with those requirements would not give a true and fair account of the financial statements, they will have to provide additional information. So one complies in the first place and then gives additional information as well if one comes to the view that complying would not give a true and fair view of the accounts.

In my view that is a welcome change, and I hope it leads to greater and better disclosure of the financial state of a particular company. There is concern in some quarters that companies have not been as forthcoming as they ought to have been in their accounts, and it is imperative that the law does what it can to ensure that disclosure is maximal to creditors, shareholders, lenders and persons who are dealing with companies.

I come now to the other substantive part of the Bill where it amends the current law in relation to insider trading. There has been concern about the efficacy of the current law in relation to insider trading. The House of Representatives Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs made some recommendations in a report entitled Fair Shares for All: Insider Trading in Australia in October 1989. The essence of the recommendations made by that Committee were that the current structure of the offence of insider trading should be changed.

The current structure applies to forbid a person trading in shares where that person is in possession of information not generally available and likely to materially affect the price of shares, and the person is in possession of that information by reason of a connection with the corporation in the preceding six months. The essence of the offence is showing a connection between the inside information and the person who has that information by reason of association with the corporation.

The recommendation of the Committee was to move away from the requirement of a connection and to prohibit dealing in shares where a person is in possession of information not generally available, regardless of the source of that information.

An exposure draft was produced in relation to the recommendations in December 1990. That exposure draft was too wide. All it required was that the prosecution show possession of information not generally available, and that it would be likely to materially affect the price of shares if it were generally available. But there would then be an onus on the person prosecuted to show as a defence that he or she did not know or did not have reasonable grounds to believe that the information was not generally available. Rather than that being an element of the offence, showing that one did know or did have reasonable grounds to believe the information was not generally available, the onus was on the person who was charged to establish that as a defence rather than on the prosecutor to establish that mental element in making out the offence.

Fortunately, the Government in this Bill has steered away from those proposals in relation to the exposure draft. It is true that there is still criticism from corporate regulators who say that proving intent, or proving that information could be reasonably expected to have a material effect on price, will weaken the structure of the offence and make prosecutions difficult.

But there is concern in the community that the prosecutors in relation to the offence of insider trading have, to some degree, in some prosecutions, overreached. For that reason it is incumbent upon us to ensure that persons who are charged are adequately protected. For example, there was a prosecution recently in Melbourne in relation to insider trading concerning a Mr de Greenlaw and a Miss Arif. As it turned out, the charges were not proceeded with because those two persons were not committed for trial, and some of the charges were withdrawn.

There was in relation to those prosecutions what I consider to be some bad faith shown by those who were conducting the prosecution. Those who were charged were arrested at 6 o'clock in the morning. There were obviously tip-offs to the media, and the television cameras were able to obtain footage. In relation to the arrest, the Melbourne Magistrates Court was told that this was part of Australia's biggest ever share racket; 50 investors were involved, 100 companies and $100m. It was alleged that money had been stashed away overseas. The investigators posed for newspaper pictures under the heading `The untouchables'. Shortly after that the then Chairman of the National Companies and Securities Commission (NCSC), Mr Bosch, declared in a speech:
I am quite clear in my mind that the people we pursue are guilty.
It is not clear, of course, that he was referring to those particular arrests, but he was making pronouncements on the guilt of persons who had been charged generally by the NCSC.

This is not the way for prosecutors to behave. I hope that prosecutors do consider themselves untouchable, but I also hope they have no aspirations to consider themselves media stars. I hope that the NCSC and the Australian Securities Commission will charge only those against whom they have strong proof. I hope they will not fall into the trap of making pronouncements on the guilt or innocence of persons. That is a matter for the courts, after a consideration of the evidence. It turned out that the charges in this case could not be sustained.

So, on balance, these provisions are an improvement. We in the Opposition will closely monitor them, but we have concerns about the way in which some prosecutions have been conducted. For those reasons it is important that we do not throw out all the protections against vexatious or arbitrary conduct in relation to corporate prosecution in Australia.

On the whole this Bill is an improvement. It fixes problems we have raised; it deals partially with other problems we have raised, such as the Australian company number; it deals with consolidated accounts, although not conclusively; it deals with some of the shortcomings of the current insider trading laws, but in a way which does not leave us without reservations. We support it as far as it goes. We tell the Attorney-General that it has further to go. We urge upon the Attorney-General that when he introduces legislation in the future, he comply with the heads of agreement, he seek public exposure, he seek comment and he allow debate. By doing that, one could get to the business of fixing legislation before these errors occur.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Edwards Mr R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —To put the context of the comments of the honourable member for Higgins (Mr Costello) this morning into proper perspective, it is better to use a literary image.

SPEECH.PARA: In Joseph Heller's book Catch 22, when the character Yossarian comes in to his commanding officer and says, `Look, I've flown 99 missions and I want to go home', the commanding officer says, `It's not enough, we have just upped it to 100'. The following day, having completed 100 missions, Yossarian comes in and says, `I've flown 100 missions, I want to go home'. The commanding officer says, `It is not enough; it is now 101 missions'. Yossarian in Catch 22 was never able to fly enough missions to meet the requirements of his commanding officer. I suspect in relation to this sort of legislation that no matter what tests the Government were to meet, the honourable member for Higgins and his colleagues would say, `You haven't done enough tests'.

I am serious about that because, to put it into a political context, the Liberal and National parties only recently brought themselves around to supporting the concept of the Australian Securities Commission (ASC). Western Australia was most famous for having a parliamentary sitting between Christmas and New Year because the upper House could not agree to legislation relating to it. We are not speaking about people who, generally speaking, have made a positive contribution to the debate, although I exempt from that the honourable member for Higgins who in more recent times has taken a very constructive role. I have to say that the Liberal and National parties have not always been motivated by saying, `Let's get this scheme up and running'.

I turn now to the question of the heads of agreement. The honourable member for Higgins has already referred to the heads of agreement. It is agreed in the heads of agreement that the States and the Northern Territory have three months in which to examine the matter; however, for this Bill, they all agreed to one month because they wanted to get it done in this session as we are dealing with matters that need to be dealt with in that time. That is not fiction; that is what happened. There is this difficulty: how does one satisfy the demand for urgency-I go back to my friend Yossarian-and the consultation process?

I make the point to the honourable member for Higgins and other members opposite that in dealing with corporations law we are not dealing with something set in concrete that will remain that way. We set up the Companies and Securities Advisory Committee to advise the Attorney-General (Mr Duffy) and the Government about changes to the law. We have the ASC operating in the marketplace dealing with the activities of corporations, and we have a parliamentary committee designed to engage in discussing the process and in a sense to supervise the ASC.

They are all dynamic processes. At no stage does one stop the game; it is not like a freeze-frame in football where one stops the game and leaves it that way for as long as one likes; in fact the game continues. I note that the honourable member for Higgins said that there will be some changes in future; of course there will in the Budget session. I assume there will be changes to this legislation over time.

The honourable member commented that the Bill was unintelligible unless one has had 27 years of formal education. We are talking about an exposure draft. Unless the Government puts out something with a degree of technical complexity in it, the people in the field are going to say, `Don't give me this nonsense'. I am telling the honourable member for Higgins that there are mechanisms for consultation which are used and tested. The honourable member for Higgins then cannot complain and say, `Look, you are going through this consultation process but you are not going quickly enough'.

I want to make it clear that the Government is engaged in going through the consultation process. It met this test in terms of the heads of agreement and it has been brought in. I go back to the original Bill, which was subject to an exposure process and to a committee of inquiry process which I chaired. None of these are fiction; they are facts which have been examined. Obviously this place is an adversarial arena and one expects this sort of process to occur, but one has to come back to a few facts about this, which are as I put before the honourable member for Higgins and the House. I think we have to make that very clear.

The Bill also picks up the question of insider trading. In case anyone following this debate has any doubts about insider trading, in 1968-69 more insider trading was conducted in the saloon bar of the Exchange Hotel in Kalgoorlie than almost anywhere else in Australia. Seismologists and geologists came in with inside information and proceeded to trade; in fact they would ring people around Australia to do so. That was, if one likes, the everyday understanding of it, and it happened that way. I quote from Henry Bosch's book on insider trading, in which he quotes Gary Lynch:

The capital formation process depends on investor confidence in the fairness of securities markets. When committing capital to the markets investors expect that the individuals with whom they deal should not be making investment decisions on information available only to corporate insiders or information wrongly obtained.
On the following page Mr Bosch, still talking about the question of people raising concerns about insider trading, writes:

It was hard to reassure them given that, at least in non-legalistic terms, the practices they resented had become commonplace. For example, on 27 December 1985 the Australian Financial Review carried a front-page article headlined `Time to buy takeovers was 10 days ahead'. It went on:
The AFR looked at 65 bids for 60 companies made during the first 9 months of 1985 and found their shares rose an average of 9.1% in the 10 days before the bids were announced.

In 12 cases, the share price rose more than 20% during the 10 day period. In 9, it rose between 10% and 20%. In 13, it rose less than 10%. In 19, the price remained steady and in 8 cases the price actually declined.

To check whether the report was merely an aberration the NCSC conducted a further survey. Twenty-five later takeovers were examined and it was found that in every case either the price of the takeover target or the volume traded rose significantly just before the bid was announced. Our selection was informed rather than random but it is impossible to believe that this increased buying was a matter of coincidence. It seems clear that certain people became aware of relevant information and either bought in their own right, or more probably caused others to buy, before the announcement was made.
Insider trading is not by any means limited to takeovers.

He then provides a model of that. There is a very real concern in the marketplace and amongst would-be investors in relation to insider trading. In fact the Committee discussed an example the other day and I agreed fully with the comments of the honourable member for Ryan (Mr Moore) at that time. I think his example of TNT Ltd was most apt; so it is relevant.

The honourable member for Higgins referred to changes. The most significant change to the insider trading provisions to be made in the Corporations Legislation Amendment Bill is the removal of the requirement that there be a connection between the person in possession of inside information and the company to which the information relates. This requirement has been the downfall of a number of insider trading prosecutions. That connection is very significant. I think that crucial issue has been addressed. The provisions will prohibit any person in possession of insider information, regardless of the source of that information, and who knows or reasonably knows that it is insider information from trading in securities of a company to which the information relates.

A number of key elements in defence which in the past have given rise to difficulties have also been defined, and I will deal with those. Inside information is information which is not generally available, but if it were a reasonable person would expect it to have a material effect on the price of securities. We have a clearer definition of what we are dealing with here. Under the current provisions, expert evidence of the likely effect of particular information in the price of securities is required, and information is regarded as generally available, either if it is already in the public arena or has been made known in a manner likely to bring it to the attention of investors when a reasonable period for the dissemination of information has elapsed.

We are talking about clearer definitions, and that is important. One of the difficulties in relation to prosecutions has been getting definitions to apply in a case. It is important to emphasise these other matters too: provisions have been extended to insider trading in securities of unit trusts and other prescribed interests. Clearly, as we have seen from the activities in the marketplace, one cannot just focus one's attention upon the equities market; one has to deal with other trading activities in the marketplace. The liabilities of companies and partnerships under the insider trading provisions have also been clarified.

I think the question of penalties is very important. The criminal penalties for a breach of insider trading provisions are to be increased 10-fold, with a penalty of $200,000 for individuals and $1m for companies. This is twice what was recommended by the Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs, the Griffiths Committee. This Bill is attempting very realistically to provide greater definition in relation to insider trading and to provide a very clear approach in relation to the link between the individual and knowledge that was obtained.

The question of the onus of proof must also be addressed. The exposure draft was significant in this respect, but if we were to reverse the onus of proof-and this Bill does not do that-it would make prosecution easier. I think it is important to offset this by saying that the increased resources available to the Australian Securities Commission will make it more possible for the ASC to pursue cases.

However, the matter is not set in concrete, and I say this to the honourable member for Higgins (Mr Costello). What this says is that we will examine the process and if as a result of that examination we find that we need to amend the law, then that process will be engaged in. What is clear is that we are in the process of intelligently amending the legislation. I believe that these are intelligent amendments to the legislation.
