SPEECH.SPEAKER: Peacock The Hon A.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have before the House the Courts (Mediation and Arbitration) Bill 1991, which is designed to facilitate and encourage the use of alternative dispute resolution procedures in the Federal Court of Australia and the Family Court of Australia. The coalition will not be opposing passage of the Bill for we welcome and support this long awaited and well overdue reform at the Federal level.

SPEECH.PARA: Before proceeding any further, I will give a brief outline of the Bill. Part 2 will amend the Family Law Act 1975 in order to provide for mediation of family law disputes, either before or after the commencement of proceedings; court referred arbitration, which will be subject to full rights of review; and private arbitration to be conducted outside of the court system, which will be subject to review on questions of law only. Part 3 of the Bill will amend the Federal Court of Australia Act 1976 in order to provide for the referral to mediation or arbitration of disputes arising out of existing proceedings .

Over the past year or so the Government has implemented three new reforms in the family law area. Firstly, the Government took the decision in August of last year to increase funding for marriage guidance counselling services; secondly, in March of this year, the Government acceded to a request by the coalition for the establishment of the Joint Select Committee on Certain Aspects of the Operation and Interpretation of the Family Law Act; and thirdly, the Government, in the form of the Bill presently before the House, is taking steps to facilitate the introduction of mediation and arbitration services in the Family Court.

All those measures are referred to in the coalition law and justice policy, which was released in November 1988. On the first measure relating to marriage guidance counselling, I refer to paragraph 9.8 of the Opposition policy:
The funding of marriage guidance counselling will be increased to enable services to be expanded.
With respect to the second measure, the establishment of the Joint Parliamentary Committee to review the Family Law Act, I refer to paragraph 9.3 of the Opposition policy:

Community concerns about the Family Law Act will be addressed by a Parliamentary Committee which will review the operations of the Family Court and family law, and some of the basic principles on which issues of great importance are determined.
On the third measure, the use of alternative dispute resolution mechanisms in Family Court proceedings, I refer to paragraph 9.9 of the Opposition's policy:

In all family law disputes a higher emphasis should be put on counselling, conciliation and mediation. Judges should be seen to be, or should be, the last resort and should exercise a purely judicial role when disputes cannot be resolved.
Counselling, conciliation and mediation functions should be separate and distinct from the judicial function . . .

I congratulate the Government for having the wisdom to pick up and act upon these important aspects of the coalition's policy on family law. Quite clearly, as in other spheres, if honourable members want to see a charter for the Government's law reform agenda to be carried out in the remaining days of this tired and dispirited Government, they should simply pick up the Opposition's policy. They will see that, seriatim, the Government is working through the Opposition's program. We do not object. We have devised it for the betterment of Australia. It is just that the Government again is bereft of its own ideas and simply turns to the Opposition's policy, either to negate criticism from this side or, indeed, to implement an effective charter for law reform so far as this particular area of government administration is concerned.

As I mentioned earlier, the introduction of mediation and arbitration proceedings in the Family Court arena is a much needed and overdue reform. It is a reform that many bodies have been asking for. These include the family law section of the Law Council of Australia and the Institute of Family Law Arbitrators. Credit should be given to those bodies for their persistence and perseverance. Unfortunately, however, upon a perusal of the Bill it would seem that we still have a long way to go. In a short while I will elaborate upon that observation in more detail.
On the question of the financial resources that may be needed effectively to promote mediation and arbitration programs, I note that the explanatory memorandum tabled with the Bill states:
The amendments are considered to be revenue neutral.

There is expected to be a reallocation of resources. However, the reality is that if court-annexed mediation and arbitration programs are to be successful, it is clear that the courts will need additional resources. This is particularly the case when one has regard to the fact that the modernisation of many of the court buildings for the Family Court and the Federal Court is long overdue. Any practitioner in my own capital city of Melbourne, for instance, will be very familiar with the inadequate and antiquated facilities found in the Family Court and Federal Court buildings. It is near impossible in many cases for the parties to a dispute to sit down and conduct meaningful settlement discussions for the simple reason that they cannot find a spare conference room.

Governments cannot simply pass laws saying that disputants can avail themselves of alternative dispute resolution procedures if the necessary resources to support such programs are not made available. I am hardly an advocate for increased government expenditure. This side of the House is, of course, advocating the cutting of government expenditure. But the Government should not bring in legislation saying that all these procedures will be available, and that it will be revenue neutral, if the resources are not there to support it. It only frustrates the intent of the legislation, to say nothing of the frustration of the parties involved. The legislative will has to be met with and accompanied by a determination to back up such reforms with an appropriate administrative and financial commitment. This problem is reflected in some provisions of the Bill, which state that a matrimonial dispute may be referred to mediation `if a mediation service is available'.

It is for those and many other reasons that the coalition would like to see greater emphasis on the use of mediation and arbitration programs that are separate from and outside the court system. Such an approach would result in a lessening of the burden that is placed on our already underresourced court system, and it would ensure that there is not an empire building element within some of the court systems.

I turn to consider some aspects of the Bill's drafting. I have raised before the question of drafting of legislation. It is hardly the most scintillating topic for those listening to the debate. The drafting of this legislation I find curious. If we can find enough time in the guillotine processes, I hope the Attorney-General (Mr Duffy), who, as ever, is good enough to be here when the legislation is drafted, will be able to respond within the appropriate time that I will certainly make available to the honourable member for Herbert (Mr Lindsay) in racing through this speech. Perhaps the Attorney-General can clarify some of the queries I am raising in relation to the provisions of part 2 of the Bill, which seeks to insert a new part IIIA into the Family Law Act.

Proposed section 19a will allow disputes relating to family law matters to be referred to mediation prior to the commencement of any proceedings. This can be done if an application is made to the court by a parent, a child or a party to a marriage. I have two queries with respect to this provision. Firstly, is it the case that it will not be necessary for all parties to consent to such a referral? It is often said that for mediations to be conducted successfully it is desirable that any referrals to mediation take place on a consensual basis. The absence of a requirement of full consent by all parties may minimise the prospects of a successful and satisfactory resolution being obtained.

Secondly, no provision is made for the court officers to dismiss or reject any complaints which may be considered to be vexatious or frivolous, and there are a number of them in this particular field of jurisdiction. It would seem desirable that such provision be made, and it may well be-perhaps the Attorney-General can confirm whether this is the case-that the rules of the court will be able to address this issue. Perhaps proposed paragraph 123 (1) (sd) will provide the appropriate authority for this, but I must say that the position does not seem clear at all.

I turn to proposed section 19c, which provides that any communications made during the course of the mediation shall be inadmissible in any court proceedings. Obviously it is desirable that there be obligations of confidentiality in such situations. However, the provision in proposed section 19c very much departs from models found in other jurisdictions. Quite often it is provided that communications made during mediations are inadmissible unless the parties and the mediator agree that such communications should be admitted in subsequent proceedings.

One example is Order 54 Rule 6 (3) of the Victorian County Court Rules of 1979, which deals with the mediation of building disputes. Another example can be found in section 21 (L) of the Victorian Evidence Act, which was introduced by the Evidence (Neighbourhood Mediation Centre) Act of 1987. There are very good reasons why such communications in limited circumstances should be admitted in subsequent proceedings. One reason may be that a settlement agreement has been reached during a mediation and it will be necessary for the terms of that agreement and any relevant communications to be disclosed in order that it be both ascertainable and enforceable.

This is consistent with the position at common law relating to the admission of without-prejudice negotiations where such negotiations lead to a binding agreement. The leading case in this area, for those who may be interested, is the 1988 decision of the English House of Lords in the case of Rush &Tomkins Ltd v. Greater London Council, a report of which can be found in volume 3 of the All England Reports at page 737.

The application and relevance of these common law rules in the context of matrimonial disputes also has a long history in England. For those interested in the matter, a very learned discussion of these principles can be found in an article written by Mr J.P. McCrory, entitled `Confidentiality in Mediation of Matrimonial Disputes', which is published in volume 51 of the Modern Law Review, commencing at page 442. So I would ask the Attorney-General to advise the House whether the provisions of proposed section 19c as presently drafted would prevent, in any subsequent proceedings, the admissibility of communications which may be relevant to a binding settlement agreement. I would also ask him to explain why the provisions of proposed section 19d depart from the principles and precedents to which I have referred.

I am sorry to have these queries, but the next query I have relates to proposed subsection 19d (2), which provides that the Family Court may refer a matter to arbitration `with or without the consent of the parties'. I do have some concern with this provision, for it may well be that a particular party will have very good reasons for insisting that his dispute be dealt with by the court rather than by an arbitrator.

This concern is compounded when one has regard to the fact that court annexed arbitrations will be subject to the full rights of review by way of a complete rehearing. An unwilling party, therefore, could be forced to participate in an arbitration and could then face the possibility of going through a complete rehearing before the court. In my view, this is absolutely undesirable. I was going to mention something from my reading of some of the submissions before the Joint Select Committee on Certain Aspects of the Operation and Interpretation of the Family Law Act at present, but that would be improper. But it is well known that the intrusion of the law and lawyers into the family law arena has been one of the brakes on the satisfactory evolution of family law, despite the 1975 Bill.

I am fearful that an unwilling party can be dragged off to arbitration, the matter will come back to the court and the whole thing will be reviewed again, at great cost and at no little inconvenience and contrary to the spirit of seeking to resolve these things, if it is possible, in a more amicable way. It is undesirable and could lead to the incurring of unnecessary expense and effort and could prolong the final resolution of a dispute. This would certainly seem contrary to the general principle that arbitral awards should be binding and conclusive, save with respect to questions of law, in order to bring finality to matters in dispute.

I also have a concern with the provisions of proposed subsection 19f (2) relating to the review of private arbitrations on questions of law. It is provided that upon such a review the full court may `make such decrees as it thinks appropriate, including a decree affirming, reversing or varying the award'. I would hope the word `including' would mean that the Full Court would have the power to remit a matter back to an arbitrator so that it could be dealt with in accordance with any directions given by the court about the proper law to be applied.

I turn now to consider clause 7 of the Bill, which seeks to add to the definition of the phrase `member of the court personnel', as found in section 60 of the Family Law Act, references to approved mediators or approved arbitrators. Earlier this year, Parliament passed the Family Law Amendment Act 1990, which introduced procedures for the handling of custody and access disputes in which allegations of child abuse are made by one party against another. By section 70bb of the Family Law Act, it is now provided that court counsellors and other court personnel, as defined by section 60 of the Act, are obliged to report any suspicions they may have of child abuse, notwithstanding any obligations of confidentiality those personnel may have.

Contrast that obligation of disclosure with the secrecy obligations found in the Bill under present consideration, and in this respect I refer to proposed section 19c. By clause 7, it would seem to me, mediators and arbitrators will be placed in the same position as court counsellors and, as such, would be subject to an obligation to report any suspicions of child abuse which may arise from the conduct of mediation. In effect, mediators will be faced with two conflicting obligations-one of confidentiality and one of disclosure. Perhaps the obligation to disclose will override by reason of section 70bc of the Act, which says that court personnel are to report information about suspected cases of child abuse in spite of any obligation of confidentiality.

However, we must bear in mind that the present Bill is a later amending Act and, therefore, a court may say that it is intended to override the earlier provisions. In the absence of any specific statutory guidance, this is a matter which should be clarified, for it would seem that mediators and arbitrators will be placed in an awkward position.

The effectiveness of the mediation and arbitration programs will very much depend upon the content of the regulations and the rules of the court which are needed to fill in the many gaps found in the proposed legislation. For example, much will depend upon the approval of suitable mediators and arbitrators by way of statutory regulations. Many bodies, such as the Institute of Arbitrators Australia, have well established programs for the registration and grading of arbitrators; and I would hope that, in forming the regulations, the Attorney-General will consult with such bodies so that their wealth of experience in alternative dispute resolution procedures can be utilised.

The provisions of the Bill, when contrasted with the provisions of the uniform State commercial arbitration Acts, are clearly deficient. I would have thought that in the area of, say, private negotiations, it may have been sensible to use the cross-vesting of jurisdiction principles to provide that such arbitrations be governed by the comprehensive regime set out in the uniform State legislation. That regime has also been the subject of much discussion before the courts, and in this regard a considerable body of law has evolved, recourse to which could be had if there are any disputes at the Federal level. Instead, under this legislation, there is the real risk that two separate bodies of arbitration law, one Federal and one State, will develop. This will no doubt cause confusion for many practitioners and parties.

In conclusion, whilst we have some very strong concerns with the apparent anomalies in the drafting of the Bill, we will not be opposing its passage. The Executive-imposed guillotine prevents me from moving any amendments which would address the anomalies to which I have referred. The concerns that we have with certain aspects of the legislation will in the context of family law, however, be able to be examined, I would trust, by the Joint Parliamentary Committee on the Family Law Act. Given that the need to introduce alternative dispute resolution procedures at the Federal level is long overdue, it is important that the enabling legislation be put in place at the earliest possible time. It is with some regret, however, that the model being put forward in this Bill by the Government is undoubtedly an imperfect one.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lindsay Mr E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Much of the credit for the Courts (Mediation and Arbitration) Bill must be attributed to the Government because, on 20 March 1990, the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) announced that in its fourth term the Government would legislate to expand alternatives to court proceedings as a means of resolving disputes. This is a very laudable objective. The Prime Minister said:

SPEECH.PARA: It is essential that the judicial system be as efficient as possible while maintaining the capacity properly to resolve disputes. The use of such processes as mediation and arbitration can help achieve this aim. The Government actively encourages commercial disputes to which it is a party being resolved in this way.

The options of mediation and arbitration are well known to the law. It has been recognised by the legal profession over a long period of time that it is an efficient way and a cost effective alternative to resolving disputes. Indeed, it has been encouraged in recent legislation, particularly the Family Law Act 1976, and since 1987 within the Federal Court of Australia.

The Prime Minister in his statement of 20 March 1990 promised that the legislation would provide a statutory framework within which the Federal and Family Courts of Australia could, by the use of court rules, establish dispute resolution processes and that the rules would, of necessity, be required to deal with such issues as time limits to lodge documents, basic procedures, privilege for persons taking part in the proceedings, recognition and enforcement of orders and, of course, fees and costs. This Bill does precisely that: it provides a legislative framework to enable the Federal Court and the Family Court of Australia to make rules of court for the conduct of mediation and arbitration procedures.

Of course, it is important that these rules of court be made before the Act is proclaimed. This will ensure that there will not be an unjustified expectation in the community that a service will be available before the courts have made appropriate arrangements. So the Bill has that so-called facultative aspect about it. But the Federal Court has been involved in so-called court-annexed alternative dispute resolution practices for some time-in fact, since 1987. Indeed, the court has encouraged mediation being performed by registrars of the court with experience as solicitors in litigation.

I suppose that the path taken by the Federal Court with respect to alternative dispute resolution practices has been one of evolution rather than revolution. Indeed, many legal practitioners will be familiar, for example, with cases under the Trade Practices Act where smaller matters have been referred to registrars by judges conducting directions hearings where the judges have taken the view or where the parties have requested that the matter should be considered by a mediator.

This is a general principle which is highly laudable. Business relationships are important between the parties and they can be damaged severely by protracted litigation, particularly in Trade Practices Act matters. This general practice, which originated in the Federal Court-in fact, it was pioneered in Sydney in the principal registry and then expanded to other capital cities throughout Australia-has been developed to the point where today the Chief Justice has issued a practice note on alternative dispute resolution procedures and the rules of court of the Federal Court have been varied to facilitate their use.

You would be interested to know, Mr Deputy Speaker, that more than 300 matters have been referred to mediation since the commencement of this program and that approximately 70 per cent of those have resulted in the matters being finalised. The remaining 30 per cent of matters have proceeded to trial where the issues have been defined in greater detail. The process of mediation conferences is normally determined by a trained and experienced solicitor who occupies the position of one of the registrars of the court. He or she has power to give directions necessary under section 35a of the Federal Court Act to try to narrow the issues between the parties and identify them in more and greater particularity. He or she also has the dual role, of course, of conciliation-dealing with the matter in an informal manner, trying to isolate the issues of liability, for example, and quantum, and trying to settle either one of those matters to save costs.

This is an important Bill before the House, because the costs of litigation have become a major issue among members of the public. The costs incurred by litigants today, particularly in superior courts, has put the opportunity of conflict resolution for people of limited means in those superior courts completely out of reach unless they obtain legal assistance.

This piece of legislation is part of the ongoing process of law reform initiated by this Government. In this regard, I would like to record the gratitude of the Australian people to the former Attorney-General, Mr Lionel Bowen, and particularly to the present Attorney-General (Mr Duffy). I also recognise, in all generosity, the very constructive contribution of the shadow Attorney-General, the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock) who, on these Bills, has been very informative and very instructive in his comments.

The second point I make is with respect to arbitrators and mediators. I do flag some concern over this particular issue. Notwithstanding that I said the Federal Court has a training program for arbitrators and mediators, it is important once this program is expanded that arbitrators be legally qualified as they will be responsible for determining questions of law. Furthermore, they will be required to possess the necessary faculties and experience to enjoy the confidence of qualified legal practitioners who appear before them. There is scope, for example, for financial experts to be used as arbitrators, especially in tandem with legally qualified arbitrators. Indeed, it should be understood that the rules of court will have to provide and set court fees as parties may be required to pay for the services of mediators and arbitrators in accordance with the determinations of the rules of court.

Before the Attorney-General responds to the questions put to him by the shadow Attorney-General, I want to record the fact that applications for divorce or declarations as to the validity or for nullity of marriage cannot be arbitrated or mediated-and neither should they be. The contract of marriage not only is a contract of great importance to our community but also, in the eyes of many people, is a sacred contract.

The dissolution of that contract is not to be treated either informally or in a way which, in my view, should be made more easy than it is today. In this regard, the power to dissolve a marriage or to declare a marriage null and void still rests with the courts.

The shadow Attorney-General mentioned very briefly some of the schemes with respect to the resolution procedures that have been adopted by the Legal Aid Commission in various places in Australia. I acknowledge the fact that in Queensland, for example, there has been a pilot scheme in operation for some time. In fact, this financial year, as I understand it, $220,000 has been provided so that pre-trial mediation conferences, coordinated by the Legal Assistance Commission of Queensland, can be tested in family law cases where the custody of children is at issue. Indeed, it has been a very successful pilot scheme. In my own city of Townsville we have in residence a judge of the Family Court of Australia who has been of great assistance to the legal profession in north Queensland in relation to the administration of the Family Law Act.

I would like to mention one other matter, and that is that I believe that care should be exercised by the courts in deciding which disputes should be arbitrated, if a high re-hearing rate is to be avoided. I notice that under new subsection 19d (2) it is provided that a matter may be referred to arbitration, whether or not the parties consent.

I pick up the observations of the shadow Attorney-General: these disputes cannot be resolved unless there is consensus on both sides. That has been my experience as a solicitor of more than 25 years standing. There must be that meeting of minds between the parties and a determination to resolve the matter on a consensual basis.

I issue a caution that the courts do need to exercise particular care in proceeding with an order to refer to arbitration matters where there is not full consent by the parties to proceed with that course. Indeed, the courts, as an arm of this legislation, are able to make those rules of court and have a tremendous opportunity to implement in a very ordered way this new law reform, initiated by this Government, and indeed to proceed further down the track enunciated by the Prime Minister back on 20 March 1990 to expand alternatives to court proceedings as a means not only of resolving disputes but also of saving litigants the enormous costs of litigation in superior courts in this country. I congratulate the Government on initiating this much needed law reform in this area.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duffy The Hon M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-In the short period available, firstly I would like to thank the honourable member for Herbert (Mr Lindsay) for his contribution on behalf of the Government. He was supportive of it and raised a couple of matters about which he expressed concern. I understand them, and I also repeat what the honourable member for Herbert said in respect of the Opposition; the contribution by the shadow Attorney-General, the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock), has also been a constructive contribution to this debate. I thank all concerned on both sides of the House.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the first matters that the honourable member for Kooyong raised, where he indicated a genuine concern, was the matter of consent, and that was the last matter touched on by the honourable member for Herbert. They both made the point, correctly, that consent of both parties is needed for this type of process to work properly. In that respect, the position is that consent is not necessary for the process to be made available. However, it does become an essential part of the process if it is to continue; that is, consent is essential for the continuation of the process but it is not necessary for the process to be made available.

So I think the simple answer to that question is: yes, the Government is happy with the way it is framed, that is the way it is intended to work, it will be made available and consent is not required for that, but if people then say, `No way are we going to proceed down this track', then of course it would be ridiculous to do that.

Another two matters were raised that were interlinked. I will deal with one first and deal with the second a little later. The question of admissibility was raised, and I think confidentiality was linked to that. In respect of section 19c, it is really the same, as was indicated by the honourable member for Kooyong, as section 19 of the Family Law Act, which applies to court counsellors. And, yes, the comments made would prevent, in this type of hearing, the use of communication in subsequent proceedings. The simple answer to the question raised by the honourable member for Kooyong is that they are not admissible.

In relation to the query as to section 19f (2), before I come back to the question of confidentiality, the shadow Attorney-General raised in regard to section 19f (2) (b) his concern about `make such decrees as it thinks appropriate, including a decree affirming, reversing or varying an award'. He voiced concern as to whether that included allowing the right to remit the matter. Yes, it does-and it may well be a commentary on drafting there, specifically-because `including' in section 19f (2) (b) is really only as a matter of example; it is not all-embracing. It is including a decree affirming, reversing or varying the award. So the question that I think has been raised correctly is: does it go further than that? Yes, it does; it is only in relation to those two matters which are given really by way of example.

All of those matters, of course, concern me when they are raised, and they were looked at very carefully before the Bill came into this House. However, one matter which I think does need a little more attention is the question of admissions made to arbitrators, because I think it is an essential aspect of this legislation.

What is intended here is that the new section 19c ensures that anything said in mediation, whether court referred or provided at the request of a person, remains confidential and cannot be used in court proceedings. It is essential, as I think is agreed, that parties to a mediation feel free to speak openly and, as a result of being able to open the whole thing up, be able to explore all the possibilities for settlement. If that is not the case, I do not think we are going to achieve what is the basic thrust of the Bill. This provision, that is, section 19c, makes it clear that no admissions made in mediation can be used against a person in further or later proceedings.

In respect of that matter, the shadow Attorney-General did refer, of course-and I think the matter was causing him some concern-to the Family Law Act 1990, particularly section 60, and contrasted the mandatory reporting in child abuse. I think the answer to that is that that amendment to the Family Law Act, to which he referred earlier this year, provided for mandatory disclosure by court personnel of child sexual abuse, which is the other point he took up today. Under this Bill, approved arbitrators and mediators are included in the definition of `court personnel', and so would be bound to disclose child sexual abuse when it comes to their attention.

Section 19c is in identical terms to the section in the Act relating to counsellors. However, there is no question of evidence per se being used in later proceedings. All the mediator can be called on to give evidence about is the fact that he or she did comply with section 73c by notifying the relevant State authorities of the belief that a child had been sexually abused. That section says:
In so doing the mediator is not breaking confidentiality.
I think that to a large extent that probably meets the matter that the honourable member for Kooyong raised.

DEBATE.TITLE: PROCEEDS OF CRIME LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1991

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 30 May, on motion by Mr Duffy:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Peacock The Hon A.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Proceeds of Crime Legislation Amendment Bill 1991 seeks to establish the confiscated assets trust fund. The coalition will not be opposing the Bill, although we do have concerns with one aspect of it. Hopefully that concern will be addressed in further detail when the Bill reaches the other place.

SPEECH.PARA: Under the Executive-imposed guillotine a mere 15 minutes has been allocated for debate on what is a most significant piece of legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is shameful.

—It is quite outrageous. I do not blame the Attorney-General (Mr Duffy) for this: it is because of the total mismanagement of the Leader of the House (Mr Beazley). Accordingly, I will curtail my remarks on the Bill so that others may have a very brief opportunity within the remaining 13 minutes to make a contribution to such a constricted debate.

SPEECH.PARA: On previous occasions I have raised with the Attorney some of the concerns the coalition has with the Proceeds of Crime Act. I will not dwell on those matters today; I simply highlight the fact that some aspects of the Act, as presently drafted, represent a substantial departure from the traditional principles of criminal liability-principles which have taken centuries to develop.

Some illustrations of the novel and somewhat drastic nature of the Act include the reverse onus provisions, whereby it falls upon defendants to establish that their property has not been tainted by illegal activity of any kind, and the fact that the forfeiture powers are not confined to property which, as a matter of fact, can truly be said to represent the proceeds or profits of the relevant crime.

The concerns I have in the proceeds of crime field ought to be understandable concerns to anyone who is concerned about civil liberties. I say that simply because it really has taken us centuries to develop notions of proper regard for men and women and their role in society, and the state simply cannot override those rights. Notwithstanding the concerns I have with some of the changes that were made by the Proceeds of Crime Act in that sense, I give full support to the underlying premise of the Act; namely, that the financial gains of criminal activity be confiscated so that the incentive to commit crime is reduced. I am in total support of that.

The outrageous displays of wealth by those who have been found to have engaged in criminal activity have to be punished, and that wealth has to be taken. In the trials of people charged with this criminal activity, I do not want to see any abuse of the processes that respect the rights of individuals. I give total support to the premise of the Act, but we do need to balance against the laudable goal considerations of justice and fairness. The ultimate objective of our criminal justice system is, after all, the protection of individual liberty, and we must never lose sight of that objective.

Fears about the extent of crime in our society-in particular, organised crime-should not always be met with a response which leads to an increase in State powers at the expense of individual liberty. Our response has to be reasoned and careful and, above all, it must be subject to an open discussion and critical examination of the various options that are available.

However, in putting in place the Proceeds of Crime Act, containing as it does such wide powers of pre-trial seizure and post-trial forfeiture, it falls upon Parliament to ensure that the Act is subject to an ongoing evaluation and that the rights of individuals are not unduly trampled on. Furthermore, we must always be looking for alternative measures to combat crime-by that I mean alternatives to enacting more diverse punishments. In this regard it is pleasing that this Bill that the Attorney has presented, which is under consideration, goes some way towards that, in so far as moneys placed in the trust fund will be used, for example, for drug rehabilitation programs.

The Bill amends various provisions of the Crimes Act 1914, the Customs Act 1901 and the Proceeds of Crime Act 1987, which deal with the forfeiture of property to the Crown. Clause 19 of the Bill will insert into the Proceeds of Crime Act a new part IIa to provide for the establishment of the confiscated assets trust fund. Moneys realised from the forfeiture of assets under the Proceeds of Crime Act and drug trafficking provisions found in division 3 of part XIII of the Customs Act are to be paid into the trust fund which will be administered by the Official Trustee. Under the relevant provisions of both pieces of legislation, the Official Trustee has responsibility for dealing with property that is the subject of restraining and forfeiture orders.

The net proceeds from the trust fund are to be distributed as follows: 50 per cent to law enforcement projects and 50 per cent to programs for the rehabilitation of drug users. The crucial provisions in the Bill are found in clause 19 and, in particular, in proposed new section 34d. By proposed new subsection (2) the Attorney-General will be obliged to make an annual determination as to the equal distribution of funds between specific law enforcement projects and drug rehabilitation programs, as selected by the Attorney and the Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services (Mr Staples) respectively.

Some people may think that the moneys taken from those who have benefited from crime ought then to be paid into Consolidated Revenue. Many honourable members on my own side do not like these small funds and the like that are out to dollop things. The Government is establishing a trust fund. After paying out to State authorities for moneys raised for their crime, et cetera, the net proceeds go to drug rehabilitation and law enforcement programs. To the extent that the Government is setting up a trust fund, I agree with it; it is laudable then to spend the money on these courses.

The only problem I have is that there is no specific accountability to the Parliament. The establishment of a trust fund removes from Parliament the responsibility that it has to determine the uses to which the public moneys are put, and that responsibility is reflected in the provisions of the Constitution which confer upon Parliament the power to appropriate public moneys from Consolidated Revenue. Moneys placed in the trust fund will be placed outside the Consolidated Revenue Fund.

The Bill will confer very wide discretions on the Attorney and the Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services to decide how the trust funds are to be expended. It may be desirable that determinations made by the Attorney on the allocation of trust funds be set out in written instruments that, in turn, could be tabled in both Houses. Furthermore, it may also be appropriate that such determinations be subject to disallowance or variation by Parliament. But at some point we have to have some parliamentary constraint injected. Because of the time constraints that the Executive has imposed on the House, it will be necessary for the Senate to take up this issue.

My colleagues in the other place will give consideration to referring the Bill to the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs with a view to determining whether proposed new section 34d should be amended so that Parliament may have a greater say in the allocation of trust moneys. We have not determined that it will go to that-that will be a matter for those in the other place-but we have said that they should look at the possibility of the Committee examining it.

I conclude by emphasising that we support the underlying premise of the Proceeds of Crime Act and the measure under consideration today, but it is imperative that Parliament has a greater role in monitoring the operation of the Act and the expenditure of trust moneys.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lindsay Mr E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Because of the limitation of time with respect to the debate on the Proceeds of Crime Legislation Amendment Bill, I will confine my remarks in the main to the issue of so-called `distributable funds'. The discretion conferred upon the Attorney-General under paragraph 34d (2) (a) of the Bill relates to the distribution of money to fund law enforcement projects. The discretion is not totally unfettered. The funding must be directed toward a project that `promotes the investigation or detection of, or the prosecution of, persons for breaches of Commonwealth criminal law'. In addition, the Attorney is empowered to and will consult with advisory bodies concerned with law enforcement matters on any major decisions. The remarks on proposed new section 34d in the explanatory memorandum refer to the role of the Law Enforcement Policy and Resources Committee in reaching such decisions.

SPEECH.PARA: The explanatory memorandum also makes it clear that the Minister responsible for health matters will consult concerning the distribution of money to drug rehabilitation and drug education schemes. The Minister will consult with the Ministerial Council on Drug Strategy on significant decisions. Clearly, it would be undesirable to refer to these ministerial councils in the legislation itself because the name, composition and functions of these councils may well change over time.

It should also be noted that proposed new section 34a provides that the trust fund is a trust account for the purposes of the Audit Act 1901. One consequence of this proposed provision is that there is a reporting requirement pursuant to section 50 of the Audit Act and the Finance regulations. The Department of Finance has issued quite detailed guidelines which apply to the financial statements made under section 50.

On 30 May 1991 the Attorney-General (Mr Duffy) and the Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services (Mr Staples) issued a joint media release. They stated that the money available for drug rehabilitation and drug education schemes would be targeted at illicit drugs. They also stated that the focus of the money available for law enforcement would be programs which promote the investigation, detection or prosecution of serious criminal offences. Like any new initiative, the effectiveness of the drug fund will be reviewed after a period of operation with a view to correcting any difficulties that may have emerged.

There are a number of other key points in this Bill. The legislation includes a provision to permit the use of assets seized under the legislation to be directed to law enforcement agencies for operational use. Forfeited property, vehicles and other assets will generally be sold and the profits placed in the trust fund. The legislation even permits the use of confiscated equipment by law enforcement agencies. In this regard, the United States experience in the application of trust funds established under similar legislation has been of assistance in framing this Bill. In the United States the proceeds of sale of forfeited property and forfeited cash are deposited in the asset forfeiture fund. Physical assets may be allocated for official use. The Department of Justice agencies are entitled to share in currency and proceeds of sale.

One of the most important initiatives contained in this Bill is the provision to allow property seized from criminals to effect a substantial increase in funds available for law enforcement and drug rehabilitation. That is to say, money available from the trust fund would be in addition to funds normally available as part of the Budget process for law enforcement and drug rehabilitation. This is a major reform. I understand it was opposed in some feckless advice given by the Department of Finance to the Cabinet when this Bill was drafted.
The Government is to be congratulated on the introduction of this Bill. I know that the Australian people applaud the legislation as another spike in the coffin of organised crime.

This follows the revelations in the last few days in relation to an operation in South Australia.
