TALK.START.PARA: —I inform the House that the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Mr Humphreys) is attending a Returned Services League conference today in Melbourne and will be absent from Question Time. Questions normally addressed to Mr Humphreys should be directed to the portfolio Minister, Mr Howe.

—My question is directed to the Prime Minister. I refer him to comments by his deputy to the effect that the Commonwealth should spend more money on improving urban infrastructure. Will the Prime Minister confirm that the support of the left wing of his Party in the leadership battle was conditional on a deal which would see the proceeds of asset sales spent on infrastructure projects and that that resolution will now be put to the upcoming Australian Labor Party conference next month?
—No.
—My question is directed to the Treasurer. Will he please outline to the House the Government's intentions with regard to its strategy for fighting inflation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Burke for his question. He has raised a very important issue. The honourable member for Blaxland recognised that reducing the inflation rate was a major objective for Australia. To see inflation reduced to sustainably low levels is my objective and that of this Government. The reasons for targeting inflation are quite clear. It is no accident that those countries which have managed to control inflation are those which have performed best over recent years. By cauterising inflation from the economic body in Australia, we establish the basis for the creation of an investment environment which is weighted towards the long term and towards production and which is the basis for sustainable, not illusory, wage outcomes. It gives an automatic advancement in welfare for those on fixed incomes. It gives an automatic increase in competitiveness and further reductions in interest rates.

ANSWER.PARA: The prognosis for further reductions in inflation is good. However, further reductions will not just fall into our laps, and that is why there will be no relaxation of our efforts to reduce inflation; it is why policy will continue to be directed towards achieving a low inflation environment for the 1990s.

TALK.START.PARA: —Following the Treasurer's answer to the last question, I ask him: is the Government now committed to achieving the 3 to 3 1/2 per cent inflation target outlined by the Governor of the Reserve Bank of Australia last week? If not, when will the Treasurer communicate the Government's own inflation target to the Governor so that he may institute action through his board to make appropriate adjustments to monetary policy settings?

—The first thing I would like to say to the Deputy Leader of the Liberal Party is that we do not pretend to the Australian community that we can achieve a nil inflation rate, as the Liberal Opposition tries to pretend. We have actually achieved something concerning inflation. We do not merely prattle about it. We are in the business of getting inflation to the lowest possible level sustainable with the other goals for general overall good economic management. The former Treasurer announced last week the two year forecast that we are working on. The Expenditure Review Committee is already looking at the next Budget and we are talking about an inflation rate that seems to be in the order of 4 per cent.
—That is your target, is it?
—The target will be to have lower inflation.
—Lower than four?
—Order! The Deputy Leader of the Opposition!

—But we are not going to get into the business of trying to predict an absolutely precise level of inflation. It is just simply nonsense. For the Opposition to pretend that it can get it to nil or that it or anyone else can pick it within a percentage point is nonsense.
—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security. Would the Minister inform the House of progress in implementing the active employment strategy?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howe The Hon B.L.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: DEPUTY PRIME MINISTER; COMMUNITY SERVICES AND HEALTH

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Prospect for her question, which is timely because the active employment strategy Bill, the social security Bill that would change the nature of benefits and the approach to social security payments for the unemployed, will be implemented on 1 July this year, having just passed through this House of the Parliament. It links the social security payment to the Commonwealth Employment Service, creating structured links between income support, labour market assistance, opportunities and client obligation.

ANSWER.PARA: There are two main thrusts: the increased investment in labour market programs and a new system of payments to replace unemployment benefits-the Job Search allowance and the Newstart allowance. The Job Search allowance will be available for 12 months only. The onus will be clearly on the job seeker to find work through an active and effective job search. The Newstart allowance, for the longer term unemployed, will involve a more comprehensive and intensive process of contact assistance and client obligation. Either payment will continue only if client obligations are met.

The active employment strategy is a substantial part of this Government's commitment to education, on and off the job training and work experience to maintain and improve the skills that people have in and out of work. The other key element is the training guarantee, a policy initiative of my colleague the Minister for Employment, Education and Training. Government and employers are working in partnership to pretrain and retrain workers in employment. In terms of this fundamental restructuring of the payment and the link being made between income security and labour market programs, Australia is developing policies that are advanced in terms of the approach to payments in a difficult time of recession and a time in which there is quite high unemployment.

It is interesting to look at what is proposed to be introduced by the Government from 1 July over and against the reaffirmation by Senator Alston of the Opposition's approach in this area-an approach in which the Opposition would, in a sense, seek to mirror the Government. In fact, the Opposition's approach is dictated by a bottom line in terms of Budget results-that is, access to benefits and assistance payments in the end will be arbitrarily determined by a decision that only 50 per cent of those who are out of work after nine months would be eligible for any payment at all. At best, that payment would be the special benefit. Not only will that special benefit type payment approach be linked directly to the unemployed but some kind of work test will be effectively adopted to the range of benefits including, according to Senator Alston, the unemployment benefit, invalid and sole parent pensions and sickness benefits.

For example, even in a situation where a person is on a sickness benefit and is clearly unable to work because of sickness, apparently the Opposition would apply some test in terms of the person's activity to seek work. That is an absolute contradiction in terms, and reflects an approach by an Opposition that it is not interested in the welfare or the future of those who might be unemployed or those who may be temporarily on social security payments. Simply, it is an approach which would reduce expenditure irrespective of the social consequences.

In terms of the issue that is raised, we have on the one hand a policy that is coherent and has been worked through in terms of the links between income security, labour market programs, training and rehabilitation. There is a sense of purpose in terms of the system. On the other hand, we have the negative, punitive kind of approach that Senator Alston is speaking about, which would denigrate, deny and effectively simply seek to save money rather than provide any kind of effective response to those desperately in need through unemployment.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the new Treasurer to promises by his failed predecessor made during the last election campaign that foreign debt would be stabilised within the life of this Government by reducing the current account deficit to 2 1/2 per cent of national production. Does the new Treasurer agree with the targets set by his failed predecessor?

—First of all, the previous Treasurer did not fail. Let us just nail that one. It is very easy to pose a great catalogue of targets but the basic proposition is that we are sticking to the fundamentals that we have stuck to. We are achieving results on a whole wide range of economic parameters and we will continue to do so.
—I direct my question to the Minister for Transport and Communications. What action is being taken by the Government to give the Australian people greater access to cheaper overseas telephone calls?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for his question. As a fellow who takes a very deep interest in the international relations problems of this country, he is no doubt very concerned about these matters. It is always nice to see him around. Queensland members are well travelled. I should give a tip to international travellers-from this point on, they should reverse the charges when they are calling home.

ANSWER.PARA: As the proposals of the Overseas Telecommunications Commission (OTC) to vary tariffs from 1 August indicate, the Government's price control arrangements are working. As a result of these variations, Australians phoning overseas will save over $6m in a full year. The new rates will mean reduced charges when calling from Australia to major world destinations, which account for around 86 per cent of Australia's total international direct dialling (IDD) traffic. Under the new IDD rates--

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you paying for stamps?

—What, with Charlie Blunt? Under the new IDD rate, the standard charge for destinations such as the United Kingdom, the United States of America, Canada, Hong Kong, Ireland and Singapore, will drop from $1.60 per minute to $1.49 per minute-a reduction of 6.9 per cent. This means that, in real terms, prices fell by over 8 per cent in 1990 and have fallen by over 70 per cent since 1980. With the Government's price control arrangements in place, and strengthen from next year, real reductions will be continued.

—I direct my question to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. As these matters have a bearing on his appointment as Minister for that portfolio and his ability to perform in that portfolio, I ask: did his then Secretary, Bill Kelty, in October or November 1988, or subsequently, advise him that he was going to meet the Prime Minister at Kirribilli House on 25 November 1988? Therefore, did he know about or did he approve of his attending such a meeting and when precisely did he learn of the Hawke, Keating, Abeles, Kelty meeting and related deal? Given the Minister's track record with the storemen and packers wool storage dispute and with the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU), how can he have the gall to accept the Primary Industries and Energy portfolio?

—Order! The first part of the question is out of order; the second part of the question is in order. The Minister is not responsible in this House for the things that he did as the President of the ACTU.
—What did he do?
— I do not know what he did but he is not going to be able to answer questions about it here.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Crean The Hon S.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —In relation to the second part of the question, Mr Speaker: the question of what I bring to this portfolio, given my background, has been alluded to. Let me just go through it because what the honourable member has to understand is my track record of experience. Whilst it is true that the Federated Storemen and Packers Union of Australia was involved in two lengthy wool disputes, it is also true that in winning those disputes we effected significant change in wool stores in this country and acceptance of sale by objective measurement that reduced costs. That is the Storemen and Packers Union connection.

ANSWER.PARA: In fact, in 1982, when I was still the Secretary of the Storemen and Packers Union, I participated, at the invitation of Peter Nixon, a previous primary industries Minister in this House, in a mission to try to sort out problems associated with the export of live sheep from this country-an area that had been bedevilled by industrial disputation, as the honourable member for Barker would be aware, and which that mission resolved. The honourable member should talk to the industry representatives who went with me on that mission and get from them their view as to my constructive input. He should then come back and talk to me about what I have brought to the resolution of disputes.

I have read reports in the press about what the honourable member for Barker had to say in respect of the Mudginberri dispute. The reality is that the ACTU never had the Mudginberri dispute until it was a hopeless case. That is correct and the honourable member acknowledges it. Indeed, do honourable members remember Jay Pendarvis? He is not in business any more because of the Opposition's strategy.

TALK.START.PARA: —Where is he? What happened to him?
—Where is he? When I had my first discussion with Jay Pendarvis--

ANSWER.PARA: Mr Snowdon interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member for the Northern Territory!

—When I had my first discussion with Jay Pendarvis, I in fact was able to reach an agreement with him that not only would have gained the acceptance of the meatworkers union but would have had the potential to guarantee him an expanded industry base. The people who would not back it were from the National Farmers Federation. They were too far involved in pushing the political issue associated with their fighting fund. I ask the House to reflect on this: is the other side genuinely interested in solving industrial issues that affect their members' interests, including the production process and the supply to the wharf? I am.

ANSWER.PARA: The honourable member for Barker might recall that, as part of our contribution as members of the Rural and Allied Industries Council, to which we were appointed by the Treasurer in his role as the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, I put the proposition to him in relation to the 4 per cent second tier wage negotiations back in 1986-87 that farmers ought to put pressure on the ACTU-and I said that I would facilitate it-by arguing that that the trade-off for the 4 per cent did not involve work on the farms but guaranteed continuity of supply through the wharves. The honourable member for Barker walked away from it-it was too hard.

All I am saying is this: in many instances I have been involved in disputes that have affected the farm community. But in all of them I have always put forward a constructive solution. The fact that that has not been able to be realised in all cases has not been my fault. So that is the quality of the position.

I think the constituency that is represented by the coalition, in particular the National Party of Australia-the constituency, I might add, that I am now proud to represent as Minister-ought to understand that background in assessing whether they should rush to judgment about my capacity to represent them. In all instances, whether it has been in the trade union movement or any other representative role I have had, I have represented my constituency to the best of my capacity and in many cases have won. The rural community, therefore, not only has to appreciate that but work with me.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is that a threat?
—Order! The honourable member for Mackellar!
—They will find a very strong advocate in me. I must say that in terms of my capacity to advocate other positions, the track record has been pretty good.

ANSWER.PARA: I am indebted to the other side of the House. I do not think that I could have had a much better introduction to this portfolio over the last 24 hours in terms of the community knowing what interests I now represent as Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. I also thank them for facilitating so quickly the circumstances with which those with whom I am going to have to deal now recognise the need to sit down and talk with me. I thank them for that, I will participate actively in arriving at constructive solutions and I believe that we will make some significant progress with them.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Transport and Communications. Is it the intention of the Government to increase telephone charges for Australia's telephone subscribers? Is it intended to raise new taxes on telecommunications?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —In answer to the honourable gentleman's question, as those who read our legislation will know, it is our intention to place a price cap on services of 5.5 per cent below the rate of inflation, which will ensure that the Australian telephone consumer will be getting his or her service at a continually falling real price. It also is not our intention to introduce a tax on telephone services.

ANSWER.PARA: If a 15 per cent consumption tax, for example, were introduced by the Opposition, it would have these effects. Under such a policy, a standard connection fee would increase by $37.95 per subscriber. That is, an Opposition government will tax every Australian $37.95 for the privilege of having a phone connected. The maximum connection fee-and here I address the constituency of my new ministerial colleague the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy-for rural and remote area customers will be taxed at a rate of $225.15. This tax will apply to all Australians who have the misfortune of residing further than 16 kilometres from an exchange and who need a telephone.

My colleagues opposite in the National Party of Australia would be better placed in asking themselves a few questions about getting some detail out on their taxation proposals instead of bothering the new Minister, who is amply capable of looking after himself. They should go around their constituencies and explain why the Opposition intends to increase that telephone connection fee by $225.15.

It does not stop there. Business line rentals will have a tax applied of $43.79; residential line rentals will have a tax applied of $23.33. In addition to these not insignificant imposts, every time anyone uses the telephone, be it for business or for social purposes, a coalition proposal will tax them. Local calls will be subject to a 3.6c tax. Community calls used by people in the bush to keep in contact with their local service centre will be taxed 3.6c per three minutes.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about Lifeline?

—And Lifeline will be taxed at exactly the same rate. Business will face a tax of 25.6c for every three minutes of telephone usage between Sydney and Melbourne. The contribution of such an impost to the inflation rate, which everybody has been talking about here on the Opposition benches, might actually have a bit of an impact on them.

ANSWER.PARA: I have just rejected an application by Telecom Australia to increase the price of a call from a pay phone by 10c to 40c. The Opposition would allow the increase but pocket the 10c. A 10-minute phone conversation between a mother in Broken Hill and her daughter in Sydney will be taxed at 86.3c.

It is obvious that the people who will be the hardest hit will be those residing in the bush living far from exchanges and who rely on the telephone to go about their everyday lives. This is something to which I expect the National Party to give some consideration in the not too distant future.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Prime Minister. Is it a fact that the TNT Ansett group has benefited in a number of ways from its dealings with the Government, including the chartering of Royal Australian Air Force (RAAF) aircraft at rates at least 75 per cent below the full cost recovery rate during the airline dispute; the waiving of more than $8m in charges by the Federal Airports Corporation during the dispute as part of the $100m compensation package; the signing of a 25-year lease over Australian airport terminals on the eve of the announcement of the deregulation of the airline industry in 1987; the awarding of the coastal surveillance contract to Skywest Airlines Pty Ltd despite the claims of Amman Aviation Pty Ltd being upheld in the courts; and the deal concerning RAAF radar contracts with an Italian consortium for which Ansett was the local agent? In view of this close relationship between the TNT Ansett companies and the Government, does the Prime Minister understand why ordinary Australians are now asking what the price of Sir Peter Abeles's silence over the Kirribilli conspiracy was?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The difference between ordinary Australians and the honourable gentleman is profound, and they are not asking that question at all. To the extent that the honourable gentleman or other honourable members opposite want to address their minds to it, I am more than happy to deal with it. If there is one Prime Minister and one government which have acted in terms of a disastrous impact upon the interests of Ansett TNT, it is this Prime Minister and this Government, because under the Opposition's cosy relationship of the past it kept in existence in this country, at the expense of Australian travellers generally, the two-airline agreement.

ANSWER.PARA: The two-airline agreement was an arrangement between the two airlines to print money. It was this Prime Minister and this Government which said, `Enough of that cosy agreement; we are bringing to an end the arrangement whereby the Government airline and Ansett, the private airline, can just hold this country to its will and determine what the outcome will be'. It was this Prime Minister, this Government-to the great expense, I may say, of Ansett TNT-which brought that cosy arrangement, the creation and perpetuation of those opposite, to an end.

I might also refer to the fact that it was this Government which introduced full user pays charging for airport services and refused to let Ansett bid for Australian Airlines Ltd. May I say that it is this Government which has gone about the privatisation of Australian Airlines-something that was within the province of those opposite to do. They never did it. Why did they not do it? Because they had this cosy two-airline agreement, which suited the Government airline and suited Ansett. We have gone about the privatisation of Australian Airlines, obviously in that way giving it a much greater capacity to compete with Ansett. It was this Prime Minister, this Government, that did it-not those opposite.

Of course, the pilots dispute itself, which those opposite are talking about-what a nice present I gave to Ansett there!-cost it in the order of $100m. But, fortunately for this country, we had a situation where the two airlines-Ansett and Australian Airlines-and this Government were prepared to do what the Opposition did not have the guts to do, and that was to stand up to a murderous claim of 30 per cent by the Australian Federation of Air Pilots right throughout that dispute. Right throughout that dispute, those opposite gave them aid and comfort at every point.

Those opposite would have assisted in the smashing of the wages system in this country. They would have brought about what they did in 1978 when the honourable member for Bennelong was the Treasurer and the Leader of the Opposition was the adviser. What was the outcome? There was an 18 per cent wages explosion because they did not have the guts then to stand up to rapacious union demands. Well, we did!
Opposition members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —The Leader of the Opposition will cease interjecting. Order! The honourable member for Mayo! The honourable member for Lowe!

—In the process of doing that, we inflicted a loss of $100m on Ansett. Some deal for Ansett! Some deal for Ansett TNT! The abolition of the two-airline agreement, the introduction of full user pays, the privatisation of Australian Airlines to give greater competition, the pilots dispute which cost them $100m-and I am the friend of Ansett and Abeles. My God, what a friend!

—My question is addressed to the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories. Most honourable members, or maybe I should say that most honourable members on this side of the House, will be aware that today is World Environment Day. Could the Minister inform the House what the Australian Government is doing to mark this day and, in particular, to ensure that the theme `No excuse let's reduce' becomes reality?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kelly The Hon R.J.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: THE ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for his question and I also thank those members of the House who have made their contributions today by circulating material to schools and also by giving environment awards.

ANSWER.PARA: The theme for World Environment Day, as the honourable member has said, is `No excuse let's reduce'. What we are all about is reducing our demands on the world's natural resources and solving the problem of our ever increasing mountains of waste. In line with that, and in line with the principles that this Government has espoused and followed in relation to ecologically sustainable development, the Government has been preparing a national strategy on waste minimisation and recycling. Later today I will be releasing and tabling this document.

There will be a three-month period for the public to comment on this document, which has developed as a result of discussions with the State governments, local government, industry and the broader community, including the conservation movement. It includes a range of proposed measures which would complement the work currently being done by State and local governments. It aims to set targets for reducing waste, such as a 50 per cent reduction in waste going to land fill by the year 2000. It also sets indicative planning targets to be achieved by 1995 for the recycling of major materials including plastics at 25 per cent, currently at 6 per cent; glass at 45 per cent, currently at 36 per cent; paper at 40 per cent, currently at 32 per cent; and aluminium cans at 75 per cent, currently 62 per cent.

The document contains much more than targets; it also discusses pollution standards; support for research and development, because this Government believes that is an essential part of any strategy; economic and regulatory measures; and, very importantly, purchasing of recyclable materials. A further area, which we cannot neglect, is education and information activities.

The strategy aims to pull together the approaches being taken around Australia to provide leadership at the national level and hopefully get better results. We believe this strategy is also critical to the growth of a potentially major industry in this country-waste management. We believe, according to--

TALK.START.PARA: —By `we', to whom are you referring?

—I am referring to the advice the Government has received particularly through the Prime Minister's Science Council, because at a discussion that took place last week it estimated that the industry is worth about $4 billion to this country. This is a way we can achieve a very important growth industry for this country, and the Commonwealth is showing a lead.

ANSWER.PARA: This is only part of the strategy. The main thing the Government has done is encourage kids and communities all around Australia working to do something for this country-that is, show by their own example that they can reduce waste in their own homes, can reduce fuel and energy consumption and can make their own personal contribution.

Today I also announced a number of environment awards, in particular to some schools throughout Australia. I know that children from the Freshwater High School, present in the public gallery today, won a particular award. Many other schools in Australia deserve to be congratulated on their marvellous contribution to the environment. I wish every honourable member and everyone of our generation had made as much contribution as the kids of Australia have.

Finally, I would like to congratulate Mr Don Henry, the Director of the Worldwide Fund for Nature Australia, because today he received the United Nations Environment Program Global 500 award for services to the environment. I thank everybody, both in this House and in the broader community, for their marvellous contribution to World Environment Day, and I hope it continues well after today.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Prime Minister. I refer him to the statement made by the former Treasurer and honourable member for Blaxland in February last year when he denied there had been any deal about the leadership and asserted that the Prime Minister would definitely serve the whole of the next term. Did the honourable member for Blaxland ever complain to the Prime Minister about being forced to participate in the Prime Minister's scheme to deceive the Australian people at the 1990 election? Or is the failed former Treasurer just as guilty as the Prime Minister?
—Of course, I will not refer to discussions between the honourable member for Blaxland and myself. I certainly would not intend to, and I do not think he would expect me to.
—I direct my question to the Prime Minister. Could he advise the House of the Government's commitment to reviewing Commonwealth programs in the context of the Special Premiers Conference process?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Moreton for his question. In launching my Commonwealth-State initiative in a speech to the National Press Club on 19 July last year, I said that as a nation we must find a better way to integrate the legitimate policy interests of the two major tiers of government-the Commonwealth and the State-and also local government, and to achieve a more integrated and effective delivery of programs and services to Australia's citizens. I said that I believed we should be ready to review all services delivered by the Commonwealth and the States.

ANSWER.PARA: I also made the quite fundamental point, which should be understood, that in all this the Australian Government can never avoid or evade its genuine national responsibilities. The central aim of the Commonwealth-State relations exercise is to work cooperatively with the States to achieve a national approach and agreed national objectives. At the Special Premiers Conference in October last year, heads of government commissioned reviews of a number of functional areas in recognition of the problems that currently exist in part because of duplication and overlap between different levels of government in many service delivery areas. Some of that duplication eats up resources which could go to the needy across a range of services. With cooperation between levels of government, I believe we could free some of those resources.

The Government which I have had the pleasure to lead for over eight years now has a very proud record indeed in advancing social justice through protecting the interests of the more disadvantaged members of the community. It is a record which, as my colleague the Deputy Prime Minister said, is now belatedly being recognised by those opposite as they dump their policy of subsidising the wealthy on child-care and have apparently now-at long last-been converted to the idea of means testing. How genuine a conversion this turns out to be remains unknown, as does much of the Opposition's policy until the Leader of the Opposition checks with his party room. It is good to see the Government's policies at last recognised by some honourable members opposite.

In conjunction with the States, priority has been given to improving services for groups which include the most disadvantaged-Aborigines, women, the aged, the disabled and the homeless. The next Special Premiers Conference, which is scheduled for July, will consider reports from various working groups established last October with a view to progressing issues through to the November Special Premiers Conference.

I want to make this very clear because I know it can be a matter of legitimate concern to many people in the Federal area of government and representation: any agreements or changes to future roles and responsibilities in the Special Premiers Conference context must protect the interests of clients and must clearly specify national interests and set out agreed national objectives. In looking at that, the views of the community will provide an important input to that process. For example, in the community services and health area arrangements have been made with the Australian Council of Social Service to coordinate national consultation with the community welfare sector.

As Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Commonwealth-State Relations, the Deputy Prime Minister will have a role beyond that of his portfolio interest in support of the Special Premiers Conference process. His support for the process has been invaluable in the work that has taken place to date, and he will now be working even more closely with me in the future to achieve these important national objectives.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Prime Minister. I refer him to his news conference held last Monday, in which he thanked the honourable member for Blaxland for `tremendous service he has given to the Government'. In the light of this statement and other words of praise that the Prime Minister has showered upon the honourable member for Blaxland, why did the Prime Minister instruct his two press secretaries to go out on the eve of the leadership challenge to complain to the media that Keating's poor economic management has not been exposed? Is this another example of the Prime Minister's increasingly infamous dishonesty? Now that the Prime Minister is totally bereft of any credibility--
—Order! The honourable member for Downer will rephrase the last part of his question.

—Is this another example of the Prime Minister being misleading? Now that the Prime Minister is totally bereft of any credibility, and given Senator Richardson's comment on radio 2UE this morning, which was that the honourable member for Blaxland would do a better job as Prime Minister, when will the Prime Minister have the decency to resign?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Honourable members can see that I am trembling with fear at this devastating question. Is that the best that the honourable member for Mayo can do? I repudiate the premises of the honourable member's question and invite him to study the whole of the transcript of the interview by John Laws with Senator Richardson. I am more than content with the totality of what Senator Richardson had to say. It seemed to me to be a very fair and balanced interview, which did credit to both the honourable member for Blaxland and myself. We both deserve credit; we both got it from Senator Richardson.

ANSWER.PARA: The final point I want to make is this: the honourable member for Blaxland and I, unfortunately, have been engaged in a traumatic exercise. That is the truth. It has given me, and I think it has given the honourable member for Blaxland, little pleasure. It has given neither of us little pleasure; but I express the belief that the trauma of that experience gave neither of us pleasure. How could it when we have had such a long, close and productive working relationship. We can have no pleasure out of it. All I can say is that nothing that has happened in the last few days will ever diminish in my judgment the debt that this Party, this Government and this country owes to the honourable member for Blaxland.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel. I ask: will the Australian defence forces be providing assistance to the very significant Lions International Convention to be held in Brisbane later this month, from 17 to 22 June?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bilney The Hon G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Most of the questions that I have answered at this dispatch box in relation to the Australian defence forces have been in relation to their performance in wartime or in war-like situations. Addressing the question asked by the honourable member for Brisbane, in whose electorate some very substantial defence establishments exist, gives me a chance to acknowledge their performance in other respects.

ANSWER.PARA: It does not come to attention often enough that the Australian defence forces in peacetime carry out some very significant tasks, many of them unsung. They get great publicity during times of flood or emergency and disaster in Australia, when they do an excellent job.

In the case of the Lions International Convention to which the honourable member refers, that meeting commences in Brisbane in less than a fortnight's time. It is not an ordinary convention because the organisers are expecting in excess of 40,000 visitors from more than 130 countries. As a result of requests from the convention organisers and the Brisbane City Council, it has been decided to provide an Army traffic control unit to organise the movement of 10,000 Lions, of the two-legged variety, to and from the Gold Coast each day. The Army has developed a plan to establish and run a terminal that will facilitate that passenger movement.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is about the limit of your understanding of this portfolio.

—In answer to the pretty penetrating comment of the honourable member for Deakin, the plan calls for the coordination of 300 buses, running on 13 routes, delivering passengers to more than 120 destinations from 7.30 in the morning until 11.00 at night. That is similar to moving a force of divisional size, garrisoned over an area the size of Canberra, to and from Goulburn each day. It is on the same scale as the Kangaroo 89 exercise, without the associated costs of troops, transport, fuel, vehicles and so on.

ANSWER.PARA: I believe that the Army will fulfil a very valuable social role by providing defence assistance to the Lions Convention, and it will gain international exposure for its expertise in the very important logistical functions which are so much a part of defence exercises. It is naturally a unique training opportunity in that regard.

In answer to the honourable member's question, this support for the Lions Convention is just one example of the defence force's assistance to the civil community. We are aware of their work fighting bushfires and floods, providing medivac services in emergencies and last, but, of course, not least, guaranteeing our security. On behalf of the Government, and of the House in general, I wish the Lions Convention well, and I am confident that the Army will do an excellent job in the assistance it is providing.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Prime Minister to his statement that the Kirribilli conspiracy meeting was called at the initiative of the Secretary of the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU) and that the people at the meeting were there on the initiative of Mr Kelty. I ask the Prime Minister: how does he justify handing the prime ministership to the ACTU as just something to be brokered?
—He obviously has run out of prepared questions because if that was a prepared question, it would rate amongst the more pathetic that I have ever been asked.
—Like your lies.
—I have said in this place before and I say it again--
—Order! The honourable Prime Minister might resume his seat. The honourable member for Corinella will withdraw that remark.
—I withdraw.

—I have traversed this matter before. The prime ministership of this country and the decision about it, when the Australian Labor Party is in power, rests in one place and one place only. It rests in the Caucus of the Labor Party, and it cannot be and has never been and never will be transferred to any other place.

—My question is directed to the Attorney-General. It concerns matters relating to small investors, particularly those in unit trusts and prescribed interests and relates to the problems that arose in the 1980s. I ask: what is being done to improve the position of these small investors in relation to Australia's corporate sector?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Duffy The Hon M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Stirling for his question. I am aware of the concerns mentioned by him. In addition, he has had a particular interest in this area through the Edwards committee. In order to address those concerns, the advisory committee under the Act will, in conjunction with the Australian Law Reform Commission, be reviewing laws relating to prescribed interests not only in the area of unit trusts but the wider area of prescribed interests, which is an area of particular importance to the honourable member.

ANSWER.PARA: In that way, it will bring together the resources of the Law Reform Commission and combine them with the business input of the advisory committee, in order to address what is a very complex area of law and one of great concern to small investors, in particular, and one which is acknowledged as such by the more enlightened of those opposite, such as the honourable member for Higgins. Grave concerns have been expressed about the need for the regulation of unit trusts and prescribed interests generally, and this review, combining business input, will be something that investors and consumers will welcome as a step which should be taken as quickly as possible.

As honourable members are aware, it is part of an ongoing reform package in this area. We have now put in place a well funded, national regulator in this country. The Government's vision, however, of a better corporate regulation in this country does not end there. We have in place an extensive ongoing program. As honourable members will be aware, the first amendment Bill in the area of consolidation of accounts involves insider trading and, despite some misinformed comment, it will make that area far more effective whilst at the same time striking that difficult balance of ensuring that proper protections are available for accused persons.

We are not going to end there, either. The other matters to be dealt with are the Australian company number and the matters arising out of the review in that area, provisions relating to fundraising, and shorter settlement periods for share transfers to enable the stock exchange to improve its efficiency. There is also a third Bill in the area of loans to directors, insolvencies and rights of shareholders.

In conclusion, for those members such as the honourable member for Stirling and others who are interested in this area, this will be an ongoing reform package which is directed specifically at the area that he is referring to of protecting the interests of investors in this country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

FINANCE AND PUBLIC ADMINISTRATION STANDING
Australian iron and steel industry

The recommendations contained in the report by the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration, entitled `Australian Iron and Steel Industry' were considered by the Government in conjunction with the report by the Steel Industry Authority on its review of the Steel Industry Plan.

The Government rejected the recommendation of the Standing Committee that secondary dumping be referred to the Industries Assistance Commission. Such a reference would not serve any useful purpose. Secondary dumping is almost impossible to prove. In addition, Professor F H Gruen, in his report on his review, in 1986, of the Customs Tariff (Anti-Dumping) Act 1975, advised that there are two answers, and only two logical answers, to secondary dumping problems-take duties off inputs or put higher duties on outputs.

The first of these would have limited value in assisting domestic manufacturers of steel-based goods, since their steel inputs are largely Australian made. The second runs counter to the Government's policy of reducing tariff levels.

The Government also rejected initially the recommendations regarding changes to the Developing Countries preference scheme. However, the Industry Statement of 12 March this year announced that preferential tariff arrangements for Singapore, Taiwan, Hong Kong and the Republic of Korea will be phased out from 1 July 1992.

The Committee recommended that the ACTU accept responsibility for overall union commitment to the Steel Plan and act to obtain greater commitment by workers at the shop floor level. I am pleased to record that progress has been made on a comprehensive series of agreements between BHP and the unions concerned. National agreements with the individual unions will form the basis for local agreements at each of the three steelmaking plants. Some of these agreements have been ratified at all levels, and others are well advanced.
These agreements provide for continuing improvements in productivity, security of employment, changes in work practices and ongoing training programs for employees.

The Committee recommended that, if a new voluntary restraint agreement on steel exports to the United States is unavoidable then an increase in the tonnage allowed into the American market be negotiated. This was achieved.

The original Voluntary Restraint Agreements (VRAs) with the USA were revised and renewed in 1989 and discussions are proceeding now on a multilateral steel agreement to succeed the current system of bilateral VRAs.
