DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker has received a letter from the honourable member for Mackellar (Mr Carlton) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The disastrous consequences for the Australian community of the deals of the Hawke-Keating government.
I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of members required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carlton The Hon J.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The House now has a good opportunity to look at eight years of the Hawke-Keating Government. Now that the deputy prime ministership has passed onto somebody else, now that the treasurership has passed on to somebody else, we can have a long, hard look at just what this Government has delivered for Australia and Australians over eight years. One would have to say by way of overall summary that this has been a government of deals and of deception. It is a partnership that began with deals and deception with the overthrow of Mr Hayden. It has continued for eight years on the basis of deals and deception and, ironically for the two players, it has ended with the partners deceiving each other.

SPEECH.PARA: The fact that they deceived each other, whilst in itself utterly disgraceful, is nowhere near as disgraceful as the fact that people holding positions of high trust-as the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the honourable member for Blaxland (Mr Keating) did-deceived the Australian public. It is utterly appalling that in the process of dealing and deceiving each other they perpetrated one of the most outrageous deceptions on the Australian public that we have ever seen in political life.

Let us understand that this is not the normal stuff of politics. It is not sufficient for people such as Senator Button to brush this aside as the sort of thing that happens in elections. It is not a case of overoptimism; it is not a case of gilding the lily in an election campaign; it is not even a case of avoiding an issue. It was a case of cold, calculated deception. It was also a cold, calculated conspiracy, solemnly witnessed, because the conspirators did not even trust each other.

Today I want to examine a small part of the history of the deals and deceptions of the Hawke-Keating Government. I mention both principal players because they jointly bear responsibility for the disastrous consequences of their Government's actions. There is a tendency in the press gallery to give hero status to the honourable member for Blaxland. I say to the House that those values are false values. They are the kinds of values that would honour Ned Kelly above the people he robbed and the policemen he killed. These two men have wrought destruction not only on the honour of their positions and on the Party they have led, but also on the daily lives of hundreds of thousands of innocent Australians. Theirs is a history of deals, deception and destruction-deals with mates, deals with unions, deals with vested interests, deals with each other, deals to secure benefits for particular sections of the community at the expense of the ordinary citizen and taxpayer. Most of these deals involved deception, either of the people or the parties to the deal, or both.

I have time to look at only two examples of disastrous and deceitful deals. My colleague the honourable member for Parkes (Mr Cobb) will look at others relating particularly to the environment and rural industries. The first and biggest deal, and the overarching policy direction of the Government, was the accord. The Government went into office on the basis of the accord, but even before that the present Prime Minister went into the leadership of the Australian Labor Party (ALP) on the basis of the accord. It was a deal between the present Prime Minister and his trade union mates. It was a deal withheld by those mates from Mr Hayden as part of the deceitful process that led to the displacement of Mr Hayden by the present Prime Minister.

This deal was rooted in deceit and dishonesty. It would be improper for me to speculate on His Excellency's thoughts on this matter today, so I will not speculate. But under that deal the mates were promised influence. They were promised access to the innermost councils of the Government. Every important decision of the Government would be discussed beforehand with those mates. Crean and Kelty would be de facto Cabinet Ministers-not only ordinary Cabinet Ministers but Cabinet Ministers with a special introduction into the higher levels of the Government. So the mates were promised influence.

The people were promised jobs. They were promised higher wages. They were promised better conditions. Employers were promised profits. Small business was promised good conditions for expansion. The farmers were promised an end to the drought. Australians overall were promised prosperity under the accord. The accord led immediately-and it is worth looking back over the years at this-to one of the biggest spending binges by government in Australia's history. The first two Keating Budgets spent on a Whitlamesque scale, and in that spending of the first two years was laid the whole basis of the expansion of our foreign debt. The jobs that were created were bought with borrowed money; they were promised falsely; they were delivered on a false basis; and we now know that they could not be sustained.

What have the Australian people got out of the accord? It is quite clear now what they have got out of the accord. First of all, they have lost their jobs. All those jobs that were bought on borrowed money are disappearing hour by hour, day by day. The Government has admitted that the number of jobless is going to be higher than in the 1982-83 recession. We now know that the situation is going to be the worst since the Great Depression of the 1930s.

The Australian workers have lost out on real wage increases. This Labor Prime Minister and the honourable member for Blaxland, as Treasurer, day after day have boasted in this House that the great Australian Labor Party has reduced the real wages of workers and increased the profit share. Day after day after day, they have boasted that the Labor Party is proud of the fact that it has reduced workers' real wages and reduced their living conditions; and they have said that the profit share has gone up and that is good because it will lead to investments and jobs.

What has happened? Of course, people have not kept those jobs. They have lost the wages. If we look at the last quarter's profit figures, we find that profits decreased by 29 per cent. So they have not even kept the promise as to increasing profits and at the same time they have screwed down the workers by maintaining a nonsensical wage fixation system that pays the least able and the least ready worker the same as the best worker, the person who really wants to work.

Of course, during this time small business has been decimated. Bankruptcies since last year are up 54 per cent. Farmers are being driven off the land; at least 25 to 30 per cent of farmers are terrified as to whether they will be able to maintain their properties. We have had the worst situation on the land that anybody can remember. Of course, as I said, business profits, which are supposed to be the basis of this investment for new jobs, have now collapsed.

The Prime Minister and the honourable member for Blaxland have day by day boasted of pushing up business profits at the expense of wages, an inevitable outcome of the zero sum game that is their economy, but even big business has been deceived because of the reduction in profits. The great deal of the accord has delivered only to the mates: Crean is in the Cabinet; Kelty may as well be in the Cabinet; I do not know about the new fellow, I do not know whether they have let him into the Cabinet-but Kelty is certainly still there. Kelty is also in Kirribilli House and party to the innermost Cabinet decisions. However, it was and, of course, always would be disastrous for workers without jobs, for small businesses bankrupted, for farmers losing their farms and for families struggling to pay the bills.

All these people were deceived as to the promised benefits of the deal that bestowed the crown on the honourable member for Wills (Mr Hawke) and put the honourable member for Blaxland into a position of high influence. But uneasy lies the head that wears the crown, and that leads us to the most extraordinary deal of all: the Kirribilli House conspiracy. Surely this is the ultimate deal-trading in the prime ministership.

It is fascinating to observe the mores of the ALP at work. Keating is a creature of Sussex Street, of the New South Wales thuggish right wing; ask His Excellency about that. The origin of this deal was in the spoils system of the ALP: `I ought to have my turn. I've been a ward-heeler. I've been a union delegate. I've been an official in the Sussex Street gang. I've been a backbencher, a shadow Minister, and a Minister. And it is my turn. If you don't give me my turn, I'll pull the plug on you'. The Prime Minister, Old Jellyback, was so scared of this threat that he was going to have the plug pulled on him by this person who was beside him--

TALK.START.PARA: —Could I suggest to the honourable member for Mackellar that words like that do not contribute to the debate.

—I withdraw the term and refer to him as the honourable member for Wills. But he simply did not have the guts to stand up to the honourable member for Blaxland and call his bluff. So they agreed to have this deal but, not trusting each other, they had to have outside witnesses, thus giving an extraordinary hostage to fortune. Either of those witnesses could have pulled the plug on them, and we only have to think of the possible consequences for public policy of that threat being held over the heads of the two principal participants, both of whom were party to the deception in the forthcoming election. So they solemnly decided between themselves to deceive the Australian public and they gave a hostage to fortune. These two people agreed to a cold and calculated act of deception-surely the ultimate deal and the ultimate deception, a deception on the Australian political body and on the Australian public.

SPEECH.PARA: The whole political system in Australia depends very much on people's personal sets of values-the kind of restraint that they automatically impose upon themselves. No written rules can dictate what people are going to do all the time. They have to have an innate sense of value. They have to have an innate sense of what democracy is all about. If they are in high office, they have a responsibility which goes beyond that of the ordinary citizen. Most things they do are subject to scrutiny. But inevitably in public life, there are all sorts of things they do which are not subject to immediate scrutiny. It is those things and the way people handle those issues and make those decisions which set the whole tone of public life.

We now know, disgracefully, that the two highest people in the land sat down at a meeting in Sydney with two outsiders, just a few years ago, and traded in the future of the prime ministership of Australia. That tells us something about the morality of this Government. It tells us that it is a government of deals and deception. Those deals and that deception have led to the destruction of the lives of hundreds of thousands of Australians. It is time both of these people were swept from public life.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for Mackellar (Mr Carlton) never speaks insincerely; he always believes what he says. What he can never do, however, is see the faults in his own side and himself. He can see the faults in the Opposition or what he believes to be the faults in the Opposition-and that has been a common failing of all those associated with the New South Wales organisation of the Liberal Party and all those brought up in the Liberal Party in New South Wales during the Askin era of politics.

SPEECH.PARA: That is a relevant consideration in this debate because, when we are debating a matter like this, we debate it not only in the abstract, on a theory of how government operates, but also in the sense of ourselves compared to somebody else, because that is what politics is about in this country. There is a government and there is a opposition. When those in the Opposition come to attack the Government, they come from a particular background, just as in the same way, when the Government attacks the Opposition or defends itself, it carries its own baggage with it-and nobody can deny that. That is why in this place, when we get the sort of unctuous nonsense that we have had from the other side of the House on this matter, it is galling to the point that nobody outside this place need take note of it-nor do they take note of it.

I will get to deal with both the honourable gentleman's points eventually. That so-called wages deal, the accord, produced for the work force of this country well over a million jobs, very few of which have been lost in the context of this period of recession. It was a deal from which the ordinary Australian benefited very substantially. If the Opposition wages policy had applied, as it wished it to, during the pilots dispute, we would not be talking around here about 10 per cent or 11 per cent unemployment levels; we would be talking about an absolutely massive unemployment number-an extraordinary difficulty for our people.

Before I get to talking about the accord, which is an honourable part of public policy, I will talk about the deals and the cloak of honesty which, unctuously, the honourable member for Mackellar chose to clothe himself in. Let me read some quotes from the last leadership challenge in the Liberal Party two years ago by the person who was the loser in that case, the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard), on Four Corners. These are his own words:

Those who boasted about their proficiency in telling lies, in practising treachery, have done the Liberal Party an enormous disservice, an enormous disservice. There is a place for some honour in a political party . . . If those people who shared my political confidences felt I was unfit, they should, in honour, have resigned from the Shadow Ministry and, from outside the Shadow Ministry, worked to bring about a change of leadership.
That would have been an honourable thing to do . . .

Peter Shack, for example, made a fetish during the weeks that led up to it of actually coming to me and saying `John, you know I've always been a supporter of Andrew's, but that is now a thing of the past. We're all getting behind you.
Elsewhere, he was asked:
Do you accept Andrew Peacock's denials; his claim that he knew nothing about this until the weekend; that he was simply drafted?
He replied:
I can't believe that in the face of what transpired on Monday night and what I know . . . I cannot believe in all my heart that he was not privy to the detail of that.
He was then asked:
So you believe he has lied?
He replied:

Well, somebody is not telling the truth . . . You can't have gone into that kind of detail and then expect people to believe that suddenly people came along and tapped you on the shoulder and said, `Hey chum, we'd like you to be leader'.
Senator Michael Baume then said:
There is a simple question. One has to decide who is lying-John Moore and Wilson Tuckey or Andrew Peacock.

Most of the participants in that series of incidents just two years ago, the same time span that the next election is away from us-a piece of recent political history in which the bulk of the front bench of the leadership of the Liberal Party was involved-were involved in a tale of lies, deceit, deceptions, deals and all the rest of it. Do not come into this place and try to kid us that that is not the stuff of politics on the other side of the House. By all means, those opposite can kid themselves, but they should not try to kid us. Do not try to debase the operations of democratic politics, which will involve invariably a series of arrangements made around the place in leadership ballots or anything else.

For those opposite to say that no leader of the Liberal Party has ever been elected or has maintained his position without entering into some arrangement at some point of time with some of his colleagues would be like coming into this place and displaying a level of gormlessness which in itself would make them unfit for government. If they are that gormless in relation to their colleagues, then they are not sensible enough to be able to deal with the Public Service in a ministerial position, or sensible enough to deal with their colleagues in Cabinet, or anything else.

The Opposition talks about deals. The deal that we are alleged to have made in regard to the wages accord created in this country over 1 1/2 million jobs. It created a rate of employment growth twice the average of the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development and about four times the average of when those opposite were in office. It will take a heck of a long recession, a length of time that will not occur, before the bulk of the benefits of those jobs, in comparison to what those opposite achieved, will be washed away. The effect that had, of course, was to ensure that there were opportunities for people in this country which were not there when the Opposition was in office.

The problem is that when those opposite talk `deal' in regard to the trade unions they have never understood the situation of the trade unions in relation to the totality of the people in this country. The Liberal Party and the Australian Labor Party collectively, in terms of direct membership, represent something like 2 per cent of the Australian community. If the Opposition numbers and our numbers were totted up, we collectively in the political process represent about 2 per cent of the Australian community. If members of the union movement and the people in the electorate who are married to them, or those people who are in some way associated with them, are totted up we are talking about closer to 20 or 30 per cent of our community.

Bill Kelty does not come into the Government and say, `How about a nice fat cheque for the building that I have just invested in; how about taking capital gains tax off my building so that I can make a substantial sum of money?'. Bill Kelty earns the average Australian Council of Trade Unions level of wages, which I think is about 50 grand a year. It is a heck of a lot less than any of the crew on the other side of the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —Plus the board directorships.

—Plus one or two directorships that probably take him up to the full level of a backbencher's salary and allowances. Big deal! That is what the honourable member is talking about. But who is he acting on behalf of? The people he is acting on behalf of are the ordinary wage and salary earners of this country, their children and their employment opportunities, and that deal is massively delivered. Failure by Thatcher to achieve a wages accord, failure by Thatcher to establish some degree of control over that very important tool of economic management-the wages outcome-has put her Government in a situation now where it faces endless inflationary wage claims and it will have to pay them, like the Opposition did when it was in office.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition was getting out of the trade union movement a level of wage claim which was economically unsustainable for the country, which put us in a position where we lost all productivity and which put us in a position where we lost all competitiveness. There can be no question that the competitiveness of this country has increased dramatically since then.

The other bogus part of the argument, the deeply dishonest part of the argument, of the honourable member for Mackellar-he is not without economic knowledge and, therefore, the depth of the dishonesty of his argument comes from the basis of his knowledge in that regard-goes to the levels of deficit experienced by this Government in its first two years in office. He suggested that part of the wages accord that was reached with the trade union movement in some way related to government expenditures. What a load of nonsense!

This is the first time, in any piece of political analysis or economic analysis anywhere around this country, that I have seen anything which suggests that at any time there was any element of public outlays in those two years associated with the deficits which occurred that were in some way or other associated with the accord. That is just stand-up, palpable and disgraceful nonsense.

We all know, however, where the first of those deficits came from. It sat there-from Mr Stone, the then Secretary of the Treasury-to be presented to the returning Liberal Government, during which time he was told that its outlays had expanded to a point where it could anticipate something like a $10 billion deficit. That was the first of the two deficits.

It is quite true that in ramping back that deficit we had to produce two extraordinarily difficult deficit outcomes. The cost of not producing two extraordinarily difficult deficit outcomes would not have been a cost borne by Mr Kelty, a cost borne by the members of the Liberal Party who were then still in Parliament, or a cost borne by its particular mates in business or whatever. It would have been a cost borne by the average Australian.

Just imagine if we had decided to ramp back that $10 million deficit in the space of 12 months. What a bonzer life that would have been for the average Australian pensioner. The sum of $10 billion can be extracted from a Budget, if one really tries, but it can never be got out of a Budget unless the very heart of the social security aspects are attacked.

When attempting to engage in debate on a serious matter of public policy, there is always a sensible and legitimate economic argument-and I am always prepared to argue with the Liberal Party on the issue of whether or not there ought to be forms of wages controls or accords-which says that the labour market ought to find its own level as every other section of the market. That is an area for sensible, decent and economic debate between any sides in politics. There is no denying that we take one view and the Opposition takes another.

It is a nonsense to criticise that central element of public policy which has been an issue for governments that predated this one, including the coalition Government with its own legislative wage freeze after the consequences of its own unmitigated wage rises. It went from one extreme to the other. When it confronted that situation it was not because of deals but because of a debate on public policy. When the Opposition moves these semi-censure motions or censure motions, it destroys and bowdlerises the decent terminology and discourse of political debate by trying to degrade a serious debate on public policy down to a question of deals. The fatuous position adopted by the honourable member for Mackellar, which made up something like two-thirds of his speech, ought to be dismissed for the complete nonsense that it is.

However, if we want to go round the place arguing about who makes deals and who does not, or who does things for people in this place that elevate their interests and who does not, we can do no better than go to the Opposition's present central position on taxation policy.

The people whom Bill Kelty represents, as a leader of the trade union movement, and whom many others represent, are the ordinary Australians. The trade union movement has always been a collection of its individual parts; it has never been centralised in its directorship. Although responsibility has been handed up the line, it operates through processes at least as democratic as anything that the Liberal Party can throw up. The central element of the unions' charter is not to make money for themselves-and they do not. On the whole, union officials die poor men, and when they die poor men, they have only this to look back on: whether or not they have served the interests of their members, who constitute the vast majority of ordinary working Australians, and secured things for them.

What does the Opposition offer these people against our so-called deal as far as wages policy is concerned? It says to them, `Listen, you can pay a 15 per cent consumption tax on your food, your clothing-everything that goes to producing your children, to bringing them up, to giving them an education, to allowing them to get themselves around the State and around the city, to getting themselves employed and to getting on the telephone. We will put a tax on you'. Who will benefit? None of them will benefit in terms of a direct trade-off with any tax cuts unless it goes well above a 15 per cent value-added tax or goods and services tax, or whatever it is that the Opposition cares to call it. But we do know one group that will benefit: it will be everybody who speculated in property in the 1980s and still maintain their assets.

In most areas of the community these people have come to be loathed over the last few years. And what is the Liberal Party policy for them? They will be able to maintain the profit of their speculation, and the achievement of that will be at the expense of the ordinary citizen, the ordinary person on whose behalf these `deals', as the Opposition puts it, were done. Some deal from the Opposition! I say: some nonsense from the Opposition; some unctuous, self-righteous baloney from the Opposition in this debate! No wonder it has put up wet-lettuce type arguments to defend itself on a Wednesday afternoon.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cobb Mr M.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have just heard an excited speech by the Minister for Transport and Communications (Mr Beazley). I remind him that essentially we are talking about integrity and credibility. If he wants an example of misleading the Australian people, I refer him to a quote of his own from the 7.30 Report on 10 September last year. In answer to a question, he said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . I think there is a great deal of respect for Paul (Keating) and the Party and I have a great deal of respect for him and as I have said before in the distant future when the leadership emerges, I will be voting for him.

I think that highlights that this Government, since March 1983 when it assumed power, has been heavily involved in deals and in deception to the detriment of the Australian people. That is the theme of this matter of public importance today: to the detriment of the Australian people.

The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) has made a personal commitment to elevating special favours and secret deals to an art form, in his desperate attempt to cling on as leader. He has anointed himself, in effect, as the high priest of dealership so that he can continue to fall over the line at election time. He has indulged in such questionable trickery as blatantly buying the voting patronage of minority groups with taxpayers' money. I think a great example of that is the millions of taxpayers' dollars that the Government has given the trade unions since it came to power. These are just the headings. It goes on for page after page in Hansard, running into many millions of dollars.

The Government has indulged in special favours, such as for the Green movement in Australia, in an attempt to buy votes. I will return to that in a moment. It has also indulged in cruel promises to a trusting public-promises that it had no intention of ever honouring. Honourable members will remember the Prime Minister saying, `There will be no capital gains tax'; they will remember well the Prime Minister saying, `By 1990 no child will live in poverty', and that sort of nonsense. Those were promises that the Government had no intention of honouring; that it could not have honoured; that it knew it could not honour; but that it made to deceive the Australian public.

TALK.START.PARA: —Should they trust them any more?
—I do not think so. The list of deals that the Government has done is mind-boggling. I repeat that it is all to the detriment of Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: Today in Question Time the Prime Minister raised the matter of the pilots strike. I guess we will never fully know the deal that was done there. When that pilots strike was on, the Prime Minister had the choice to side with Abeles or with the pilots. He chose to side with Peter Abeles. He may have been right or he may have been wrong, but as an Australian I would like to think that he sided with Abeles for the correct reason. It was well known that Abeles wanted to get rid of his surplus pilots, it is well known that the Prime Minister is a mate of Abeles-he admits it and reinforces it every day in the House-and it is well known that Abeles has granted the Prime Minister several favours. It makes one wonder. When the Prime Minister will go back on what I would have thought was a lifelong principle to stoop to the level of bringing in overseas labour-foreign pilots-to break that strike, it makes one question what sort of a deal was struck. The relationship continues even today.

We have just heard the honourable member for Mackellar (Mr Carlton) talk about the Kirribilli secret deal-a secret which, if it had got out, would have cost the Prime Minister an election. What power the Prime Minister put in Abeles' hands on that occasion! Let me list a few more deals. Look at Coronation Hill. We all remember that famous telephone chat with the Director of the Australian Conservation Foundation (ACF), Phillip Toyne.

Coronation Hill is an area that has been heavily prospected; 12 old mine sites were worked over in the 1950s and 1960s. Coronation Hill itself was worked without Bula being disturbed in any way. As much as 1.2 million ounces of gold has been proven up there. It has platinum and palladium-anti-greenhouse minerals-waiting for the taking. We know that it would earn $500m in export income and $200m in profit for this country. It would employ 630 people, perhaps for 20 years, including Aboriginal people, thereby giving them a great opportunity.

BHP Gold and the other joint venture partners spent $13m on exploration and development plans for the area. In September 1987 Senator Richardson virtually gave them the nod to go ahead. The Prime Minister, in effect, did the same thing one month later. Then Phillip Toyne from the ACF rang the Prime Minister and spoke to him for 90 minutes. As a result of that, the Prime Minister put it on the back burner. When Sir Arvi Parbo, the Chairman of BHP, a great Australian chairing Australia's largest company, which produces millions of dollars of taxpayers money every year in the taxes that it pays, rings the Prime Minister to put his case, his side of the story-surely not an unreasonable request-the Prime Minister refuses to even take the call. He would not even listen to him, because of this deal that he had struck with Phillip Toyne in an attempt to get preferences. It is sickening indeed.

We only have to look at what has happened in uranium mining where we have this ridiculous three-mines policy, now a two-mines policy. A deal was done with the Prime Minister to placate the internal factions of the Labor Party. That is not in the interests of Australia. At this very moment the Prime Minister is trying to ensure that this topic is not even debated at the Labor conference this month. If that comes to pass, it will mean that it will not even be debated, let alone changed, until the next conference, which is due in 1993. As there is an election due in that year, it will not come in until 1994. That will be too late for the mines presently waiting for approval, including Jabiluka, Kintyre, Koongara, Yeelirie, et cetera. The contracts for that uranium will probably be written for the Canadians. I think that almost borders on treason.

For a few grubby votes the Prime Minister has sold out Australia again to stitch up some sort of deal to try to placate the factions in the Labor Party so that he can have the left wing vote should some leadership challenge emerge, which it has this week. We all saw how much he depended on the left wing votes. That is what is going on in Australia today. That is what the Australian people should know about.

We have had the issue of the third runway at Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport. The Prime Minister is paralysed to show any leadership at all. He cannot make a decision, except to make no decision. The interests of Australia again are put aside. As far as the Government is concerned, that is a secondary consideration. It says, `Forget about Australia; let's think of a couple of marginal seats or some people who might vote for me that I might offend'. It is incredible.

Honourable members will remember what happened with regard to Wesley Vale. The Prime Minister and Senator Button gave the go-ahead in October 1988. As a result, North Broken Hill and Noranda spent $20m on development there. Then the greens got into the Prime Minister again, Richardson stitched up a deal to ensure the preference votes went to the Labor Party at the next election in the distant cities of Sydney and Melbourne, Wesley Vale was put on the back burner; it was ditched in May 1989 and the biggest commercial manufacturing investment in Australia's history was put aside. Four hundred jobs in the mill and 1,200 jobs outside the mill were put aside so that the Prime Minister could stitch up yet another deal for a few grubby votes. Forget about Australia-that is the Prime Minister's motto.

TALK.START.PARA: —Will it work next time?

—It is working every time, but I think the public has finally seen through it. In Ravenshoe the Government locked up the rainforest that had been logged for over 100 years. That was its decision. It again made a deal with the greens. It could not even keep the deal it had made with our side to compensate for a mill in Ravenshoe. It not only sent a cheque for just under $1m to the wrong mill but it sent it to the wrong town. It was even sent to the wrong State. That is how incompetent and indifferent the Government is to the real workers, the wealth creators, of this country. It is obsessed with deals and stitching up votes and grubby little things such as that. It forgets about the interests of Australia, wealth creation, the workers and that type of thing. It is absolute insanity.

SPEECH.PARA: My time has almost run out. We remember how the Government ditched the goods and services tax. It favoured that at one stage but there was another deal done in a motel here with Kelty. The Treasurer at the time was never told about it. The Government stands condemned for the deals that it has struck since it has been in power.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Holding The Hon A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —When the honourable member for Mackellar (Mr Carlton) brought on this matter of public importance I thought that at least we would get issues of policy and issues that go to the heart of this nation in terms of what is important to the Australian people.
—Dirty deals are important.
—Order! The member for Gippsland!

—He slinked to the table and we got an exercise in moral unctuousness. All of a sudden the honourable gentlemen opposite were the men of principle, the men of honour, the men who would never make a deal. They have been living on a high. Last week the honourable member for Blaxland (Mr Keating), the then Deputy Prime Minister, went to the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) very openly and honestly.
—Openly!
—Order! I warn the member for Gippsland.
—He said, `I propose to challenge for your position'. That is a legitimate position in any political party in Australia. I contrast that with the events of 9 May 1989 when the then--
—Here we go.

—This is exactly where we go. Is the honourable member for Kooyong going to sit here and lecture? I can see that he is feeling distinctly ill at ease, and so he should be. At 9.30 on Sunday evening on 7 May 1989 he, as Deputy Leader of the Opposition-he vowed loyalty to the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard)-along with the honourable member for Pearce (Mr Chaney), went to the office of their leader. After all, Leaders of the Opposition are alternative Prime Ministers; they are officers of this Parliament. At that stage they talked about the mayhem in Melbourne, the fact that one of the last of the small `l' liberals had been knocked over in his preselection. That was a matter of concern.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for Kooyong and Senator Chaney, as he then was, did not bother to tell their leader on that occasion that they were already hatching up a plot to destroy him. They did not say, `Look, we propose to challenge you', because they had to take him as close to the wire as possible. It was not until 8.30 p.m. on 8 May, the very next night, that these men of principle, these men of honour, went to their leader and said, `We're going to spill you tomorrow morning'. I ask the honourable member for Kooyong not to leave the chamber. It is all on the record and I would like him to stay and hear it.

TALK.START.PARA: —He has just ruined your speech.
—Not at all. What did the honourable member for Bennelong say when he was asked about this? On 14 May on the 60 Minutes program when asked whether he knew about the plot, he said:

SPEECH.PARA: Yes, I was, I make no bones about that. I knew nothing of it until my three senior colleagues called to see me and said they were going to spill me out the next day.

If there was to be any resistance from the honourable member for Bennelong to that proposition, his Deputy Leader and his Leader in the Senate were carrying a signed petition of 25 Liberal members of parliament. They were certain that they had 40 votes out of 71. Not one of those 40 members had the gall or the guts to go to their leader and say, `Look, you're being plotted against'.

TALK.START.PARA: —Dishonest.

—It was nothing like that. They had a signed petition so that if the honourable member for Bennelong resisted they could use the rules of their own Party to put him to the wall. Let us follow the interview:

SPEECH.PARA: PAUL LYNEHAM: What about Fred Chaney, what was your feeling when you saw him there?
JOHN HOWARD: I think we might terminate the conversation.
JEFF McMULLAN: Was it Fred Chaney's ambition that led to this onslaught?

JOHN HOWARD: I think he failed the basic test of honour and that is of warning, and I don't object to people changing their mind about you as a leader, but when they are in a special position of trust, they have an obligation of candour and warning.

I ask the honourable member for Mackellar: was his name one of the 25? Was he one of the 40? Had he been approached or did he know nothing about it? Where are all these men of honour who now come into this House, having stabbed their own leader in the back and who now want to lecture us about principles and honour?

After the last election none of these people could stand recycling as leader, so what did the smart advertising men of the Liberal Party do? The advertising agency said, `Look, you've got to get somebody who doesn't look like a politician and who doesn't think like a politician'. For the first time in the history of Australia we have a Leader of the Opposition who wanders around Australia saying, `I'm not really a politician; I'm just the Leader of the Opposition'. That is a very useful exercise for the honourable gentleman because he promises the people of Australia a consumption tax and when he is asked questions about it, he says, `Goodness me, don't you mind about that; I'm not really a politician'. When he is asked about his promises of vouchers for education and health and the dismantling of Medibank, a cut of $3 billion, he says, `Don't ask me about that; I'm not really a politician'.

These are the people who come in here and talk about honour. The Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Reith), a new boy, was a solicitor who acted for the Liberal Party establishment in a range of land deals in the Frankston Mornington Peninsula in which their supporters were involved. He would be the first lawyer in the history of Parliament to come into this place not on the basis of what he knows but on the basis of what he had promised to forget.

Then we have the Leader of the National Party of Australia (Mr Tim Fischer), a man of honour and principle. He has never heard of the Bjelke-Petersen trust fund. I say to the honourable gentleman that he has a great distinction in Australian history: he is the first Leader of the National Party in Australia who has more ex-Ministers of his Party in gaol than he has sitting in a Cabinet-and he does not even have the decency to send them a bunch of flowers and suggest that they form the Boggo Road branch of the National Party. He should not come in here lecturing us about ethics and morality.

They are the same old sordid bunch. The reason he was picked as Leader is that nobody would have believed it if they had said of the right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair) that he did not know about it. At least he would have had the courage and capacity to stand up. But the Leader of the National Party comes in here and says, `Oh no, the Bjelke-Petersen trust fund would never have been used for Federal purposes'.

He would have to be the only person in Australia who believes that it is possible to wander in to see the Premier of Queensland, not have to sign a book, be checked out by security, and leave $600,000 without anybody knowing who left it. Dear me! What sort of party do we have? Do honourable members opposite believe that those funds were never called for or applied for in a Federal election? I say to the Leader of the National Party: where is the speech that he has made in this House condemning the tactics and the deals made day after day by his political cohorts in Queensland and recently in New South Wales? He knows nothing about honour and morality.

Let us have done with the whinnying and the whining. It is time the Opposition started to address the real issues that confront this nation. The Opposition has failed. It has a trendy gentleman who runs into Parliament every morning, trying to look good and saying, `I am an athlete; I am an ex-economist; but I am not a politician. Don't ask me any of those difficult political questions. I will put up the honourable member for Mackellar to talk with sincerity and principle about honour and candour'.

When honourable members opposite have the guts to admit that the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard), one of the distinguished parliamentarians of this House, was treated with grave dishonour and was the subject of a sordid political ambush, with the people involved now sitting on the front bench, they can come to us and talk about honour and principle. Perhaps then we will listen. Until they do that, I advise them to get on and deal with the real issues in the economy, the real problems that face the Australian people.

It is time the Leader of the Opposition was prepared to stand up here and spell out the details of his policy, instead of slinking away, going to any little meeting he can go to, and saying, `Don't ask me the hard questions. I can tell you what I am going to do: support a free market economy and kick the trade union movement to death. Although it has not worked in America and not worked in England, and it will not work here, don't ask me for details; I'm not a politician'.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired. The debate has concluded.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 30 May, on motion by Mr Griffiths:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lloyd Mr B.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Quarantine Act 1908 provides that the expense of keeping goods in quarantine for the time necessary to be assured that the risk of diseases and pests is minimal is a legal charge against the goods. However, it is not clear, if the payment is not made, whether the goods can be sold to recoup the costs or whether they must be surrendered to their owners. The Bill before us remedies this uncertainty. The Minister for Resources (Mr Griffiths) in his second reading speech gives an example of a recent case where valuable animals had undergone extensive quarantining but had to be released with the owner owing the Commonwealth $1.5m. The Commonwealth is now suing for recovery, with little likelihood of recovering the full amount. Another example quoted involved a program where a large number of animals were held in quarantine for many years to address the risk of scrapie. That is coming to an end early next year. While the Commonwealth claims that it has subsidised the seven-year care of these animals, charges will be up to $900,000 and the importers have disputed the outstanding debt.

SPEECH.PARA: This Bill gives the Commonwealth the power to hold the goods until payment, or an arrangement for payment, has been made. If this does not apply, the Bill gives the Commonwealth power to sell the goods and apply the proceeds of sale to the debt owing to the Commonwealth. `Goods' is rather a loose term because we are really talking about genetic material of animals, plants or embryos coming into Australia and undergoing the necessary time in a quarantine station to ensure that no diseases enter the country with a particular animal or plant.

To protect the rights of the owners under the new arrangement, the Commonwealth must serve notice advising that if at the end of 30 days any expenses relating to quarantine are still outstanding the goods may be sold. The Opposition supports this legislation. However, I am concerned that the balance between the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service (AQIS) and the client may now move too much to the Government and away from the client. For example, I am advised that, in the scrapie issue, the client believes that the $900,000 charges are not fair or reasonable. There is no appeal mechanism to determine this dispute.
I put a serious question to the new Minister for Science and Technology (Mr Free). I congratulate him on his appointment, and I hope he can start off well by giving me an answer to this question.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not immediately.

—Not necessarily immediately, but I do not want him to quarantine it for too long. There is a need for some mechanism for a client facing the loss of goods or material to have an arbitration ability, to challenge whether or not it is a fair or reasonable cost, short of an actual legal challenge. I believe that is a reasonable question which I hope will be passed on to the appropriate Minister.

SPEECH.PARA: This raises the related issue of AQIS and its role generally. I am not talking about export inspection services today, but I do want to commend AQIS for the increased capacity that has now been made available in Australia for people to import the new genetic material-mainly animal-that this country needs if its livestock industries are to maximise their potential. One thinks of a whole range of animals. For example, sheep from the continent of Europe, where scrapie is a problem, have high fertility and are very good meat producing animals. The genetic material, the embryos, et cetera, for the development of the best angora goats in the world comes from South Africa and neighbouring countries. There are certain types of sheep that can withstand more tropical climates. We have some cattle from Kenya and Zimbabwe at the present time in that category. They can withstand the tropical climate better than other breeds we may have currently. There is tremendous scope to increase our plant and livestock production in this country with a quarantine system that has the capacity to handle it, and I commend AQIS for what has been happening in recent years in that regard and for its technical ability to cover against disease.

In this quarantine area, AQIS has a very important dual role. First, there is the role I have been referring to-that is, quarantine on imports. There are two types of imports: there are particular animals or plants for breeding purposes-which I have been referring to-and there are the goods, mainly horticultural goods such as fruit, which come here in bulk as consumer items, which AQIS must make sure are free of disease. I have been critical of AQIS in the past with regard to this. I believe AQIS has a very critical role in ensuring that the relatively disease-free status of our animal and plant industries in Australia is not put at risk by less than adequate quarantine procedures.

There is another role, and that relates to the export of plants and animals from Australia. Importing countries may require certain standards, for example, with meat or horticulture. In relation to exports, I believe that AQIS is moving in the right direction, to more self-regulation-apart from where a certain country may require government confirmation of particular standards-but I would dispute that it is moving at an adequate speed.

However, there is a final area-that is, gaining access to our exports by the consumers of other countries where there is a quarantine problem at the importing end. If one wants to talk about politics or trade restrictions and quarantine, Australia is a very fair country-sometimes I think it is too fair-when we compare it with other countries and the way they play the game. I believe that we need to maintain political pressure on those countries. I know that is not the role of AQIS, but there is a technical role for an AQIS; sometimes the country needs to be convinced that we have got all of the technological answers that are necessary or we need technical information to assist our exporters to gain access to those markets.

I believe in this final area there is a very important role for AQIS-one in which presumably at the present time AQIS is not being encouraged or given adequate facilities to provide the maximum support that could be given. I recommend an expanded role for AQIS in the future, particularly in relation to our potential horticultural exports and access to certain countries in Asia. I think in particular of Japan, but it certainly is not the only relevant country. As I said earlier, the coalition supports the legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Courtice Mr B.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The objective of the Quarantine Amendment Bill is to strengthen the ability of the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service (AQIS) to recover debts from commercial importers. The amendments will apply to all imported goods, animals and plants, but I must stress that importers of family pets and one-off imports are not usually a problem in relation to payment for quarantine services.

SPEECH.PARA: Under the provisions of the existing Quarantine Act 1908, once the period of quarantine has expired the animals must be released to the importer or owner. This resulted in a loss of some $1.5m in revenue from the use of the Cocos (Keeling) Islands by the Boran-Tuli syndicate, which had 80 head of cattle released before paying its outstanding debt. The amendment is designed to prevent such losses in the future and, of course, to give AQIS a stronger bargaining position.

In recent years, there has been a trend towards larger scale importation of animals to bolster the gene pool of or introduce new species to Australian agriculture. For instance, the Spotswood quarantine station in Victoria has some 150 head of cattle at any one time; the Cocos (Keeling) Islands station has been used for large herds of alpacas; birds are imported in commercial consignments of flocks of up to some 400 at a time; and deer herds of 20 to 40 animals are imported. This has led to AQIS entering into arrangements with the private sector to run its own quarantine stations under AQIS supervision and subject to quarantine law at Terraweena in South Australia, Wongan Hills in Western Australia, Glendook in Victoria and Kirra in South Australia.

Unfortunately, this has also led to the accumulation of higher debts. For example, the accumulated debt for animals held at the Torrens Island quarantine station between 1986 and 1991 is about $750,000. On top of this, the charges levied do not recover the true cost of the services, so in effect the importer using Torrens Island has received a subsidy of about $1.1m over the quarantine period. That is certainly not good enough. This is only one example; similar considerations apply at other quarantine stations.

Animals subject to scrapie freedom assurance programs are kept at Torrens Island and the private quarantine stations. Scrapie is a transmissible sub-viral biological agent, with incubation periods usually ranging from two to five years, and it affects sheep and goats. There is no known test to detect carrier animals and for this reason it is necessary to quarantine imported sheep and goats for a period of years.

One can imagine the accumulation effect of costs. In addition, progeny of imported sheep and goats are quarantined for more than one generation. The animals involved in this program are quarantined at various places throughout Australia and have attracted substantial, highly subsidised charges of up to $900,000 for services provided by the Commonwealth in ensuring that the animals are free from disease and may be released for breeding purposes.

The amendments contained in the Bill, allowing the Commonwealth to retain possession of the animals, will ensure that the Commonwealth's bargaining position over payment of the debt is not weakened. However, the amendments will apply to any goods undergoing quarantine, both now and in the future, not just the animals in the scrapie freedom assurance program.

The honourable member for Murray (Mr Lloyd) made a very valid point when he explained the quarantine standards in other countries. Certainly, there is some suspicion that some countries use quarantine as a form of tariff barrier. Australia is extremely fair and sensible and again, when it comes to trade, Australia leads the way. If we have to continue to raise these matters and shame the rest of the world, we will do so. I concede that the honourable member for Murray and I have had the privilege of working together on that matter. On that basis we often come to agreement that we are sick and tired of seeing the European cowards hiding behind high trade barriers-whether they use quarantine or whether they use subsidies, as at the present time.

The opportunity for export exists for Australian horticulture, in particular. I have a very strong interest in that, having the biggest and best electorate for horticulture in Australia. The potential export of cucurbits and tomatoes to New Zealand, Singapore and Hong Kong opens up a massive opportunity because, unfortunately, we are now flooding our domestic market. We have only 17 million Australians, and the market is very competitive.

Fast food takeaways are often substituted for the traditional type of family meal. This occurs for different reasons, such as social or sporting reasons or the fact that a lot of families have mum and dad working and, consequently, there is a lot of competition as to whether potatoes and tomatoes are put on the plate or whether the family has a pizza or Kentucky fried chicken. Therefore, we have to get into the export market if we are going to improve the viability of our horticultural sector.

In the earlier part of this century, with only one or two animals brought to this country at any one time for breeding purposes, the Quarantine Act of 1908 obviously served its purpose. Now we are looking at whole herds being brought in by importers and therein lies the problem. I believe that the amendments contained in this Bill add a new provision to the Act, enabling the Commonwealth and the owner to enter into an agreement about the payment of quarantine expenses. I certainly welcome these amendments-as does the Opposition, and that is pleasing.

At the current time the outstanding debt as of 30 April 1991 is over $1m. I believe that this Bill, small though it may be, will tighten up and make sure that people who do use our quarantine services actually pay. I commend the Bill to the house.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question is that this Bill be now read a second time. Those of that opinion say aye, to the contrary no. I think the--

INTERJECT.PARA: Mr Tim Fischer-Is he entitled to do that?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wooldridge Dr M.R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker. I rise with pleasure to announce the Opposition's support for the Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation Bill 1991. This is significant because it is the first time in eight years that there has been bipartisan support for a major piece of Aboriginal affairs legislation. This has come about due to six months work and consultation, and it has come about because the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Aboriginal Reconciliation (Mr Tickner) and the Government have been very much prepared to substantially address the concerns of the Opposition on this matter.

SPEECH.PARA: When the Minister first put the Bill to me in the form of a discussion paper six months ago, I did have very serious concerns. I was concerned that such a council might end up like another constitutional commission-doing its own thing and really not aware of the imperative that was put on it by the political process. I was concerned that such a vehicle might be a body for activists, and I was really concerned as to what it might achieve on the ground for Aboriginal people. Those concerns have been addressed through six months of pretty hard work on both sides. I would suggest that this Council will set new ground for Commonwealth advisory bodies in terms of its focus, in terms of its goals and, hopefully, in terms of its outcome.

This Council will operate via a strategic plan. This strategic plan will state its goals and objectives and its strategy for achieving those goals; it will describe its programs, estimate the cost of the programs, set out performance indicators and targets, prepare a plan every three years and report annually to the Federal Parliament. I think this is a model that many other advisory bodies could learn from because it does mean that there will be that accountability, that it will be goal oriented with a definite focus and, hopefully, its performance will be such that there will be a real chance to achieve something worth while.

Moreover, I believe that this body will be particularly accountable in a way in which other bodies have not been accountable in the past. In addition to a strategic plan, it must annually report on its progress towards reconciliation, annually set out its performance against performance indicators as set out in the strategic plan, have its annual report referred to the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Aboriginal Affairs, have its report tabled and debated in both Houses, and operate within the limits of the resources made available for its purposes.

The Opposition is particularly pleased at the focus that the Minister and the Government have agreed on for the Council; that is, that the Council will focus its work mainly on a process of reconciliation at a community level. I note with pleasure and thanks that the Minister has agreed to further recommendations, which will be moved later in the debate, that will strengthen that community focus by making a change in proposed section 6 (1) (a) to say that the Council must have as its focus working community by community. The Opposition insisted on this essentially because it has two concerns: first, the Opposition does not particularly believe in grand plans in this area and, secondly, the Opposition is concerned not to raise the hopes and expectations of Aboriginal people only to have them dashed.

To speak on the first point, it was my strong impression as I moved around rural and remote Australia and talked to Aboriginal people and Aboriginal communities that where things have worked well they have done so because people at a community level have made the effort to get up and get going in solving their own problems. In many ways, they have worked in spite of government, not because of it.

The Opposition's second concern about not wanting to raise the hopes and expectations of Aboriginal people only to have them dashed comes from the clear message I got from Aboriginal people and organisations when consulting them about this Bill. Quite simply, when I asked Aboriginal organisations for their opinions on this process of reconciliation, I was told, `We will not get our hopes up. We want to see whether you in Canberra can get your act together first. If you can do that, maybe we will put some work into it'. I think that puts a fair responsibility on our shoulders here. That is why I have been prepared to work with the Minister on the basis of cooperation and common interest, and to put behind us some of the animosity we have had in Aboriginal affairs over the past eight years, because I think it is about time we attempted to get our act together here in Canberra.

If anything is to be achieved in the area of Aboriginal affairs, it will be achieved with simple practical solutions, with realistic, measurable and achievable goals, with cooperation rather than confrontation and, quite simply, hard work free from political bickering. For these reasons, the Opposition is happy this will focus at a community level, because it will have some real chance of success there.

In addition, I am pleased that the Council will cooperate and consult with the Commonwealth, State, Territory and local governments. This is really just an extension of what I said before. There has been too much division in Aboriginal affairs and too little consultation and preparedness to work to find some common ground. If it is to succeed, it will have to understand fully and work within the Federal framework we have in this country. That is frustrating and limiting at times, but it is also a political reality. As I moved around the country and talked to State and Territory leaders of the Liberal and National parties and party organisations about this concept and whether they would be prepared to support it, I was heartened to find that in very few cases did I actually get what might be called a `gut reaction'. A logical and reasonable approach was adopted to it, as well as a preparedness to say, `We will move halfway, but we will not move the whole way.' I note the Government is also prepared to move halfway, so we now find ourselves hopefully getting our act together.

I am pleased that the Government has further picked up the Opposition's concerns about the nature of the Council and its secretariat, which will come from the full time Public Service, and that the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) will have some freedom in the person he may choose to be a nominee on the Council. That augurs very well for the future.

The Opposition still has two concerns about the Council and I foreshadow two amendments that I will move at the committee stage. However, I will not move these amendments to be petty. I put on the record that I do not intend them to take away from the fact that the Opposition is prepared to be fully bipartisan on this issue. The first proposed amendment relates to the matter of the remuneration of Council members. This originally appeared in the Government's discussion paper back in December. I was particularly pleased with it because, in essence, the Council was going to comprise a group of prominent Australians giving their time voluntarily to try to achieve something worth while in this important area. In the past, committees of government have been open to the criticism that they exist as an end in themselves rather than to try to achieve something really worth while. I was concerned to see that people should not be out of pocket for serving on such a committee, but should not actually make money out of it. So the proposed amendment will delete clause 19 on remuneration and replace it with a new clause 19, which will read:

. . . a person (other than an ex officio member of the Council) who is a member of the Council or a member of a committee or who is both is to be reimbursed the expenses that the person reasonably incurs in performing duties under this Act.
My second amendment will be to clause 6 (1), to add new clause 6 (1) (k), that the Council should:
monitor and evaluate:
(i) the implementation of benchmarks in relation to Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander well-being, as agreed by Commonwealth, State and Territory Governments; and
(ii) the progress towards achieving those benchmarks.''.

The reason for this amendment is quite simple. There seems to me to be an expectation in Aboriginal affairs that process equates with outcome. To explain further, the House of Representatives Aboriginal Affairs Committee recently looked at the community development and employment program-the single most important program administered by the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission (ATSIC). Although this program has been going for many years, the Committee was able to get virtually no information on outcomes. When the Committee asked ATSIC for that information we received piles of facts and figures. Facts and figures are the process. That is how we do it. The Committee was looking for what is at the end. Is everything we are doing making things better or worse?

I have had discussions with the Minister who assures me that the legislation as written does not preclude the Council examining benchmarks; I thank the Minister for that consideration. The Opposition considers this issue of benchmarks to be the most fundamental issue in Aboriginal affairs. Quite frankly, the impression of many people in this field is that things are going backwards and that in spite of all our best efforts things are actually getting worse. But that is only an impression; we have no objective way of working out where we really are, where we are coming from and where we are going to. For this reason, I propose to move this amendment at the committee stage.

In foreshadowing this second amendment, again in no way do I seek to diminish the fact that there is full cross-party support for this Bill. The Opposition thinks it would be an improvement. We wish to make the statement and are quite prepared to leave it at that.

It is my sincere hope that the Council might provide some leadership, because that is desperately needed in Aboriginal Australia and the broader community today, so the whole community might take a fresh look at itself, its history and its hopes for the future. A council like this, which works in a constructive and positive manner and realises what is achievable in Australian society and then goes for what is achievable in the strongest possible way, might just provide that leadership and might make some difference. It seems to me that in Aboriginal affairs we desperately need a win. We have not had many wins in recent times. Certainly some good things have happened, but in the end we need to convince ourselves that we can make a difference and can do something worth while and that the end results of our efforts will be something positive on the ground for Aboriginal people.

It is my sincere hope that this somewhat hybrid Bill that has been a product of Government and Opposition cooperation-and, dare I say it, bipartisanship-will turn out to give us the win we need in Aboriginal affairs so that we can convince ourselves that all this has been really worth while. That puts very great importance on the people who will make up the Council and on the person who will be its Chair. I hope that when they take up their appointments they are mindful of what we have gone through to try to get our act together so that this may then go on and give us a win.

There are a lot of things for a council such as this to address. We hope that it will be mindful that, if it is going to achieve anything worth while, it has to achieve something on the ground for Aboriginal people. There is a lot of cynicism about this in Aboriginal Australia, not just in white Australia, and the cynicism in Aboriginal Australia is, `Is there going to be anything in it for me? How is it going to affect my life?'. Again it is my hope that the Council is mindful of that and realises that, in the end, what is important in Aboriginal affairs is making some difference on the ground.

In the end we will not address every problem through this Council, and the Council is certainly not an end in itself. It is not going to deter me from what I believe to be the main issue in Aboriginal affairs, which is providing effective service delivery on the ground to Aboriginal people. Ultimately the success, or failure, of what we achieve in Aboriginal affairs is going to be nothing if the appalling state of health, housing, the lack of access to education and other issues relating to Aboriginal well-being are not addressed. Finally, this Council is going to last for 10 years. No-one can predict what will happen in that time.

One of the most moving speeches that I heard in my time as shadow Minister for Aboriginal affairs was at a dinner that the Minister arranged and kindly invited me to attend when Bishop Malcolm-an Anglican bishop in northern Australia, an Aboriginal man-got up at the end of the dinner and gave a very moving speech about his hopes and aspirations for the future. They were quite simple. They were not hopes and aspirations that looked to the past at all; they were hopes and aspirations for the future. He said, `All that Aboriginal people want is for someone to say, ``Sorry''.' We cannot undo the past. We have to look to the future. The first essential step in that is just simply saying `Sorry'.

Whether this Council is that vehicle or not, I do not know; whether this Council provides the impetus for the Australian population to look to its future with some hope and some unity, I do not know. But it is my sincere hope that it will do just that and, for that reason, on behalf of the Opposition I give our support to the Council and I commend the Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hulls Mr R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation Bill 1991 is well deserving of the support that it has from both sides of this House. Immediately prior to my entry into politics, I had a legal practice in Mount Isa in western Queensland. My firm was retained by the West Queensland Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Corporation for Legal Aid for about five years immediately prior to my election to this House. As the solicitor retained by that legal service, I provided legal advice to Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people in a fairly large area north to Mornington Island, south to Birdsville, east to Julia Creek and west to the Northern Territory border. During that time I appeared for the family of a deceased Aboriginal at a coronial inquest prior to the matter being referred to the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody. In fact, I was the instructing solicitor before that Royal Commission when it appeared at Doomadgee in my electorate.

SPEECH.PARA: My five years with that legal service in Mount Isa certainly does not make me an expert on Aboriginal matters. However, I would say that it has given me some insight into the depth of racism suffered by Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people. It was in Mount Isa in fact that a young Aboriginal man was gaoled and then remained in custody in circumstances that I believe were at least as outrageous as those endured by Lindy Chamberlain. Kelvin Condren was his name, and he was convicted of the murder of a woman in Mount Isa and received a life sentence. At the time evidence was in fact available that a man in gaol in Darwin had actually confessed to that murder.

After years of lobbying by his family, solicitors and friends, Kelvin was finally released from Stuart Creek gaol in Townsville. He had been in gaol for some seven years for a crime that he did not commit. In fact, there was evidence to suggest that he was actually in police custody in the Mount Isa watch-house at the time that the murder was committed. I must say that further aspects of that matter are currently being investigated by the Queensland Criminal Justice Commission.

I raise that issue because, whilst I am not blaming the police, the courts or the media, or in fact any other identifiable group, for this obvious miscarriage of justice, I am blaming racism and misunderstanding-unspoken, unacknowledged racism, acting behind the scenes, I believe, to entrap someone like Kelvin Condren, in much the same way as I believe Lindy Chamberlain was the victim of underlying sexist attitudes. I believe that this Bill is an attempt to confront the sort of under the surface racism that enabled the tragedy that happened to Kelvin Condren to occur.

The Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody highlighted the factors which combined to explain the level of disadvantage, both economic and social, suffered by many Aboriginal people in Australia today, which honourable members would know has resulted in the over-representation of Aboriginal people in prisons and in police custody. The report also focused attention on the distrust, enmity and disputation that characterise the relationship between Aboriginal and non-Aboriginal Australians. It is these underlying tensions that I believe must be addressed.

The Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation will start a process of reconciliation which will enable us to start building bridges. In his second reading speech, the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Aboriginal Reconciliation (Mr Tickner) emphasised that the need for a process of reconciliation has been recognised by all political parties. My research seems to show that the last time that there was similar bipartisan support on an Aboriginal issue was way back in 1967 when the Government and the then Labor Opposition actually worked together to secure constitutional change to effectively give Aboriginal people full citizenship. I cannot stress enough the significance of cross-party support for this Bill, and I certainly welcome the bipartisan stand being adopted by both the Government and the Opposition parties in this matter.

It is fair to say that there is an urgent need to educate non-Aboriginal Australians about the cultures of Aborigines and Torres Strait Islanders. In particular, the tragic history of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people must be told with the objective not of creating guilt but of fostering a compassion and empathy for Australia's indigenous people. As a solicitor retained by that Aboriginal legal service, I heard of individual life stories of many of my clients. I heard of grandparents who had died of measles and aunties and uncles who, as five-year-olds, actually hid in caves to avoid being taken away from their families to a reserve.

I heard of Aboriginal stock workers being herded with nooses around their necks by white stockmen on horses, and of Aboriginal women who did not know who their fathers were because their mothers had been raped by white people. Just about every client had a family history involving early death or great suffering.

The Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody recognised that it is this history of suffering, much of it extremely recent, that is the primary cause of the current disadvantaged position of Australia's indigenous people. It will be a central role of the Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation being established by this Bill to bring this history out into the open. The stories must be told and non-Aboriginal Australians must listen.

The national Aboriginal health strategy report highlighted the fact that Aboriginal people are still paying the cost of white contact with their lives. The report included the following tragic statistics: in all age groups and in all States and Territories, Aboriginal people suffer significantly higher mortality rates than the rest of the Australian population; for almost every cause of death, the death rates for Aboriginal people are between two and eight times greater than for non-Aboriginal people; Aboriginal children suffer much higher rates of rheumatic heart disease, diabetes, lung cancer, ear infection, eye disease, asthma, and kidney disease than non-Aboriginal Australians.

Sadly, it is children who have suffered most. In Doomadgee, a town in the far north-western corner of my electorate, one child has already died this year and many others have visited Mount Isa Base Hospital suffering from meningitis. As I said, non-Aboriginal Australia cannot ignore these sorts of tragedies any longer. Therefore, I believe that education will play a key role to help raise the level of awareness of Aboriginal history, cultures, dispossession and continuing disadvantage. Maureen Watson, a secondary teacher, wrote an article entitled Black Reflections in March 1982. She stated:

Racism is accepted as one of the norms of Australian society. Aboriginal students are alienated, misunderstood and neglected since teachers know nothing of the needs of Aborigines trying to fit into an alien system.
Aboriginal studies must be made a top priority in schools if future generations are to avoid being as ignorant and racist as their predecessors.

The report of the working party on a national Aboriginal health strategy makes the critical point that no matter how sound a strategy, or how broadly it is supported within the community, it will fail if there is a lack of political will and commitment on the part of governments.

I do not think that the cross-party political support can be emphasised enough; in fact, I believe that the value of such cross-party support for the process of reconciliation has been highlighted recently by the irrational and, some may say, racist response of some Queensland members of parliament to the mere mention of land rights by the Queensland Government. To suggest, as some Queensland State Opposition members of parliament have, that there will be a land grab for the Gold Coast or that Mount Isa Mines Ltd will have to cease operations if land rights were introduced I believe is a blatant misuse of the political process and, indeed, it was blatantly untrue.

All Australians-Aboriginal and non-Aboriginal-suffer as a result of the level of political debate that we saw in Queensland, where unfortunately there is not cross-party political support on Aboriginal issues. As Michael Howard, in his article entitled Australian Aboriginal Politics and the Perpetuation of Inequality, said:

The Aboriginal problem seen in a sociological perspective is the alienation of Aborigines from access to and utilisation of land, minerals, capital and human resources. The white majority in power has been able to define the Aboriginal problem differently. In their view Aborigines are deviants and should be assimilated and integrated into white society.

For far too long that has been the view of many in society.
