As the shadow Minister for Aboriginal affairs (Dr Wooldridge) has just said in his speech, the legislation before the House will free Aboriginal affairs from the bickering of politics, which I am sure is welcomed by everyone in this House. In his second reading speech, the Minister stated that the legislation will set up a council that will have as its objects, inter alia, the promotion by leadership, education and discussion a deeper understanding by all Australians of the history, cultures, past dispossession and continuing disadvantage of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders and of the need to redress that disadvantage.

I fully support the Bill. I congratulate the Opposition on the forward thinking approach it has adopted in relation to this legislation. I believe it should have the full support of everybody in this House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am delighted to be speaking on the Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation Bill and to be again expressing the support of the Opposition for its basic thrust. I believe that the need for a better relationship between Aboriginal and non-Aboriginal Australians and the importance of that better relationship to achieving improvement in the area of Aboriginal disadvantage would command near universal support; it certainly commands the support of the Opposition.

SPEECH.PARA: I was struck, however, during the speech of the honourable member for Kennedy (Mr Hulls) by his reference to his work with the Aboriginal Legal Service because that means that the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Tickner), who first spoke on this Bill, the honourable member for Kennedy, who was the third speaker on the Bill, and I represent what one would call a narrow strand of Australian opinion because I have also had a long association with the Aboriginal Legal Service.

I think it would be useful in this debate to bear in mind that for many people in Australia that would be regarded as a disqualification from having a sound opinion. It may not be from those of us who have spent many years thinking and working in this area of policy. I mention that because it is very important that this debate is realistic and that we acknowledge the reasons why we need a process of reconciliation. We need it because there are real and genuine difficulties out there in the community and there are some powerful attitudes, some of which are strongly supportive of Aboriginal Australians but others which clearly are not. There is a great deal of unhappiness and uncertainty and, at times, I think resentment.

If this Bill is about anything, it is about our lack of success in weeding those things out of Australia in the past and the need to do something different. I hope it will be accepted in this debate that it is important to acknowledge the difficulties, because if there were no difficulties this legislation would not be needed.

It is also very important to acknowledge progress. When we stop to think about it, I think we can find progress with respect to infant mortality-something that is pretty fundamental. We can find progress in the fact that there are now hundreds-more than a thousand, I think-of Aboriginal graduates, whereas just a few years ago there were none. We can find progress in the fact that many Aboriginal people now live in houses, whereas once they lived in car bodies, but we know there are still plenty of the latter.

It is important to know that the very considerable political effort, the administrative effort and, on the part of the Australian taxpayer, the financial effort have brought some rewards, but many people believe they have brought nothing but difficulty. That is not a right wing or tory view. I will never forget my last conversation with the late Dr Charles Rowley. Those of us who have worked in this field will acknowledge that he is a great Australian contributor. His research into the Aboriginal condition in New South Wales in the 1960s is set out in detail in books such as Outcasts in White Australia, and was part of the educational material that I used as a younger man and as a lawyer to try to understand why there were so many dreadful situations affecting Aboriginal Australians.

Dr Rowley was appointed by the Whitlam Government to head up the Aboriginal Land Fund Commission. He remained in that position under the Fraser Government and was a trusted friend and adviser to me, as he was to the previous Government and I am sure to many members of the Australian Labor Party. In my last disturbing conversation with him here in Canberra-and I am talking now of the early 1980s; I am not scoring some political point about the present Government-the point he made to me was that he was redoing his research and he had found that many things were worse. Sadly, he died soon after, and I chased up the research he was doing. I do not have it with me still, but I remember, for example, that with respect to Aboriginal unemployment there was a significant worsening of the situation in the period from the early 1960s to the early 1980s, a period of unprecedented effort, with the unlocking of very considerable financial and human resources.

It is that reality that is part of the overall resentment one finds in the community and, at times, even in the political parties we represent-I believe on both sides of the chamber. This is a delicate task we undertake because where there has been lack of progress it is disturbing. If we want further evidence of that, we can read the speeches of successive Ministers for Aboriginal Affairs. I take a close interest in this portfolio and I have watched all the Ministers who have held it since I had that privilege in the late 1970s. There is a disturbing similarity about all the speeches. If we look at what was said by Minister Viner, the first Minister in the Fraser Government, we find a catalogue of Aboriginal disadvantage. I found it necessary to be very repetitive of that catalogue. The early speeches of the present Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, who is at the table, could have been made 15 years ago.

I think that is a very sobering reminder of the fact that we come in here in good faith and often, in fact, on a bipartisan basis-the recent conflict over the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission (ATSIC) obscures that. There was bipartisan support for the extraordinary change represented by the Northern Territory land rights legislation, and broadly bipartisan support, as I recall it, for the Aboriginal Development Commission established during my term. There have been plenty of opportunities for bipartisanship which have been availed of. But the fact is that we have not made as much progress as we would like. I think this Bill is about tackling one of the fundamental reasons why.

I am sorry to generalise because, of course, Aboriginal people are as individual as the rest of us, but when we visit a town or settlement or suburb or city and find a good situation, it seems to me that there are usually two factors. The first is leadership, and there are occasionally exceptional people who produce exceptional outcomes. It is very dangerous to mention names; I dropped one name off the list after talking to someone this afternoon because he told me it probably was not very wise to mention it. When I visited Yandeyarra in Western Australia, for example, I thought that the calm and strong leadership of Peter Coffin was a marvellous influence. In the old days at Hooker Creek, before it became Lajamanu, Morris Luther obviously had a strong and benign personal influence which avoided some of the problems that one found at Yuendumu or other places where there was tension and a great deal of unhappiness.

The other factor that I think has been a strong influence in the places where I have found satisfaction about the position and status of Aboriginal Australians has been a genuine community involvement. Again, I was struck by the fact that the honourable member for Kennedy spoke because when I was Minister so long ago the place I most enjoyed visiting was in his electorate, Cloncurry. I thought I could sum up what was right about Cloncurry by simply telling the story of returning there as Minister for Social Security to open a small aged persons unit built by a community organisation fostered by the Anglican Church. There were four little units in one block, occupied by four elderly women, two Aboriginal and two non-Aboriginal. I thought: one would not go into a lot of Australian towns and find that. Yet that was typical of the sense of cooperation and involvement that I found in that town.

Where did that sense of cooperation and involvement come from? It came from splendid Aboriginal people such as Ruby and Viv Tim on the Aboriginal side. On my first visit to that town, I nearly dropped. The shire president was addressing a meeting and Viv Tim interjected and said, `Come on, hurry up, you talk too long'. I thought the floor would open under him. The shire president said `Yeah, you're right, Viv, I do', and brought his speech to a close. I actually have not seen too many Aboriginal interjectors on shire presidents get that sort of response. Then there is the extraordinarily devoted work of people such as the Reverend Ray Ayles and the Reverend Harvey Sutton. Ray Ayles now has the spiritual guidance of the shadow Minister on my left, the honourable member for Mayo (Mr Downer), and I wish him well. The honourable member will, I am sure, require all his reserves of charity and understanding.

There was a tradition in that town of involvement by community leaders which was, I think, entirely benign, and I believe that is what this Bill is trying to construct. Let me say to the honourable member for Kennedy that the late Bob Katter, his predecessor, was a splendid contributor to that. Bob Katter, in bringing me as a Minister into his community, spoke in terms of both affection and respect for his Aboriginal constituency. That is all part of the pattern that I believe is absolutely essential if we are to achieve success where in the past we have too often achieved failure. We have to learn, in our approach to Aboriginal affairs, how to multiply the good examples and how to learn from our mistakes, and goodwill is essential.

This is a point where I wish to utter some cautions. If the Minister and the Government genuinely wish to promote reconciliation at the community level, then I think they need to be aware that a lot of the things that are said in the best possible faith can be utterly destructive. I think there is a great need to avoid theatre and a great need to avoid the totemic. What may give us a wonderful warm glow and what may be very pleasing to Aboriginal activists may in fact promote the enlargement of barriers between Aboriginal and non-Aboriginal Australians.

Take the simplest example contained in this legislation. The preamble contains in its first two paragraphs what to me are simple acknowledgments of historical reality: the reality of the occupation of this country by Aborigines and Torres Strait Islanders, who have been here for thousands of years, and that that was the position prior to British settlement; and the fact that since settlement we have had many people suffering dispossession and dispersal from their traditional lands. That is a statement of fact; but I think it is important to understand that, for many Australians, there is a great resistance and a great depth of resentment about the notion of guilt.

Our own shadow Minister, to whom I pay great respect because of his strenuous and splendid work in this portfolio, referred to an Aboriginal bishop, Bishop Malcolm, saying, `Perhaps people should say ``I'm sorry''.' I want to put up the caution that I think there is a splendid reserve of goodwill in the Australian community for doing something now about present Aboriginal disadvantage, about present injustice, about remedying the wrongs of now, and there is an enormous resistance in the community to the notion of our carrying a burden of guilt and spending too much time in the past.

I can say this from direct personal experience: the other night I walked out of that most interesting United States film, Dances with Wolves, and managed before I reached my car to have a violent row with a neighbour on this very subject. Again I am sorry to throw in what might be a meaningless anecdote, but unless we understand that there is a strong stream in the Australian community and, I believe, in both our political parties as well which sees the guilt notion as being something that is a barrier to solving present problems and a barrier to our living together, then I do not think we will do this job well. I think we need to be very cautious.

I have been very critical of the Government in the past for its approach to national land rights and the treaty, and I have said some of the rudest things I have ever said in politics about the Prime Minister's contribution to the debate on those issues. I think it has been wrong and destructive. In the same vein, if this is to succeed there does need to be the tight focus that is now possible under the legislation, possible under the changes negotiated with the Government by the shadow Minister, the honourable member for Chisholm. It is very important that the Government consider that not as a matter of form, something we do to achieve bipartisanship, but as something that is very much part of the reality.

I want to close by mentioning two other people. I had the benefit of a meal with Charles Perkins a few months ago when he was in Canberra. I wish that every Australian could have heard what he said across the dinner table about the message that he is trying to put out to Aboriginal Australia, because it sounds awful coming from a middle class white Australian. Basically he was saying that the person who can solve the problem is the person who is looking at you while shaving in the morning, or when you put on your lipstick in the morning, or when you wash your face in the morning: it is you. Again in this discussion it is important to acknowledge that Aboriginal Australia, given the tools which are available from government, has its salvation in its own hands.

The other person I want to mention is a Catholic priest whose name I cannot remember, I am sorry, but he was from Bathurst Island. Just a few weeks ago he was quoted in the weekend press as saying that perhaps the contribution that each Australian could make would be to go out and make friends with a couple of Aboriginal people. In a funny sort of way, I think that is right, because basically we are talking here about a sense of community and about providing an environment in which Aboriginal people will feel that, if they work and try, their efforts will be rewarded and that they are part of a community which accepts, respects and, indeed, gives them the love and affection they are entitled to in the community. That again underlines the delicacy of this task, because that cannot be produced by passing a law. It has not been produced by a lot of wise effort and the contribution of many good people.

I close by saying that, if we are to succeed and if there is to be any long term faith on this side of the House in the notion of bipartisanship, the Labor Party should also understand that there is a belief on our side of politics that the Labor Party has been ruthless in its vote gathering among the Aboriginal community. I mention that because I think we should be realistic, and I think that unless we get--

TALK.START.PARA: —Effective rather than ruthless.

—There have been some faults on our side-I certainly concede that-but I think that we actually have to avoid that touch of political ruthlessness which muddies the debate. Again, I offer that because I think it is a genuine barrier to the sort of across the chamber cooperation which is necessary. I commend the Bill, I commend the Minister for his efforts to produce a new approach, and I commend our own shadow Minister for doing so much to ensure that the Government now has an approach which we can support.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Snowdon The Hon W.E.

TALKER.NAME: Mr SNOWDON
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Transport and Communications)

TALK.START.PARA: —It gives me great pleasure indeed to speak in this debate. At the outset I would like to acknowledge the contributions that have already been made by the honourable member for Kennedy (Mr Hulls), the honourable member for Chisholm (Dr Wooldridge) and the honourable member for Pearce (Mr Chaney). I will not say, because it would be dishonest of me, that I agree with everything that the honourable member for Pearce has said. I would certainly take issue, for example, with the last portion of his contribution. But now is not the time to do that; perhaps at some other stage we will get the opportunity to discuss that in some detail.

SPEECH.PARA: I also acknowledge the contribution of lawyers-God forbid-to the portfolio of Aboriginal Affairs. Not only have the honourable member for Pearce, the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Aboriginal Reconciliation (Mr Tickner) and the honourable member for Kennedy all been involved with Aboriginal legal services, but I see also my colleague the honourable member for Denison (Mr Kerr)-yet another ex-employee of an Aboriginal legal service.

I am a person who passionately believes in the need for Australia to come to terms with Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Australians. That demands of us a number of things. It demands of us that we approach this question in a proper bipartisan way. I wish to acknowledge publicly now-as I have not had the ability to do so before because, quite frankly, it has not been forthcoming-the way in which the Opposition has approached this matter in a bipartisan manner. The fact that the Government has been prepared to accept a small number of proposed amendments by the Opposition to this legislation to ensure its passage is, I think, testimony to the goodwill that exists on both sides of the Parliament.

I would caution all of us to remember that in a sense we represent the peak bodies of our respective organisations in this place. The fact of the matter is that not all of the elements of the conservative parties in Australia support the propositions which have been put forward in this legislation. That is nowhere clearer, as the honourable member for Kennedy pointed out, than in Queensland at present, where there is a very public debate about the issue of land rights. That is a subject which I hope we get the opportunity to discuss in some detail sometime later, because it seems to me that there is a necessity for the Australian community to recognise the justice of Aboriginal claims to land.

If this reconciliation process, in part, gets those things on the agenda, then I think that is important. What is more important, in a sense, however, is that we non-Aboriginal and non-Islander Australians come to terms with the reality of Aboriginal and Islander Australia and recognise the injustices of the past, for that will allow us to come to terms with the present and to plan for the future.

That necessarily means that we need, as a group of people, as a nation, to approach this issue without imposing the cultural baggage that could limit our horizons. This should not be a debate which is determined by the lowest common denominator. This is a debate which should be determined by what is just and what is right. What is just and what is right necessarily means recognising, belatedly, at least, the sorrowful past that has beset Aboriginal and Islander Australians since the occupation of this country in 1788.

I wish to just point to the preamble that has been recognised by the honourable member for Pearce already, because it is important that we understand the context. It is important, when we are talking to those people outside of this place who might not yet understand what we are on about, that they themselves understand the reality, the truth, about Australia's past so that they too can come to terms with our present and be able to plan properly for the future.

It is with a great deal of sorrow that I express those remarks, because in a sense the person who epitomised that sort of approach to Australian history left us recently. Manning Clark was a person who fought deeply for this concern for Aboriginal and Islander Australians, and who said to us: `You must come to terms with your past to deal with the present and effectively plan for the future'.

There is one other very prominent non-Aboriginal Australian who has spent his working life-at least the last 30 years-dedicated to trying to get non-Aboriginal Australians to recognise the reality that not only confronts our history but also confronts Aboriginal and Islander Australians every day, and that of course is Nugget Coombs. Nugget, when he was advancing the cause of a treaty, or a makarrata, wrote a book for Aboriginal Australians. I want to quote briefly from a portion of that book. He said:
The occupation of the continent has therefore been one of territorial conquest and the aggression by which it was achieved has never been formally concluded . . .

This occupation has been defended by reference to a legal doctrine accepted by European governments and by the great colonising powers-that where newly discovered lands were `desert and uncultivated' it could be presumed that no organised society or system of government existed among the inhabitants and that a nation could lawfully take possession of them and establish colonies in them.
This doctrine was convenient for colonising powers but, not surprisingly, there is no evidence that its validity was ever acknowledged by other people.
In brief, we occupy this land as the result of territorial conquest justified or excused by a doctrine unilaterally determined and even then inapplicable to the true circumstances.

It is of fundamental importance that non-Aboriginal Australians understand that reality. When we discuss what this Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation is and how it will work, we should understand that acknowledging that reality means that we have to give it some recognition to how we nonAboriginal Australians deal with Aboriginal Australians in that forum.

It is also a reality that we must deal with them, as the honourable member for Chisholm said, on a daily basis in terms of the administration of services. It is true, in part, that governments have spent a lot of money and it is true that we argue accountability, but it is also true that we have not given Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders their dues in the way in which we treat them over these issues, their lives and the way they want to live them.

As I said at the outset, it is important that we understand that not all areas of conservative politics in Australia accept the reality of this debate. It is important, I think, as a message to the general community, that we argue vehemently that what we are talking about in this place in the spirit of bipartisanship should permeate the whole of the Australian community and certainly the whole of the Australian body politic. That will mean including the Northern Territory Government. I hope it gives the same recognition as the honourable member for Chisholm and the Opposition have, in the constructive way in which they have participated in this process, to recognising the reality and the importance of accepting that we all participate in this process of reconciliation in a constructive way and to not inhibiting its processes by, in many senses, dealing with Aboriginal and Islander Australians in a way which is not justified. This means accepting Aboriginal and Islander Australians as equals across the table to be able to discuss, consult and, dare I say it, negotiate.

Recently the Standing Committee on Aboriginal Affairs brought down a report entitled Our Future Our Selves, in which it examined the issue of consultation. I quote two paragraphs on that issue which deal specifically with why we must negotiate with Aboriginal and Islander Australians. This Committee report was endorsed unanimously. It says:

The Committee believes that the complete and extensive involvement of Aboriginal people in decision making must become a requirement, not an option. Instead of Aboriginal involvement being one element of the process of policy development and service delivery, it must pervade the whole process and be crucial to the final outcomes.

4.56 The Committee concluded from the evidence provided to it that the practice of `consultation' does not support the level of Aboriginal involvement required to realise the policies of self-determination and self-management. Aboriginal people need to be actively involved in the settlement of the terms of the policies and programs as they apply to them and at a level which is more accurately described as `negotiation'.

The issue is that Aboriginal and Islander Australians have just demands. They have a right to be treated as equals and they have a right to argue that we deal with them through a process of negotiation. The process of reconciliation is extremely important. I go back to what I said at the beginning of my speech: we must treat them as equals and it must not be a question of the last common denominator in politics-what the worst people in our community will accept as legitimate. We are talking about something which is just and right. That means that we non-Aboriginal Australians need to be not afraid to stand up and say what we think and, if necessary, to try to lead people into accepting that what they are doing may be unjust and not right.

In my view, the Queensland Government has not acted in that way in the course of the land rights discussions. It has not accorded Aboriginal and Islander Australians in Queensland the justified place that they have in the process of consultation about the land rights legislation in Queensland. It is extremely important, if we are to move this debate forward, that Aboriginal and Islander Australians who reside in Queensland are treated properly by the Queensland Government. That means that it must negotiate with them over the issue of land rights in that State.

The time for my contribution to this debate has nearly expired, but I point out that that process of discussion, consultation and negotiation about the issue of this process of reconciliation and about all other matters concerning Aboriginal and Torres Strait Island Australians means that we must all recognise now the reality of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission; and, in recognising the reality of ATSIC, we must give due prominence and recognition to the Commissioners of ATSIC.

I acknowledge with great pleasure that the ATSIC Commissioners are in the gallery this afternoon. It is with even greater pleasure that I see my bearded friend Geoffrey Shaw sitting next to Pat Turner in the gallery. Geoffrey, as some honourable members may or may not know, is an Aboriginal Australian who should not need any introduction to this place. He is an Aboriginal Australian who fought for this country, representing Australia in the armed forces in Malaya and in Vietnam, who came back to this country and could not go into a Returned Services League club. The shame that that should bring upon non-Aboriginal Australians is self-evident. It seems to me that, if by the year 2000 we have not come to terms with this process of reconciliation and out of that process obtained an agreement, an article or treaty through negotiation with Aboriginal Australians, we too will have failed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kerr Mr D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today we have heard a number of moving speeches saying what should be obvious but, unfortunately, too frequently is not. It is a matter of real surprise to many Australians when they learn of the history of their own country on the issue of the contact between non-Aboriginal Australians and Aboriginal Australians. `Contact' is a very neutral word. `Contact' suggests perhaps something that would involve little pain or little consequence, but the history of the dispossession of Aboriginal people in this country through their contact with the European invaders comes to most non-Aboriginal Australians as a complete surprise.

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Tickner), in his second reading speech, said:

Generations of non-Aboriginal Australians have grown up with a very poor education about Aboriginal Australia. As recently as 1967 my own official New South Wales history textbook for year 10 said Aborigines who lived in towns would `recklessly share their possessions with parasitic relatives and friends'.

Similar textbooks have very little history of the contact between Aboriginal and non-Aboriginal Australians. It is only slowly, though the work of scholars such as Manning Clark, who began some of this ground-breaking work-and more recently scholars such as Professor Henry Reynolds and Dr Coombs-that we really begin to see the tragedies that unfolded for those who were the original inhabitants of our country.

Only when one sees the tragedies unfold for those people-how they were driven from their lands; how their resistance was broken; how their fight was broken through military means-and the terrible repressions that were meted out to Aboriginal people in place after place throughout this country, can one begin to understand how far we are from reconciliation and why something that ought to be entirely non-contentious has stirred such emotions.

We regard it as a matter of some pride that we as a Parliament can come together to agree to a council dealing with these issues. It should not be a matter of pride, but it has to be as a result of our starting so far behind in our understanding. In my own State of Tasmania, generations of non-Aboriginal Australians grew up being told and taught that there were no Tasmanian Aboriginal people. They were educated to believe that the last Tasmanian Aboriginal was a woman called Truganini who died in the late 1800s.

Aboriginal Tasmanians do survive and do persist and they are only now gaining their voice. Around Australia now Aboriginal people are only beginning to gain the voice that they are entitled to. Their voice will become stronger and more powerful through institutions such as the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission (ATSIC), which gives back to elected Aboriginal people control over the management of funds which maintain programs that are designed to improve Aboriginal living standards. Most importantly, the ATSIC process is part of a process of giving back to Aboriginal Australians pride and self-determination. Self-determination does not mean much if it is just an abstract set of words, because there is no meat in self-determination; there is no substance in self-determination.

Self-determination has substance when it is coupled with realistic programs designed to make sure that the capacity for real choice is available to Aboriginal Australians. Without the capacity for real choice, without being able to make meaningful decisions, self-determination is really just a couple of words. That is why it is so important that we have to reach out to our fellow non-Aboriginal Australians so that they have to come to terms with what it means to make provision in this country for those whom we have dispossessed and neglected for so long.

We have to get away from the tragic debates that occurred some years ago about land rights in our country when the mining companies put up the most disgraceful propaganda and created an atmosphere of fear so that governments were scared away from programs which would have led to the establishment of national land rights legislation. It is important, therefore, that we start at the beginning by recognising that we are the inheritors, not Aboriginal Australians, of a land grab of a continent where the original inhabitants were dispossessed by force and really not cared about for many years. As Professor Reynolds and others will say, the idea was put about by many in those early days of dispossession that the Aboriginal people would simply die out; they were a doomed race. Policy was not designed around their preservation and protection; it was designed around compassion to see them quietly fade from the scene.

Given that, I am surprised that there is so little anger in the Aboriginal community. We all find some difficulty when we are confronted by anger. From time to time even those of us who are at the forefront of advocacy of Aboriginal rights, as the Minister has been, find themselves in the firing line of anger from Aboriginal people. I, working in the Aboriginal Legal Service and outside it, have also found myself the focus of Aboriginal people's anger. If one has not found oneself the focus of some anger, one has not had much to do with Aboriginal affairs.

It is surprising that there is so little anger. As the Minister has said, there are so many people who look forward to the future with optimism. They recall the past with sadness. They are able to tell us about their own families, of children who may have been taken from them and of elderly relatives who were treated appallingly as servants or less by non-Aboriginal people. Some cannot tell us about their family histories at all because of the tragedies that occurred to break up their connection with their ancestral places and their families.

As I have said, the surprising thing is that there is so little anger. That means that there is a chance to bring together Aboriginal and non-Aboriginal Australians. We cannot do it if we pretend that an act of reconciliation is somehow an extension of generosity of this Parliament. It is not a generous act. It is simply a recognition that for far too long we have turned a blind eye to our own national disgrace and our own national history. That flows from the difficulty in seeing clearly where one's own self-interests are concerned.

One of the things that I am continually taken to task about by some non-Aboriginal Australians is this question of land rights and the argument that in some ways land rights would give to Aboriginal Australians rights different from those of ordinary non-Aboriginal Australians. The argument often advanced by people of goodwill is, `Look, we're all equal now in Australia. There might have been some dreadful things done to Aboriginal people in the past, but they have no greater claim on the community than you or I. We are all taxpayers, and what's all this business about land rights?'.

The bottom line is that, when our ancestors came to this country and displaced and dispersed Aboriginal people, the whole basis of wealth that was then created was by land grants. Land was passed without cost, or at very little cost, to settlers by way of grant. There was no payment for that land in the initial years. Freeholders were encouraged to come to this country from Europe and England to take up large spreads, to settle here and make themselves wealthy. Slowly, as time passed, money was a condition of taking up land grants. Huge tracts of Tasmania, for example, were given without any cost at all to the original settling families.

The wealth of many of our ancestors that stands behind our most prominent citizens and has formed the base of our industrial growth and the sustained economic development of this country, which has benefited non-Aboriginal Australians, has simply excluded Aboriginal people. They have been the victims. Their land formed the basis of capital, given originally to the first settlers for nothing. Having taken advantage of that in accumulated wealth, they applied that wealth to the expansion of the economic base of this country. In that whole process it was not Aboriginal Australians who benefited. Granting land rights really does no more than say that we have some responsibility to those original Australians who thus far have been held out of the kind of inheritance that every other non-Aboriginal Australian has been able to share in. It does no more than give them that opportunity to reclaim some of the land that was once theirs, to establish traditional relationships to it and to do something in real terms about putting flesh on the concept of self-determination.

I do not believe that this Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation is controversial. The proposal is to see whether we can bring together all Australians to think hard about what we need to do in these areas. I hope the fact that the proposal is not controversial does not mean that the process of seeking reconciliation does not involve controversial ideas. One of the things that I feel we have failed to do in this country in any significant debate is to work out how we can give effective political power sharing to Aboriginal Australians.

I worked with Paul Coe in the Aboriginal Legal Service, and I believe he is one of the most significant thinkers about the way in which our relationship with Aboriginal Australians and non-Aboriginal Australians may develop. Part of my work was with respect to a submission on behalf of the National Aboriginal and Islander Legal Service Secretariat to the Constitutional Commission. In that submission, one of the ideas put forward was that Aboriginal Australians be entitled to the equivalent number of senators as those who come from a State, so there would be at least 12 Aboriginal members of parliament elected from around Australia representing that interest group of Aboriginal Australians, in the same way as we permit the representation of the State of Tasmania or New South Wales.

So, imagining the success we have had as a Labor Party in championing Aboriginal affairs, perhaps we would have the likely result of seven or eight Aboriginal senators on our side and, no doubt, the coalition would attract some Aboriginal votes and be so represented in the Senate. That would mean that, within our parliamentary process, we would have people representing a group of Australians who are so frequently forgotten because, in numerical terms, they do not represent a sufficient proportion of any particular seat to be elected. Although Neville Bonner did break the ice by becoming the first Aboriginal to be elected to this Parliament, it has not been repeated, tragically, and we now sit in this Parliament discussing reconciliation with Aboriginal people but there is not one Aboriginal member or senator.

If I went through the lists of those put forward for endorsement at the last Federal election campaign, I do not think I would find more than one or two Aboriginal candidates put forward by either major party, and certainly not for seats which were considered winnable. We need to look at ways in which we can cut new ground and initiatives to empower Aboriginal Australians, and not just talk about issues and refer to the sorts of areas where we might provide better funding, although I take some of the points that the shadow Minister for Aboriginal affairs, the honourable member for Chisholm (Dr Wooldridge), has made about accountability and making sure that we have measurable targets and performance indicators. What he said was very sensible, and I am pleased with those sorts of responsible comments.

I do not want to shy away from the fact that we need to have fairly bold thinking in this area. As the honourable member for the Northern Territory (Mr Snowdon) has quite rightly said, this is not an opportunity for lowest common denominator politics. We should not seek outcomes which represent what the least amenable thinkers in our society have towards Aboriginal interests. We must be willing to reach out to all Australians but, at the same time, provoke debate looking towards best solutions rather than solutions which are just as limited as the worst and most basic prejudices would permit.

I have great hopes but I say this is only the first step. The Minister for Aboriginal Affairs should be congratulated by everyone concerned on having built the coalitions around this proposal that he has, and I am delighted with that success. However, we have much to do before we can say that this process will bear fruit. It will be seen to have not been more than a good first step unless we build on this base with constructive and solid achievement.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Riggall Mr J.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is with some pleasure that I rise in this debate to support the Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation Bill, which seeks to establish the Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation. When I first heard this matter being floated, the actual word `reconciliation' left me with some problems as to what the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Tickner) actually meant by it. So I eventually got around to looking at the Collins Concise Dictionary to see what it had to say about the word-and I apologise to the purists who had another dictionary in mind. In defining the word `reconcile', it states, `to make (oneself or another) no longer opposed; cause to acquiesce in something unpleasant: she reconciled herself to poverty'. I do not think the Minister had anything like that in mind. The next part of the definition states, `to become friendly with (someone) after estrangement or to re-establish friendly relations between (two or more people)'. To some extent, that says part of it. A further portion of the definition states, quite simply, `to settle (a quarrel or difference)'. Perhaps there is a grain of truth in that. The last definition states `to make (two apparently conflicting things) compatible or consistent with each other'. I guess that is the definition that I liked from the Collins Concise Dictionary, which sits very comfortably with me.

SPEECH.PARA: Given that that is the definition that I take it to be-and I am sure the Minister would agree that those words were fairly appropriate-I looked at the Bill and was very pleased to see under the heading `Object' that clause 5 stated:

. . . and the wider Australian community, based on an appreciation by the Australian community as a whole of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander cultures and achievements and of the unique position . . . the indigenous peoples of Australia, and by means that include the fostering of an ongoing national commitment to cooperate to address Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander disadvantage.

It is a very interesting clause because it basically says two things: it accepts very simply the fundamental proposition, if one thinks very seriously about it, that indigenous people, the Aboriginal people, are a disadvantaged people in this nation, and that is something that needs to be resolved. It also says quite simply that there is a piece of culture and history that belongs to all Australians, and it is up to the broader community to take that on board. It is part of our culture and our history, and is something that is being lost rapidly at the moment.

I have the privilege in this place to serve on the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Aboriginal Affairs. Whilst not wishing to state too much about that Committee, one of its charters is to look into language maintenance. One thing I have learned quite briefly in that Committee is that there is a sense of urgency required for the culture of the Aboriginal people. There is no doubt that, in Victoria, Tasmania and parts of New South Wales, because of the loss of language, there is a loss of culture, and that is a tragedy that all Australians face. We are a much poorer people because we have lost this culture. It is something that needs to be addressed very quickly.

As someone from the white Australian population, I must say that there is very little that I can do about it. It is a personal frustration to me that I know very little about it, and I would like to know a lot more. I would like to think that the next generation of Australians will have the opportunity, through schools and general education programs, to learn more about the culture of Australia's indigenous people. The responsibility lies with the Aboriginal people, who are the custodians of that culture, to guard that culture with the dignity and pride that it deserves, and to be able to pass it on to the broader community so we will all feel proud of it. This will be the saviour of the Aboriginal people, with the dignity that it will bring them, and the understanding of the broader Australian community is most important.

There is one thing in the Bill that I would like to bring to the Minister's attention-something that he may look at changing somewhere down the track. He said the Chairman of the Council must be an Aborigine. That is positive discrimination and I can understand the arguments for doing that. But, if we are going to give the recognition and dignity to the Aboriginal people that they deserve, that particular Council ought to elect its own Chairman. I would very much hope that an Aboriginal person would be there in his own right, because he deserved to be in that position, rather than through a ministerial directive. It is only by achieving something in one's own right that one can stand up and be counted as an equal.

I am very pleased that the Minister has given the Council the freedom to hold its meetings in ways other than face to face, sitting around a boardroom or in an office. Council members can use any means of communications-for example telephone or closed circuit television-determined by Council. I think that is a splendid thing to put into a clause. With modern technology, it gives the flexibility for what I hope will be a wide and diverse range of people to be able to communicate around Australia without having to put in an enormous number of flying hours and without impinging on the time constraints that eminent Australians have.

I am very pleased to see that provision, especially when one considers that we will be moving an amendment that basically says that positions on the Council are voluntary positions and that, while the Government will pay out of pocket expenses, one cannot replace time and cannot give time back to the people who donate it. If we can short circuit the process and make it somewhat easier for people to contribute, I am sure that the Council will work much better.

I accept that the working of the Council is not only a responsibility of the Federal Government; I believe the State governments and local governments must all play a part. I believe the most important part will be at the grass roots, where the real problems have to be resolved. It is very difficult for well-meaning people in this place to make decisions and have them carried out at the grass roots level. It is the goodwill of the grass roots participants that will resolve their problems.

I am very pleased to see in the letter from the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) to the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) mention of the success of a grass roots process of reconciliation in the township of Moree. I hope that the Council takes this on board and uses it as a model that may be replanted in other places.

Having mentioned that, I have to say as a Victorian that what may work in Moree and outback Australia may not be effective in my part of the world. In my seat of McMillan, it is apparent that we have a somewhat different problem from that of isolated Aboriginal communities. One of the good things in my electorate is that an Aborigine who is well known to Australia-Lionel Rose-lives there. Lionel Rose is held up as a success story, but he is a success story by the broad Australian standard. I understand that he is also very much a success story in his own community. We judge things such as success on different values, and herein lies one of the great problems that I see in the urban population in Australia. Unfortunately and tragically, we often see bad publicity involving a few Aboriginals who have problems with alcoholism. That is presented as the public face of the Aboriginal community. Some shopkeepers in my electorate complain to me that the bad publicity afforded to such people affect their businesses. A natural anger has then built up between people who have their businesses impacted upon and people who, through alcoholism, are not giving the Aboriginal community a good public relations image.

Yet that is the unfortunate tip of the iceberg. There are also the people whom I call the quiet Australians, the quiet Aboriginal communities, who are part and parcel of the townships. They are people who are working away at jobs, who are responsible people, who have dignity and who have no problems with their neighbours, whether they be white or black. It is great to see those success stories; but, unfortunately, they are not news. They never get the headlines in the newspapers; they are never mentioned at local council meetings. We see only the down side. The more we can see the achievers in the Aboriginal community taking a higher profile and taking the responsibility within communities, the better off we will all be.

One of the other things that we see on television too often is anger over land rights. We have seen it in Queensland, where a group of young Aborigines showed great anger over land rights. Most people who look at that problem say, `Well, they should not be doing that; the police should arrest them. They are damaging a fence and it is a bad sight to see'. I have got to concur that nobody in my position, nobody in this Parliament, could agree with people breaking the law or demanding something through violence. It shows me something that is not necessarily recognised: a sense of pride is starting to creep back into the Aboriginal community-the pride of being an Aborigine. Often the frustration appears in the younger members who want to get on and want dignity and independence, and it is reflected through an unfortunate face of violence.

I think those in the broader Aboriginal community are starting to feel their own responsibilities as a people. When I see the Aboriginal flag being hoisted in the Parliament grounds in Queensland, I look at it and say that that is just the tip of the iceberg. The face behind that is a broader community of people who are proud of being Aboriginal and who want to say, `We will take our place in Australia'. That is something that should not be overlooked. Once again, the quieter achievers within the community ought to be coming forward and saying what they are on about.

I understand also the recent tragic history of the Aboriginal people, which often evokes great emotion in them. Fancy having babies taken away from their families and put into hostels. If that happened in the broader Australian community, we would be absolutely devastated. If we saw it happening overseas, there would be outrage about it. When it happened here-not so many years ago, within living memory-it was done with good intention, but it was thoroughly incorrect. There is a great anger out there in the Aboriginal people because of it. I understand that.

I also have heard evidence of the impact of R-rated and X-rated videos in Aboriginal communities and the cultural differences between their impact in what we call mainstream Australian communities and outback Aboriginal communities. We have had evidence of young children of five or six years of age being experimented on by their older brothers and sisters. For us to allow X-rated videos to be part of our Australian scene in such instances ought to be condemned. Anybody who thinks that we ought to allow X-rated videos in the Australian community should look at what is going on in some of the outback communities. I am sure they would immediately support the banning of those videos.

That evidence was given by a woman at a three-day council in Townsville last year. I have to say I walked out of that session with tears in my eyes and compassion for those young children who are being affected by what one can only say is the impact of mainstream culture on an outback community.

Finally, I would like to end my speech by saying once again that it is tremendous to see the bipartisan approach to this issue. From time to time members of this House disagree with each other on a few points but the main thrust is down the same track, and that is tremendous to see. I wish the Council well in its deliberations, and I hope it can deliver to all Australians those things we hope it can. There is one area where I would differ slightly from the honourable member for the Northern Territory (Mr Snowdon), who stated that Aboriginal people have a right to be treated as equals. I would vary that statement and say that we have an obligation to treat Aboriginal people as equals.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gibson Mr G.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —Some 203 years ago, white man's history tells us, a new country was born. Black man's history, if it were fully told, would tell a different story. For the whole of this time the events and actions of European and Asian settlers in establishing their communities have been recorded by white fellers as a conquest of a harsh and temperamental continent and its insignificant primitive inhabitants. For the murri and koori people of this continent, the arrival of the three ships from England with their cargo of unwanted criminals, vagabonds and homeless, marked the start of an ever widening process of destruction, murder, abuse, break-up of families and communities, dispossession, and devastation of culture and heritage.

SPEECH.PARA: It is only in the last 25 years that any meaningful attempts have been made to correct this pattern and to give murris and kooris some chance and reason to survive. It has really been only in the last decade that any structural changes have occurred in our approach to the preservation of Aboriginal culture and identity. But these have really only touched the surface. I agree with the honourable member for Pearce (Mr Chaney) on one point: the Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation Bill is not about recriminations or guilt or determining responsibility for the actions of the past 203 years. It is about giving the indigenous inhabitants of this land some hope for a future as part of the nation that now occupies this continent.

One of the most persistent features of Aboriginal affairs has been the frequency of reports and studies by government agencies, the media, academics and others about every aspect of Aboriginal life. Perhaps just as remarkable has been the extent to which these reports and studies have been sorrowed over and then all too promptly forgotten. In this respect neither side of politics in this country can take any comfort. Our mutual eagerness to forget the frequent and blindingly obvious reminders of Aboriginal disadvantage that we are presented with is, quite frankly, embarrassing.

In recent months, however, this Parliament has witnessed two stark reminders of the duty this nation owes to the indigenous people of Australia. In one case, that of the national Aboriginal health strategy, the Hawke Government has recognised that action is needed to the tune of committing $232m of additional Federal funds over five years to addressing the health needs of Aboriginal people. In October last year in this House I moved a private member's motion, supported by the honourable member for Kennedy (Mr Hull), calling on governments at all levels to be forthcoming in allocating resources to implement the recommendations of the national Aboriginal health strategy. Only the Federal Government has responded. When will the States fulfil their responsibilities?

What is needed now is a real commitment, not just words, because nice words and no dollars have been a feature of government activity in Aboriginal affairs for too long. What is needed is not a flowery and ideologically sound commitment by State governments to the health strategy. What Aboriginal people quite rightly expect is that, in something of a break with the past, there will be an actual dollar commitment to keeping Aboriginal children alive longer, to keeping Aboriginal communities healthier, to keeping Aboriginal people out of hospital, and to addressing the appalling deficiencies in community infrastructure that give rise to the quite shocking health problems faced by Aboriginal people.

The other major report in this area that this Parliament has been presented with in the past few weeks is the report of the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody. This inquiry has been criticised for its cost and for the fact that it kept a lot of lawyers wealthy. The fact is that, in terms of this country's approach to Aboriginal affairs, this is the report we had to have. The contents of the report are not particularly palatable. The Royal Commission's report provides all of us in this House, however, with a blueprint for action on the wide range of issues affecting Aboriginal people. Let it not become merely the subject of well-meaning press releases, speeches, questions and commentaries by politicians and others in our community. There must be action to follow the words.

One of the functions of the Bill now before the House is to foster an ongoing national commitment to cooperate in addressing Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander disadvantage. It is my belief that the machinery established by this Bill will ensure that the recommendations of the Royal Commission will receive from this House and from the Australian people the profound attention they deserve.

I endorse the remarks of the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Tickner), who urged State governments to play their part in this process. State governments, regardless of their political colour, have a duty to join with the Commonwealth in affording Aboriginal people some measure of the justice they deserve. The most obvious way for State governments to do this is by putting their money where their mouth is-in the way the Federal Government has with the national Aboriginal health strategy. Through this legislation today Australia will have an ongoing facilitator of action to implement the recommendations of these reports, and some of the others that have preceded them, in a non-political and non-divisive manner. For Aboriginal people to have any sort of hope for a future, this is fundamental.

This leads me to another important issue. One of the words much bandied about in the year leading up to the introduction of this Bill is `bipartisanship'. This House has rarely witnessed true bipartisanship. I suppose it is in the nature of an adversarial party political democracy such as ours that bipartisanship is difficult to achieve. One of the issues, however, on which this Parliament has shown a willingness to adopt a genuinely bipartisan approach is the field of human rights. Quite rightly, Australia has an admirable reputation internationally as a champion of human rights. Australian politicians, for all our championing of causes beyond these shores, tend to have something of a blind spot on occasions when it comes to Aboriginal affairs. Aboriginal affairs, so the thinking goes, are not a human rights issue; they are the stuff of domestic politics.

As many on this side of the House have said for some time, Aboriginal issues are too important to be the plaything of politicians in search of a king hit. The king hitters have had a pretty good run in recent years but, quite frankly, their time has passed. Honourable members will recall, some with shame and some with disgust, the innuendo and quite blatant racism that has been directed at Aboriginal people through the Aboriginal Affairs portfolio in recent years. As usual, when politicians deign to play games with Aboriginal affairs, Aboriginal people themselves are the main losers.

What this Bill seeks to achieve is not some smug agreement between the conservative parties and the Government. Rather, it is about achieving some measure of justice for Aboriginal people-justice in the sense of achieving a public view of Aboriginal people that is not consistently negative; justice in the sense that Aboriginal people receive from all governments the degree of support that is so obviously necessary; and justice in the sense that Aboriginal people are no longer fair game for politicians with a few cheap points to score at the expense of a section of Australian society not well placed to defend itself.

I commend the honourable member for Chisholm (Dr Wooldridge) for his efforts to secure some degree of bipartisanship within his own Party. I am aware, from talking with the Minister and from my own experience of honourable members on the other side, that there is in the Opposition a reservoir of goodwill and principle that can be drawn upon whenever the temptation arises for some to score a few cheap and transitory points by kicking black heads.

Bipartisanship does not mean that we in the Government will cop it sweet whenever the Opposition elects to use Aboriginal affairs in an attempt to score points; nor does it mean that we have reached some sweetheart agreement with the Opposition in order to push through our agenda in Aboriginal affairs. Bipartisanship in Aboriginal affairs means active and constructive involvement by both sides in pursuit of the necessary programs for change. More specifically, a bipartisan approach to this Bill means that the Opposition will not be able to vote in favour of this Bill and then simply walk away from its responsibility to Aboriginal people. Opposition support for this Bill involves a commitment to the work of the Council over the coming decade. The structure, membership, functions and powers of the Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation will give everyone in our country an opportunity to contribute in a positive and meaningful way.

It is particularly important that the Council contains members of parliament as appointees, as this will ensure a direct and ongoing relationship between the Council and the Parliament. It will provide an avenue for the constructive participation of all groups in this Parliament in the work of the Council and ensure we are kept in touch with the issues being addressed. I congratulate the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs for his vigour and commitment in pursuing this cause. I commend the Bill to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nugent Mr P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Like a number of members of this House, both past and present, I serve on the Standing Committee for Aboriginal Affairs. In my short time in this place I have had the opportunity to travel reasonably extensively around this country and to see some of the situation of our Aboriginal community.

SPEECH.PARA: Unlike the honourable member for Pearce (Mr Chaney), the honourable member for Denison (Mr Kerr) and others who have worked for many years with Aboriginal communities in one form or another, I am a relative newcomer because I only came to this country in 1977. There are those who have said to me that, therefore, I really do not understand, that I do not realise what it is all about, that I have not had to live with the problem, and so on and so forth. However, I would say to this House, as I said in our party room when we discussed this two or three weeks ago, that the fact that I am a newcomer will perhaps give me some degree of objectivity, which is often lacking in those who have been fortunate enough to live in this country all their lives.

By whatever yardstick one chooses to use, I believe the Aboriginal community in this country is in an unacceptable situation. Whether one is talking about rural communities, remote communities or urban communities, or whether one is measuring in terms of life expectancy, the disproportionately high number of Aborigines in gaol, the grog problems which lead to the violence problem, the poor standards of health and education and the incredibly high levels of unemployment-all of these well evidenced by the recent Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody-the Aboriginal community of this country is a disadvantaged group.

In a sense it almost does not matter who is to blame-of course, it does matter-because the bottom line is that whatever has gone before has failed. Money alone is not the answer; obviously money is important, but it is not the only answer. Money needs to be delivered at the sharp end where it is needed and not perhaps, I suggest, on some of the Aboriginal bureaucratic industry that has grown up in certain quarters. However, money is not the real issue. It seems to me that we need a new initiative and I believe the Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation Bill could be it, or at least part of it.

We cannot ignore the history behind the present situation. There have been mistakes made on both sides of the argument and on all sides of politics. I believe, from what I have seen in the brief time I have been associated with the Aboriginal community, that by and large that community is angry. I think it feels betrayed by the present Government because it had higher expectations of the Government than perhaps it had of this side of politics when it was in government. The Opposition has not covered itself in glory all the time either. I think the Aboriginal community is fed up with the reports that have gone on interminably, is fed up with people from outside visiting communities-flying in, staying for a couple of hours, flying out again and then writing more reports-and is fed up with white experts; and it wants some action.

Unfortunately that desire for action to tackle the fundamentals of the problem is not always reciprocated by the white community. That situation will breed Aboriginal activists who will be strident in their cries, which is perfectly understandable. They talk about wanting land rights and control of their own destiny, which I think is understandable and, frankly, not unreasonable. I put it to the non-Aboriginal community: how would we feel had we been conquered in the last world war and our country was still being occupied by the people who took our land by force? Would arguments about how we ran the country before cut any ice in terms of our claims to our land? I do not think we can complain about the attitudes of the Aboriginal community when it makes those strident calls.

Racism has existed and does exist in Australia, and we need to recognise the role it has played in the history of this country. Unfortunately, racism exists in some of the attitudes still endemic today; we have to acknowledge that problem. The key is that we now need to start to fix some of the problems on the ground and to build up some of the solutions to overcome the disadvantage. That means that we have to do some more meaningful things in health and education and that we must look at the violence and create the jobs and so on.

The Bill is particularly well worded, and I was struck by the reference of the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Aboriginal Reconciliation (Mr Tickner) to its objectives:

The object of the establishment of the Council is to promote a process of reconciliation between Aborigines and Torres Strait Islanders and the wider Australian community, based on an appreciation by the Australian community as a whole of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander cultures and achievements and of the unique position of Aborigines and Torres Strait Islanders as the indigenous peoples of Australia, and by means that include the fostering of an ongoing national commitment to co-operate to address Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander disadvantage.

The Aboriginal community are the indigenous people of this country; and they are disadvantaged. By any objective assessment, past policies have failed. We must now try cooperation by adopting a process of reconciliation to try to address these matters.

The honourable member for Chisholm (Dr Wooldridge) dealt earlier with the main points of the Bill and has indicated the coalition's support for it. He foreshadowed some amendments which, because of the guillotine, I suspect we will not actually get to, but I support his position. The Minister has obviously moved a long way from the original draft of the Bill to try to achieve a truly bipartisan position, for which I congratulate him, as I congratulate the honourable member for Chisholm on the work he has done with the Minister.

Having achieved this degree of agreement, it is important that we do not now let divisive forces take over. It is important to guard against activists taking over the structure we are now talking about. I can understand their frustration, but they need to recognise that it can be counterproductive. The emphasis must be on community contact and the Council must concentrate on practical outcomes. As has been said before, this Bill sets a level of accountability new to any statutory authority and operates via a strategic plan that will make the Council entirely goal driven, with regular reviews of its own performance, both internally and externally. I think that is commendable.

The plan will state its goals and objectives, state its strategy for achieving those goals, describe its programs, estimate the cost of the programs, and set out performance indicators and targets; and The Council will prepare a plan every three years and will report annually. The plan will also require the approval of the Minister and, after consultation with the Leader of the Opposition, will be laid before both Houses of Parliament; it can be varied only with the approval of the Minister after he or she has consulted with the Leader of the Opposition and then that variation must be tabled in both Houses of Parliament.

In addition to its strategic plan, the council will be required to report annually on progress towards reconciliation, assess annually its performance against its performance indicators set out in the strategic plan, have its annual report referred to the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Aboriginal Affairs, have its annual report tabled in both Houses of Parliament and operate within the limits of the resources made available for its purposes.

I suggest that there is probably little doubt that the preamble to the Bill will upset some people-and I regret to say that it will probably be more on my side of politics than anywhere else-but it seems to me that that preamble is actually a true statement of history. Before I came to this fine country, I served in the Royal Air Force in Britain, and I helped Britain preside over the handing back of some of the finer parts of the world to its original owners. Britain has acknowledged on many occasions that this is the case in various parts of the world, so why should we not also acknowledge that.

My plea to the non-Aboriginal community is that they now try to approach this whole subject and the reconciliation council with an open mind, to give it a chance, to look into their own souls, and to ask themselves if their community should not do better by the Aboriginal community. I say to the non-Aboriginal community: please do not dismiss the initiative as an attempt to erroneously assuage white guilt or as a comfortable, warm feeling for white middle class intellectuals or as a back-door entry into land rights or whatever-and I have heard those phrases used. I urge that they acknowledge the fact of Aboriginal history at white hands, the demonstrable fact of Aboriginal disadvantage, the fact of failure of past policies and the fact of the actuality of different cultural values.

Aboriginal people are not migrants in this land as we, the white community, would normally use that word. So why not accept that they have a special right to regain their self-respect, their economic independence and social equality with all other Australians in the land of their birth and of their forefathers' birth. I urge the Aboriginal community-and I know it is hard-to be just a little bit more patient. Let us not put the clock back by extreme actions that will only generate a backlash from the non-Aboriginal community. They may take the view that that is not fair, that they should not be asked such a question. They would say to me, `How do you know what it is like?'. Of course, I cannot put myself in their position, but I have some understanding. Over 30 years ago I married a non-Caucasian lady. At the time I was serving in the air force in Britain and such things were not done by British serving officers. I served in that air force for 24 years, and my wife and our children and I have all suffered discrimination in various forms over the years. So I have some understanding, but not a true understanding.

But things do change, and I say to the Aboriginal community that I believe their situation can be overcome. It must be overcome, but they must do their part. I assure them that there are members in this place, on both sides of the House, who are determined that the situation in which the Aboriginal and the Torres Strait Islander communities find themselves will be corrected in our lifetime. I support the Bill and I hope that the amendments proposed by the honourable member for Chisholm will be accepted by the Government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Truss Mr W.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —This Bill to establish the Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation is not being opposed by the Opposition, despite the fact that its birth has obviously been through a period of considerable suspicion. There has indeed been an atmosphere of concern about what the Government really intended as a result of this legislation. There had been much talk about treaties and specific acts of reconciliation. Those kinds of concepts are not readily accepted by me or many other people on this side of the House. A treaty of itself achieves absolutely nothing to improve the welfare of Aboriginal people. A piece of paper does nothing to enhance the feeling of goodwill between Aboriginals and other Australians. Indeed, there is the real risk that it could create additional division.

SPEECH.PARA: The signing of any kind of document implies that there are two different races of people, two different nations, within this one continent, and that is a concept that is not readily accepted by Australians. I am pleased, therefore, that this legislation leaves out almost all references to its objectives being to establish some kind of treaty or particular document and talks much more about improving relationships between black and white. It deals with the tensions which clearly exist currently and, in particular, it deals with methods where perhaps those kinds of tensions can be reduced, and refers particularly to community level consultation. That is where I feel real achievements can in fact occur.

This legislation has very meritorious intent. We in the Opposition parties have a real commitment to the welfare of the Australian Aboriginal community and, indeed, all of those who identify with Aboriginal races. But we must be looking towards the achievement of a real objective of one nation, a group of people working together for the benefit of our country. Australia will fully come of age as a multi-racial society only when there are no special provisions for any particular race, no need for special provisions for Aboriginals, no Aboriginal Affairs department, no Abstudy or special settlements; when all Australians are as one, working together with cultural specialities, with particular aims and objectives. Obviously, there are many differences in our outlooks, but we must combine our differences for one benefit.

Sadly, over the years, Aboriginals have been abused and used as political pawns by so many sectors of our community, manipulated in many instances by white advisers, often with the very best of intent, often with the objective of doing the best for the people. Aboriginal people have been, over the generations, a very trusting group. They have tended to believe what many people have said to them, even when that has not always been in their best interests. Those people have come from all sides. There have been those, sadly many on the Government payroll, who, rather than help the Aboriginal lot, have fed racial hatred and incited people to make demands which have done nothing whatever to improve the real welfare of Aboriginal people. That is one of the reasons why we talk about reconciliation today. There would be no need for reconciliation if the divisions had not been created in the past. It is most regrettable that people, both white and black and every other colour, have contributed towards the development of those divisions in the past.

I am proud to say that I represent the people of one of the most excellent Aboriginal communities in Australia, the people of Cherbourg. It is an excellent town with magnificent facilities. It is an excellent example of all that is good in an Aboriginal community but, sadly, also it is an example of many of the things that are bad. It has some very fine leaders like Councillor Les Stewart, who heads the Cherbourg Community Council. It has magnificent facilities-I would venture to say superior to any country town its size anywhere in the country. It has a fine hospital, an aged people's facility, a child-care centre, magnificent schools, and soon even a technical and further education centre. It has an excellent shire council. Recently, the emu farm received an award under the local government achievement awards, and the community includes artists and other people who are contributing to society as a whole. It has much of which to be proud. But, sadly, it also has unemployment, drunkenness, crime and arson.

Indeed, one of the deaths in custody which were investigated recently occurred in Cherbourg. So it also has its share of strife-much of it, again I am sad to say, stirred up by troublemakers, some of whom have even had training in Cuba, Nicaragua and places like that. Those things have contributed nothing to what is in many ways a model community.

Through the Queensland Government's deed of grant in trust, the community has had title to its land for many years. But as happens in many of these instances, land rights in themselves achieve nothing. The fact that the people have had title to that land has not contributed significantly to the many outstanding achievements in that community, nor has it done anything to redress the social ills that are so apparent. Unfortunately, these days there are many who are choosing to use Aboriginal people with other intentions.

One very sad example in recent times has been the way in which radical conservationists have endeavoured to mobilise the Aboriginal land rights cause in their own interests. I guess Coronation Hill is an example of that, where the Jawoyn people have been asked to put arguments forward as to why Coronation Hill is a sacred site, despite the fact that Justice Kearney ruled in 1987 that the spiritual affinities of the Jawoyn people ended some 59 kilometres south of that particular area.

I have had an instance in my own electorate in recent times in which some people in the radical conservation movement have tried to use elements of the Batjala people to develop some kind of a claim to Fraser Island. We saw the quite extraordinary action of some of these radical conservation groups signing an accord with people who it was contended were descendants of the Batjalas and claiming some kind of credibility for their claims to that particular area.

It was only a matter of days later that Olga Miller, the recognised chief of the Batjala people, disowned that kind of document.
