Earlier she had made it quite clear, as a senior elder of those people, a person recognised by all in the community as a lady of great honour and achievement, that the Batjala people had no claims on Fraser Island. Those people have been used by radical conservationists in order to give some kind of credibility to their radical claims. Sadly, that fact has now confirmed by Mr Fitzgerald's inquiry. Those sorts of things are doing a great disservice to the Aboriginal people.

The radicals are not recognised generally by full-blooded Aboriginals, who see them as part white or even less. We have seen Chinese people, Afghan camel drivers and the like trying to make claims on behalf of Aboriginals to particular areas of land.

Aboriginals do have an affinity with their land, just as I do as a third generation Australian farmer. I have a great affinity with the property that my grandfather settled three generations ago. That is important to me. Such an affinity is important to many Aboriginal people who traverse their land for long periods, and I recognise that type of affiliation, just as I expect other people to recognise my close attachment to my family farm.

In recognising that, we need to put aside the claims of those whose ancestors left their areas hundreds of years ago and who have now been brought back by people-who perhaps are well meaning in their intentions-to try to claim that they have a deep and long-lasting affiliation with a particular area of land. It is those artificial claims, which can be demonstrated throughout the community to be without substance, that do serious damage to those who are genuinely working in the interests of Aboriginal people and who want to see their reasonable aspirations advanced wherever they possibly can.

Land rights themselves do nothing to improve the Aboriginal lot. Queensland led Australia in the development of deeds of grants in trust. Now we have the political development by the Goss Government of trying to introduce some kind of so-called inalienable freehold title. Of course, there is no such thing. `Inalienable' and `freehold' are contradictory terms; it is either one or the other. The Aboriginal communities have recognised and said publicly-even in their radical demonstrations-that the deed of grant in trust was better for them than what is being proposed today.

Land rights do nothing to improve health, education, the onset of alcoholism, unemployment or social degradation. They do nothing for the spiritual welfare of people who left their land generations ago; nor will the treaty achieve anything. The only people who really believe they do are the ones who have been listening to white activists trying to convince people that somehow or other a piece of paper or the ability to call a piece of land their own will suddenly cure all their ills.

Australia has a responsibility to its Aboriginal people and, indeed, all of those who are in need. Aboriginal development and achievement have been disappointing. Their current status is totally unacceptable to Australians. Ours is a rich country with bountiful resources and we have a responsibility to use them to ensure that all people who live in this country, regardless of their colour, have basic rights, privileges, good health and freedom of opportunity.

So it does not achieve anything to throw money, land, or treaties around. What we really need is to show compassion, to understand better health care and, in particular, to encourage self-reliance. Programs such as the community development program have achieved a great deal in that regard. So the consultation process is indeed necessary. We need to bring about reconciliation among all Australians and break down the existing barriers. Whilst the establishment of the Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation is a somewhat bureaucratic response, I hope it will at the community level encourage talking and consultation and will achieve a better lot for all Australians as a result.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Taylor Mr W.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is indeed a pleasure to participate in the debate on the Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation Bill 1991. Earlier this year, it was this Opposition's pleasure to support the Government in its initiatives in the Gulf conflict. Tonight, we have another piece of very critical legislation requiring similar support, in both our national and international interests.

SPEECH.PARA: Previous speakers have spoken of the need for bipartisan support for this legislation. While the Opposition will be moving a couple of technical amendments to the legislation, demonstrably we have that necessary bipartisanship in very large measure. Irrefutably that should be the case. Very few reasonable people could argue that our Aboriginal people are not disadvantaged to a greater degree than most Australians.

Aboriginal youth unemployment, for example, stands at about 60 per cent, or twice the national average for unemployed youth generally. The establishment of the Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation, central to this legislation before us, is nevertheless not the panacea to the national disgrace-and that is not too strong a word-that is the lot of our Aboriginal people.

To see it simplistically as such is to hide one's head in the sand. As the honourable member for Kennedy (Mr Hulls) indicated earlier in this debate, the issues of unemployment, education, housing and health are central to the reversal of the Aboriginals' unfortunate lot in our society today. All of that will take time. However, time is fast running out if we are to make real progress. This Bill and its attendant legislation are simply starting points, albeit critical starting points, in re-establishing the one nation in which all Australians, black, white or brindle, should believe, and in which we should believe fervently, uncompromisingly and without undue apology for the inequities of the past.

The legislation before us today should not be seen in any way as condoning the need for a formal treaty arrangement between the Aboriginal and non-Aboriginal peoples of our land. Most importantly, as the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) said in his recent letter to the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke):

The process of reconciliation should provide to Aboriginal people the same opportunities that are available to other Australians . . . The process of reconciliation should be devoted to the attainment of specific goals to improve the wellbeing of Aboriginal and Torres Strait islander people thus ensuring them equality of opportunity and enabling them to play a full part in the Australian nation.
He went on to say:

. . . the council should work to establish agreed goals and set annual benchmarks for progress including in housing, health, education particularly literacy, employment opportunities and other infrastructure. This is something ATSIC appears to have difficulty doing to date.
He finished by saying:
. . . a process which improves broad community understanding and Aboriginal self esteem offers the best hope of an environment in which Aboriginal advancement programs will succeed.

Implicit in this process of reconciliation is a need for the Aboriginal community to understand that it must enjoy the same measure of public accountability referred to by the honourable member for Denison (Mr Kerr) earlier as all other elements of our society. We need equality, but it is not in the national interest for any element of our society to be seen to have more than equal opportunity.

For example, in 1988, I raised with the then Federal Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, Mr Hand, a number of substantial anomalies in the public accountability of the Darling Downs Aboriginal housing cooperative and its involvement in the former Alma Vale horse stud on the outskirts of Toowoomba in my Queensland electorate. In particular, I was concerned about the high purchase price of nearly $750,000 from public funds and seemingly little earnings return for such a large outlay of taxpayers' money. To the then Minister's credit, he sustained those views and some corrective action was taken in a very short period.

Recently, I was informed by concerned members of the local Aboriginal community that there are, once again, major problems in Alma Vale created by elements in the cooperative. I am informed that this facility is now being used to house homeless Aboriginal youth of both sexes.

Whilst I welcome such initiatives by the Aboriginal community, a number of basic questions, however, need to be answered in several quarters. Firstly, I ask the cooperative: who is supervising such activities? Are they qualified to do so? Are appropriate standards being maintained? Who is funding the initiative? Secondly, I ask the Toowoomba City Council: has the necessary city council approval to vary the official use of this land been given; if not, why not? Thirdly, I ask the Queensland State Minister: has she been consulted on this initiative? Is she satisfied with the facilities provided? What are the funding arrangements involving the Queensland State Government? Fourthly, I ask the Federal Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Tickner), who is at the table: is he satisfied that such a variation of land use is an appropriate Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission initiative or is he happy to leave such a decision to the local co-op? What degree of scrutiny is he exercising to ensure that public accountability and other standards are being maintained?

To the Minister's continuing credit and honourable intentions, and having spoken to him briefly about these matters on a couple of occasions this week, I understand that he is now taking ministerial action appropriate to the circumstances. If such an initiative is to be effective to the degree that it deserves, it seems to me that all of these authorities at unofficial, official and ministerial levels need to be swimming in the same direction and in harmony. Unless that is done-it seems to me that sort of process is implicit in the legislation before us this evening-some people can be excused for assuming that we do indeed have a segment of our community which might be receiving more than equal opportunity over and above the due processes of law and social cohesiveness.

I finish my contribution to this debate by saying simply that, unless we can learn to live as one proud undivided nation under one national flag, irrespective of our origins, then we can only fall further behind in maintaining our national and international standing. I reject this legislation, or indeed any other statutory medium, if it is seen as yet another vehicle to national land rights claims. It cannot and must not be seen in such a light by any reasonable person.

I salute the Aboriginal community in my electorate. I recognise that there is some frustration at a lack of progress in certain quarters. However, I hope that the Aboriginal community will continue to exercise the necessary degree of maturity and patience, rather than resort to the inexcusable behaviour by an unruly element, such as we saw in George Street in Brisbane last week. For many of those and others they have turned the other cheek for too long. However, it should be through the auspices of such legislation as we have before us tonight, rather than through such unwarranted violent action, that a truly equitable solution lies.

I congratulate the Minister and the Government on this legislative initiative as an important first step in ensuring that we maintain our unassailable one country ideals. I commend the Bill and its amendments by the honourable member for Chisholm (Dr Wooldridge) to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wooldridge Dr M.R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-As we are drawing towards the end of this debate, I would like to make a few comments on the course of the debate as I would like to place a few things on the record. They relate to two things: firstly, certain difficulties that have been brought up in the debate; and, secondly, the issue of bipartisanship. The honourable member for Pearce (Mr Chaney) said that he was concerned that people in the community have resentment over any notion of inherited guilt; the honourable member for the Northern Territory (Mr Snowdon) raised issues relating to the Northern Territory Government and, to be fair to him, he also raised issues relating to the Queensland Government; and the honourable member for Wide Bay (Mr Truss) raised concerns about separatism, concerns about a treaty, and concerns about land rights.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to address these issues because it seems to me that these difficulties are at the heart of what the Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation is trying to go towards. Soon after I was given this job as shadow Minister for Aboriginal affairs I found-I certainly was not expecting to find this-the degree of entrenched suspicion in Aboriginal affairs very disturbing. It is not just suspicion on one side or the other, but it is suspicion right across the board.

I will give some examples. Some time back, the Chief Minister of the Northern Territory wrote to the Minister for Social Security (Senator Richardson) and asked whether there was some way we could look at food coupons to reduce the problems of alcohol in central Australia. The letter from the Minister for Social Security was really fairly damning, to the effect that we were not going to have anything to do with any scheme like this in any manner or form. Yet, when the final report of the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody came out, Commissioner Elliott Johnston actually commended the Tangentyere Council in Alice Springs for the work that it had done in its own food coupon scheme, and suggested that maybe other parts of Australia could look to this as a model to help solve alcohol problems in certain communities.

I think I got the job of shadow Minister on a Thursday and that afternoon I was phoned by a member of the Northern Territory Government. He said, `There's a big march in Alice Springs against the grog on Saturday; can you make it up?' The very first occasion on which I actually got to consult with a large number of Aboriginal people was at this march. I was incredibly moved to see women of central Australia taking these problems into their own hands and protesting against the effects grog had on their community. I was shocked, quite frankly, to see in the next couple of days people denigrating this march, questioning its authenticity and trying to play down something that had moved me very deeply. Having been there and been part of it I was certain that it was very genuine.

Just half an hour before this debate started, I received a fax from the Australian Teachers Union which I will read out because it illustrates the point. It is from the President, Di Foggo, who I have not had the pleasure to meet. It criticises me for a press release put out a couple of days ago. It states:
For you, or any other individual or organisation, to attempt to block bi-partisan support for a process which promises fair representation and consultation . . . is disloyal to Australian society.

This was in response to a press release where I had said it was most disappointing that we were not looking at benchmarks, and that the Government had moved away from something it was going to do in the past. I went on to say that I acknowledged the Government had moved substantially to address the Opposition concerns and I would be discussing these matters with my colleagues in the coming weeks.

I say this not out of any fit of pique but just to illustrate the point that there are stereotypes in this. It is impossible to express something as mild as disappointment without someone on the other side coming out and saying, `We are disgusted that you are trying to block bipartisan support', particularly when I have spent the last six months of my life-I have probably travelled 30,000 kilometres around this country-trying to promote bipartisan support in this matter.

It highlights the problems and the suspicion we have in this area because of stereotype views and entrenched attitudes. I found that in some areas the Northern Territory Government has been enormously progressive in Aboriginal affairs, particularly in the area of bilingual Aboriginal education. It was actually the only State or Territory government in the country to support national land rights legislation. I hope that one thing this Council can do is to break down some of those stereotypes on both sides of the political debate and we can perhaps have a little more trust in all of this.

One honourable member alluded to bipartisanship and said that there was active and constructive discussion. I agree, and as long as the Government wants to address issues concerned with the well-being of Aboriginal people, it will have Opposition support. The Opposition also gives a commitment to the future work of this Council, provided it remains focused and goal-oriented and is delivering something of benefit to Aboriginal people. This legislation is one small step together from both sides of this House. It has involved an element of trust on both sides, which is unusual. I hope we do not all get tied down in the tyranny of words, because we have a real opportunity to go forward. I hope we can take it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tickner The Hon R.E.

TALKER.NAME: Mr TICKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Aboriginal Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Aboriginal Reconciliation)

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-In such a wide-ranging debate there are a number of matters to which I would like to respond. I begin by responding first of all to some matters raised by the shadow Minister for Aboriginal affairs, the honourable member for Chisholm (Dr Wooldridge). He put forward in good faith some suggestions for improvements to the Bill. As he would acknowledge, the Government has gone to great lengths to find common ground with the Opposition. I accept that the amendments are put forward in good faith, but unfortunately I cannot accept them. I have in a letter indicated the reason for being unable to do so, and I am inspired by the view and the commitment put forward by the shadow Minister that in no way were those amendments intended to diminish the full commitment of cross-party support given for this legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: In relation to the Government's amendments that have been accepted substantially to accommodate views put forward by the Opposition, I believe that in no way do they diminish the significance and the principles of the legislation. There is a reference added to the preamble which acknowledges that to date there has been no formal process of reconciliation. There is recognition in an amendment of a view of the Opposition that the other side does not wish to have a clause in the legislation that locks it into appointing a serving member of the Parliament. The Government acknowledges that view and the legislation has been amended accordingly. What I would say, however, is that it is important that we keep a dialogue going on this issue, because I very firmly believe that the processes of the Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation will be assisted by keeping in touch with the Parliament and ensuring that we continue to remain on common ground.

There is a further amendment that it is important to emphasise, and that is the continuing community focus the Opposition has put forward in relation to the Bill. The Government passionately believes that ought to be part and parcel of the process and, therefore, we have no hesitation in accepting those amendments.

I would like to say a number of things in the six minutes remaining to me. I have to think: what do I say to the shadow Minister when, like him, I left my room to attend this debate, which came on some 40 or 50 minutes prior to the expected time? It is one of the few pieces of legislation that passes through the second reading stage of the House of Representatives and then happens again once more with feeling. It is a demonstration of our mutual commitment that we did want to make this a substantial debate, and there is no question that it has been just that.

In public life there are probably all too few opportunities when people are able to be in the right place at the right time and, by virtue of the convergence of circumstances, are able to affect the outcome of an important issue. The shadow Minister is fortunate, as am I, to have been elected to the Federal Parliament and particularly fortunate that we happened to be allocated the responsibilities of Aboriginal affairs in this Parliament.

The shadow Minister's role, as the honourable member for Chisholm, has been one of behaving throughout this entire process with total integrity, with a very genuine and, I believe, heartfelt commitment to what all of us have been trying to achieve in this process. It has not been easy because we have realised that we have to ensure that the views of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people are listened to; that we have to be conscious that the Australian Democrats have a role in this process; and that we have to deal with our own parties. It has been truly an enormous task we have undertaken, but it is one that I think has been brought to fruition. We will see when the Bill passes through the Senate, but I have every confidence that it will. I want to take this opportunity to place on record my appreciation for the personal contribution made by the shadow Minister, and I think we should all welcome and acknowledge that.

Many things were said in the course of this debate: by the honourable member for Pearce (Mr Chaney); by the honourable member for Kennedy (Mr Hulls); by the honourable member for the Northern Territory (Mr Snowdon); by the honourable member for McMillan (Mr Riggall); by the honourable member for Moreton (Mr Gibson); by the honourable member for Aston (Mr Nugent)-who, I might say, made an outstanding contribution; by the honourable member for Wide Bay (Mr Truss), and I ought to say that I did disagree with a great many things he said, but it is true to say that his comments reminded us of the need for this public awareness and public education process, and to that extent I am indebted to him for his contribution; and by the honourable member for Groom (Mr Taylor), who also raised some specific matters to which I will respond formally. Time will not enable me to comment in detail about those individual contributions. However, I want to thank the honourable member for Calwell (Dr Theophanous) for giving up his opportunity to speak in this debate in order to allow me to make these remarks.

In the remaining minutes I would like to say some thankyous to people who deserve enormous appreciation for their contribution: to Lois O'Donoghue, the chairperson of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission and the ATSIC commissioners; to the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), who in the course of this process has allowed me carriage of the matter and has never failed in his commitment to ensure that we reached the conclusion we are reaching today; to my Caucus colleagues, my true believer friends, who have remained firm and staunch in the course of this debate and in the process; to all the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people who have shaped my life and, indeed, shaped this very process that is before the House; to my trusted friends and confidantes, some of whom are in the public gallery and who have worked with me from day one in trying to find the common ground; to the Opposition, as I have already indicated; to the Australian Democrats, who have also from day one never faltered in giving their support to this process; and-something I have never done before-to my own staff, who put up with, to use a phrase of the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock), my manic determination to ensure that this Bill got through the House on a unanimous basis. I thank them all.

Mr Deputy Speaker, in the very limited time available to me, I want to encapsulate what this Bill means to me. I, like others in this place, both Aboriginal, Torres Strait Islander and non-Aboriginal, am very proud to be Australian. We have an incredible, wonderful country, although one that is far from perfect, as all the contributions to this debate have made absolutely clear. If there is one issue that above all else looms large as one to be tackled as we move to that centenary of Federation, it is this issue of reconciliation and justice for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people. I say in absolute conclusion that this process we are embarking upon is one that is intrinsically Australian, one based on recognition of the essential dignity of humankind, the elimination of racism, the recognition of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders as Australia's indigenous people, and a commitment to a fair go for Australia's most disadvantaged people.
I commend the Bill to the House and I table the further explanatory memorandum.

DEBATE.TITLE: COMMUNITY SERVICES AND HEALTH LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1991[COGNATE BILL:THERAPEUTIC GOODS (CHARGES) AMENDMENT BILL 1991]

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 30 May, on motion by Mr Staples:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that it is the wish of the House to debate the Community Services and Health Legislation Amendment Bill 1991 concurrently with the Therapeutic Goods (Charges) Bill 1991. There being no objection, the Chair will allow that course to be followed.

DEBATE.TITLE: COMMUNITY SERVICES AND HEALTH LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1991

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Woods Dr R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to address, firstly, the Community Services and Health Legislation Amendment Bill. It has two sections: one relates to nursing homes and one relates to a number of health matters. I will, firstly, address the clauses which relate to nursing homes in terms of the amendments to the National Health Act. This part of the Bill contains provisions which enable much more information about nursing homes to be made publicly available. These changes will enable three further categories of information to be released directly to the public.

SPEECH.PARA: The first of those categories relates to action plans prepared by a nursing home indicating how the home will be improved so as to meet prescribed standards of care. Action plans apply to homes that have been found not to meet the standards and are the proprietor's indication of the changes which will be made in the practices of that home. This provision poses no problem to the vast majority of nursing homes, because quality care has always been and will remain the pursuit of all responsible persons and parties to the nursing home and hostel system. However, it is regrettable that insufficient funding in the present construction of the standard aggregate module is endangering the financial viability of the industry as a whole and putting undue stress on proprietors and nursing staff in their endeavours to care for our frail elderly. This provision will also answer, following the publication of an outcomes report, the home's intention to deal with matters. At present, with publication of the inspection report only, matters of non-compliance are often left up in the air as to how a proprietor intends to deal with them.

The second provision relates to basic descriptive information concerning each nursing home, such as its name, address, numbers of beds, fees charged, et cetera. These can now be published. Some concern has been expressed that this seemingly innocuous provision is full of hidden dangers. There is some anxiety about possible bias by bureaucrats against the private enterprise sector in making public, in any way that the Secretary sees fit, any or all relevant information. This could, in fact, have an immense effect upon the financial viability of the business, particularly in those geographical areas where there are higher than average bed vacancies. Occupancy clearly has a major impact on the financial viability of a nursing home, and the unchecked comments of a bureaucrat are completely unacceptable.

We understand that an appeals mechanism is available to a proprietor who is not satisfied that all the information has been made public without bias, but I seek reassurance from the Minister for Community Services and Health (Mr Howe) that the departmental officers and the geriatric assessment teams will be instructed not to favour one home or another in giving out information of this nature.

The third issue is the information which will be released directly to the public on action taken, or intended to be taken, to suspend or revoke the approval of a nursing home, to vary the conditions of its approval, to cease benefits for new admissions or to remove or vary exempt status. Again, there is concern that the sanction of ceasing payment of benefits to new admissions to a home can only cause standards of a home to drop even further. It has been pointed out that the present funding arrangements allow for optimum viability of homes only when more than 98 per cent occupancy is achieved.

If funding is denied to new residents, while occupancy levels will be maintained, in fact, funding will be appropriate only to occupancy levels of those residents still receiving benefits. Therefore, only one result can occur: the funding intended for existing residents will have to be spread over all residents and, of course, standards will drop. Problems will result in the work force of the home as payments of wages would be jeopardised, causing interference by relevant trade unions and, potentially, industrial courts.

We understand from the Department of Community Services and Health that such action will be taken only in drastic circumstances and that an appeals mechanism is available to the proprietor. Again I seek the Minister's assurance on this matter. I also seek confirmation that an appeals mechanism is available prior to the publication of information about ministerial action and other information about approved nursing homes. Subject to these assurances being given, the Opposition supports these amendments to the National Health Act. We also support the technical amendments to the Nursing Homes and Hostels Legislation Amendment Act.

Regarding the health related issues in this legislation, there are some changes which are relatively minor but still significant and which the Opposition will support. For example, the definition of `a professional service' under the Health Insurance Act will be clarified by this legislation so that Medicare benefits can be claimed for a service only where a physical attendance on the patient occurs and a clinically relevant service also takes place. This effectively closes a loophole which has been exploited by some members of the medical profession.

Part V of the Bill contains amendments to introduce a scheme which allows sponsors of therapeutic goods to pay their evaluation fees by instalments when applying to register their goods under the Therapeutic Goods Act. Similarly, there are also amendments which deal with the introduction of fees similar to those payable under the Freedom of Information Act for processing the information in the Australian register of therapeutic goods and making it available to the public.

One of the more forward looking changes relates to decentralisation of the individual patient usage (IPU) scheme, which has been in operation for a number of years. It was intended to cover situations where drugs which are not normally available in Australia-usually because they have not been marketed-may be used by individual doctors to treat individual patients in given circumstances. The usual sequence of events is that, in a situation where a physician feels that a particular therapeutic product, usually a pharmaceutical product, is necessary for the well-being of his patient and there is no viable, acceptable alternative, he has to make an approach to the therapeutic goods department, and its medical officer in Canberra will assess each individual request for an IPU and determine whether or not it is to be agreed to.

As could be imagined, this is a very cumbersome procedure. It was cumbersome at the best of times when there were very few IPU requests. I understand that the number of IPUs is now approaching 20,000 per year. Clearly the problem is going to increase, and the suggestion of the Minister, which is to be implemented by this legislation, is that the IPU scheme will be decentralised so that the decision will be made by individual medical officers in various hospitals to undertake effectively the same decision as is currently made by the Commonwealth medical officers in Canberra in the therapeutic goods administration. I understand that the guidelines will be much the same as at present, but certainly it will allow a greater flexibility and, presumably, will end up as a more sensible solution to what is an ongoing problem.

The reason there are so many requests for IPUs is that a large number of therapeutic products, mainly pharmaceuticals, are not available in Australia. The reason they are not available in Australia is, by and large, a result of restrictions in the approval process for those products. Those restrictions have reached a level where they are acting as a deterrent to pharmaceutical companies to introduce products into Australia. Already there are difficulties because of the pricing structure in Australia, which is significantly lower than most other world markets. There is also a major deterrent in the fact that the red tape-the bureaucracy which has to be gone through-is much worse here than in most other comparable advanced countries.

In this House before I have illustrated some of the problems which face pharmaceutical manufacturers. The problem is a very real and a very large one. It is because there is a deterrent to pharmaceutical companies to introduce drugs into Australia at an early stage in their development when, in many cases, there are no alternative drugs available that the IPU system has been widely used. It should be a safety valve for the occasional situation where the optimal drug is not available in Australia. The fact that there are now 20,000 approvals is an indictment of the system of drug approval in Australia which has deterred so many pharmaceutical companies from seeking approval for their particular product.

I was only too well aware of this in my alter ego as an oncologist prior to entering Parliament when there were a number of well proven pharmaceutical products which, for one reason or other, had not been approved for general marketing in Australia. Looking down the list which is in front of me now, I see that there are at least half a dozen drugs that have been around for a considerable length of time on the IPU list which clearly have no place on that list. They are drugs which are well recognised as being very valuable in the treatment of a number of malignant diseases.

If I look outside the cancer area in pharmaceuticals, there is an even longer list of drugs which should be approved by this administration but which have not been. On the cancer list, there are drugs such as bulsulphan, which, if I remember rightly, was introduced in 1955 and has been regularly used as a treatment of choice for chronic myeloid leukaemia ever since. Ifosphamide is one of the drugs of choice for a number of odd carcinomas. Hexamethlymelamine is a very valuable drug. Mesna, pentostatin, fludarabine and 4-Hydroxy Androsteinedione are all drugs which should be available in Australia and at present are only available in this crazy restricted fashion on the IPU.

I welcome the Government's move to decentralise the IPU system, but I urge the Government to take steps to rectify the basic problem. What it is doing is, to a large extent, only a bandaid. It should solve the problem by making sure that products which are on the IPU at present which should not be there are taken off and made appropriately available. That is certainly the case in the majority of these drugs which I have been discussing today.

Apart from that problem, we have no difficulty with the Community Services and Health Legislation Amendment Bill. Most of these changes are sensible. They impose no extra undue costs on either the industry or on individuals or consumers. Overall, there should be a decrease in the bureaucracy associated with these procedures. Subject to seeking the assurances mentioned earlier regarding nursing homes, we will support this Bill as it stands.

The second Bill we are discussing is the Therapeutic Goods (Charges) Amendment Bill 1991. This briefly makes a number of amendments to part 3 of the Therapeutic Goods Act. They result from problems that we and the Australian Democrats had with the original Therapeutic Goods Act passed earlier this year. This was an example of a Bill being passed at a time when the Government recognised that it was flawed and recognised that it would have to introduce amendments to resolve those flaws. These are some of the flaws which were pointed out at that time. They relate basically to the grouping of therapeutic goods where they share common characteristics and a common manufacturer and some alteration to the charges relating to those groups so that each individual group is subject to a charge for registration and inspection rather than each individual therapeutic item. Again, this should reduce the bureaucracy and the charges to manufacturers. We will support this Bill also.
Therefore, I am happy to point out that we are taking yet again a bipartisan approach in some of these matters to ensure that the collective health of Australia is indeed improved.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Elliott Mr R.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to speak in support of the Community Services and Health Legislation Amendment Bill and the Therapeutic Goods (Charges) Amendment Bill that are before the House this evening. I note the comments of the honourable member for Lowe (Dr Bob Woods) about the Opposition's support for the Bills before us. In his comments on the Bill dealing with nursing homes, the support was somewhat qualified, particularly in the area of his concern that proprietors of nursing homes should have their rights spelt out perhaps more clearly than he suggested was the case in this legislation. The fundamental thing to say about that is that these provisions provide for an important further step in the Government's real commitment to ensure that the residents of nursing homes are paramount in the well-being of the whole of the aged care services. That is an important step because it is long overdue.

SPEECH.PARA: Frankly, in the past all too often residents of nursing homes were allowed to go there, often with very little information-in many cases, misinformation-and very often the quality of care that should be a fundamental ingredient was left on the back-burner as the pursuit of profits and economic interests on the part of nursing home proprietors became the paramount consideration.

Fortunately, this Government-particularly added to in the measures before the House-is determined to ensure that residents of nursing homes and the overall quality of nursing home care is strong and is conducive to a quality aged care policy commitment. That is very much a hallmark of what this Government stands for. We have made it a priority that aged care should be a comprehensive policy provision. We recognise that in many cases nursing home care is an important component of that. It is not in all cases. One would hope that before families reach the conclusion that nursing home care is the appropriate accommodation for aged relatives they have the chance to consider all the available options and to consider whether there were other appropriate options in terms of community care that could be provided.

Many families reach the conclusion that nursing home accommodation is essential. The provisions contained in the Community Services and Health Legislation Amendment Bill will ensure that basic rights are spelt out very clearly and will ensure that some of the difficulties that have arisen as a result of the provisions of privacy and secrecy relating to nursing home arrangements do not stand in the way of people who may be going into nursing homes having full details about costings and other arrangements that will affect them vitally in their future years.

The quality of aged care is critical. I have been to a number of nursing homes in my electorate over the last 12 months. The Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services (Mr Staples) has visited two or three of them as well. Only recently, he opened extensions to one of the major nursing homes that exists in the electorate of Parramatta. It is very pleasing to see the way improvements are being undertaken, particularly in the area of dementia care, which has been one of the areas to which the Government has devoted attention as part of its overall aged care commitment.

The changes to this Bill enable the Department to make crucial information available to the public without in any way compromising the rights of residents to privacy and the nursing home proprietor's right to have commercial information remain confidential. A noteworthy feature of the Government's aged care policies has been to enable older people to make their own decisions about the care they need. Freedom of choice underlies all the Government's policies in this area. The whole philosophy of the charter of residents rights and responsibilities is to empower the nursing home resident to take his or her own decisions.

Fundamental to the ability to make an informed decision is the provision of information. Surely, no-one could argue that point. It is impossible to make an appropriate decision about available options for aged care without all available information. This Government is concerned to ensure that older people and their families are well aware of the choices available to them when they seek that help. These choices include whether to seek additional help to care for the person at home; whether to approach a geriatric assessment service for an assessment; and whether to consider hostel or nursing home admission. If nursing home admission is recommended, then the family needs to know more about the range and availability of services. They need to know things such as location of nursing home services and more details about fees that are charged and services provided.

The existing secrecy provisions of the National Health Act have unfortunately restricted the ability of the Government to properly inform residents of nursing homes, their relatives and the rest of the community about care provided in nursing homes. As well, the Act has restricted the dissemination of information concerning action taken by the Government against nursing homes which are not providing appropriate care. The honourable member for Lowe (Dr Bob Woods) referred to this and expressed concern about the all-embracing nature of those provisions. Surely it is the right of the community at large, where very serious problems are identified in terms of the quality of care, the nature of the facility and how it is being maintained, to be aware of those issues in making their decisions about future movements into a particular establishment. They are very important issues.

Several amendments are proposed to the National Health Act which will significantly strengthen the effect of the regulatory program of standards monitoring in nursing homes. Again, that is a provision that people can reasonably see as a positive step forward. The nursing home outcome standards, established by the Government in 1987, emphasise the importance of residents as individuals and members of the community. The standards set out the care and lifestyle objectives which the nursing home industry is expected to achieve for all residents. Surely, again, that is a provision that the people at large would want to see. The whole community shares the concern and objective of wanting to ensure that all residents of nursing homes do have quality of care, that comprehensive services are provided and that the residents are not allowed to be just left and forgotten as has occurred, sadly, in the past.

The standards focus on the outcomes for residents, as it has been found that monitoring of inputs or processes alone cannot guarantee that residents have a high quality of life and care. The standards represent a significant change in the way that government perceives nursing homes and the care of the aged in general. In the past, regulations and legislation have primarily addressed the inputs to care and the physical environment of nursing homes rather than the quality of care and the lifestyle of residents affected by them. Outcome standards also recognise the changing perception of nursing homes as being the long term home of residents as well as health care facilities, and by not specifying inputs or processes, the standards encourage flexibility in nursing home design, service provision and work practices. The intent of the standards is also to encourage and enable residents to perform activities, maintain responsibilities and receive support according to their individual needs and capabilities.

Owing to the increasing frailty of residents in nursing homes, it is recognised that not all residents will be able to avail themselves fully of freedoms which are available and utilised by some, and which are properly theirs. However, this is not a reason for withdrawing or qualifying the quality of service that is provided for the majority of residents in those nursing homes. As part of the Government's residents rights strategy and intention to ensure that information about nursing homes is widely available, the Government publishes reports of its visits to nursing homes and age hostels.

However, some parts of the National Health Act unnecessarily restrict the provision of available information in these areas to the public. Those restrictions make it difficult to inform the public about action that a proprietor is taking to meet the standards, any action the Minister is taking in relation to homes providing a poor quality of service, and any information on homes that have closed. Existing legislation prevents the publication of a standards monitoring report once a home has closed-again, an undesirable consequence addressed by these Bills.

The proposed changes to the legislation will allow publication of standards monitoring reports prepared on visits undertaken before the closure. I also emphasise that the proprietor will still be given at least 30 days in which to comment on the report prior to its publication. That was one point raised by the honourable member for Lowe which is actually contained within the Bill. The proposed amendments also allow the Government to release information in regard to details of action that the Government has taken or intends to take in relation to sanctions and a nursing home's condition of approval. The Government will allow proprietors 30 days in which to comment on these statements, except in circumstances where there is an urgent need to release information to protect the welfare or interests of persons who are or who may become residents of the nursing home in the immediate future. I am sure honourable members would agree that that is a fairly sensible provision.

I would emphasise also that the spirit of the proposed amendments reflect the Government's concern that residents of nursing homes receive care of the highest quality. Inherent in this responsibility is the need to inform people who have a vested interest in aged care-residents, their relatives, State Government agencies and industry bodies-of action that the Government has taken or is taking. It is inappropriate that the proprietor can decide not to inform residents and prospective residents of any sanctions action being taken by the Commonwealth. The ability of the Commonwealth to release this information will ensure that residents and relatives are fully informed of what is happening to their home.

These provisions are sensible arrangements because they ensure that the quality of care that residents deserve, and rightly seek in the current age, will be maintained and adhered to. The action that the Government has taken over recent times to ensure the quality of aged care is something that the community now recognises and appreciates. Fortunately, we have much less emphasis on the sorts of very negative and damning exposes that we have often seen in the media in the past about nursing homes that were very poorly maintained, where the quality of care was appalling and where residents were being treated very much as lepers in an institution and forgotten.

The Government has been very vigilant in ensuring that those sorts of stories are matters of past history, and that residents of nursing homes now receive quality care treatment. I have no doubt that those measures are an important further step in what is, as I say, this Government's very strong and abiding commitment to quality aged care policies. We have demonstrated that commitment in terms of policy provision across the whole range of services that the aged desire and need in our community. It is one that will go down, when the decade of the 1980s is written up, as something that ensured that quality aged care and the needs and services for the aged were really put on both the public agenda and the Government's priority agenda. Very strong measures have been taken, particularly in the provision of nursing home services, with respect to the extension of the quality of those nursing home services, and this Government rightly deserves great credit for its achievements in this field. I commend the Bills to the House.
