SPEECH.SPEAKER: Woods Dr R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Health Legislation (Pharmaceutical Benefits) Amendments Bill implements a number of proposals, most of which were outlined in the 1990 Budget, and, to a certain extent, follows the agreement between the Pharmacy Guild of Australia and the Government on restructuring of the pharmacy profession. The basic thrust, which the Opposition entirely supports, is to reduce fraudulent access to pharmaceuticals under the pharmaceutical benefits scheme (PBS).

SPEECH.PARA: The Bill falls broadly into three areas. The first is that it defines those who are eligible to receive pharmaceutical benefits scheme benefits and restricts those to Australian residents or specially approved persons, broadly bringing eligibility for the pharmaceutical benefits scheme into line with the eligibility for the Medicare card. Clearly, we support this part of the Bill.

Secondly, the Bill provides for a checking mechanism to see whether individuals who seek pharmaceutical benefits are, in fact, eligible for those benefits. In general terms, there are two groups that the Bill would be looking at: one is those who are resident in Australia and, therefore, eligible in general terms; and the other is those who are eligible under the concessionary entitlements-pensioners and the like-who are now able to receive drugs at the subsidised $2.50 charge rather than at the maximum $15 charge.

We have a number of problems with this part of the Bill. Firstly, the checking procedure is effectively compulsory for all pharmacists. The reason for this is that, although it is not compulsory de facto, it will involve pharmacists who do not undertake this checking mechanism, and who subsequently find that some of the claims were not genuine, in a financial penalty. Unless they check, pharmacists run the risk of being financially penalised. Clearly, the end result is to make this a compulsory checking mechanism. Sadly, it makes pharmacists into policemen for the Health Insurance Commission (HIC). This is a role which is entirely foreign to their current view, which is that they are professional advisers on health to the community and dispensers and checkers of pharmaceutical products and other products. Quite clearly, that is a major issue with the pharmacy profession.

The second question about the checking mechanism is whether it will actually achieve the savings which the Government claims it will achieve. The estimates of the Government's potential savings in full years are some $40m. We in the Opposition are trying very hard to find out how the Government has reached this figure.

The answer seems to be that the Government has taken from the Auditor-General's report an error rate-that is, people who falsely received pharmaceutical benefits-which is slightly more than 5 per cent, and it has taken an error rate from a small sample of its own. It looked at slightly more than 1,000 scrips to see how many of those were incorrectly given subsidised benefits. I think the figure in that survey was some 3 1/2 per cent. The Government then said, `Okay, we will take a middle figure'. It seems to me that just plucking a figure out of the air-which is what the Government is really doing-is a crazy way of trying to work out what the savings to government are going to be. That is the potential saving.

The Government admits to costs of around $15m or $16m per annum. Basically, those costs relate to the cost of leasing the equipment and leasing the telephone lines. The equipment involved seems to be a swipe machine to run credit cards through-in this case, the Medicare card-together with a keyboard and some sort of screen on which to receive messages from the Health Insurance Commission computer, which is presumably based in Canberra.

Those are the actual costs which are mentioned in the document. There are a lot of costs which are not mentioned in the document. The legislation seems to conveniently forget that there are a number of other expenditures involved. It does not cost, for example, the work involved by the pharmacists. If, in fact, a Medicare swipe card-one of the new magnetic Medicare cards-is going to be acceptable to swipe through the individual's identification (ID), then the extra time involved for the pharmacist is fairly minimal.

However, it seems that the Minister for Community Services and Health (Mr Howe) is completely confused about whether that will be enough by itself, or whether, for example, the numbers of pensioner's concession cards would have to be entered manually in order to access eligibility information. The Minister was apparently unable to answer that question yesterday. It seems to me to be a sorry state of affairs when the Minister does not understand how the legislation is going to implement a particular procedure. Nonetheless, that seems to be the case.

Clearly, there are going to be problems with the costs of entering extra data. Even if we assume that everybody in the country has a Medicare card with a magnetic strip on the back that can be swiped through very quickly and conveniently, the facts of the matter are, clearly, that a number of people, when they come to the pharmacy for their scrip, will, for one reason or another, not have their Medicare card with them.

Let us assume that that figure is one in 10. If one in 10 scrips actually need to have the ID of the individual-that is, name, address and, if appropriate, a social security number-entered in manually, then what are the costs involved? At present, the Health Insurance Commission offers that as a service to pharmacists who want to bill their patients via the HIC bureau. The HIC-which is doing this, I must point out, on a massive scale and therefore has a reduction in costs associated with the scale-charges 22c per entry, per scrip. If one in 10 scrips are unaccompanied by a Medicare swipe card-even assuming that everybody has a Medicare swipe card-then the cost involved, the 22c per scrip, amounts to several million dollars again.

The Pharmacy Guild estimates that potential extra costs to the scheme, which will initially be borne by the pharmacists, are some $12m just for entry alone. If one associates that with an interview of the patient to see whether he or she is the person he or she claims to be and also has to discuss some of the other matters related to this legislation, the Guild claims that, conservatively, the extra costs will be some $60m.

We must understand, of course, that if that is the case then the pharmacists are not going to be keen to bear that cost themselves. The next time a tribunal examines the remuneration of the pharmacy profession, we could bet our bottom dollar that there will be a claim in there for a minimum of $12m extra. It may well go much higher, in line with the $60m. If we get that and we are trying to save a potential total of $40m-which, at best, is rather dubious anyway-then we have to ask ourselves whether the sums add up.

We can also add in a number of other factors, such as the fact that, even if the Medicare cards are used as ID, we have to bear in mind that there are at present some 17 million Medicare cards. Another 9 million of the new magnetic Medicare cards are being issued; but, at the same time, the other 17 million cards are not being withdrawn. We have a potential 26 million cards for a population in Australia of some 17 million people. Clearly, there are a number of cards floating around which are not going to be necessarily held by the person who should be holding them. For example, my own wife has three Medicare cards. She got a Medicare card for herself. When we had our first baby, she got another one and when she had her second baby she was sent another one-without asking for it. I hasten to add that I think my wife is entirely trustworthy and that these will not be used in a fraudulent manner. Nonetheless, there are other people in society who may not be so scrupulous and who may, as has been made clear, sell their Medicare cards on the black market, where they are used both to obtain scrips from doctors and services from doctors and also, presumably, potentially to obtain extra pharmaceutical benefits to which they are not entitled.

Similarly, this system will not stop people borrowing a friend's card-if the friend happens to be a pensioner, for example-and using that to obtain the pharmaceutical benefits. The whole problem is exacerbated when there is no destruction of outdated Medicare cards. I urge the Government, as I have in other fora, to make sure that the whole system is tightened up.

There are a number of other questions. Clearly there are doubts about potential savings, there are doubts about the costs involved in achieving those savings, and there are also doubts about whether, even if the costs are negligible, the identification program as planned will result in true savings by eliminating fraud. We have major doubts about all these issues. As a result, we would make sure that we refer clause 7 and clause 11, which provide access to the Commission's computer system, to the appropriate Senate to investigate whether the financial considerations are such that the legislation will result in savings to the Government, and also whether the safeguards for privacy are adequate.

This brings me to the next problem: what happens to the privacy information? We have had concerns since the program was first announced last August that there was a potential for misuse. For example, the information that will be entered will include two types of information. From the Medicare card, of course, there will be access to individuals' Medicare rebates and therefore the types of services that are offered, such as operations or even abortions. From the PBS information now entered there will be information about their pharmaceutical history-for example, whether they have been receiving psychiatric treatment in terms of pharmaceutical drugs. Potentially, of course, if we marry those, there is a lot of very personal and private information available.

We understand there have been assurances that that will not be the case, that the databases will not be matched. We are happy to accept that. On the other hand, we are concerned that there is no mention of this in the legislation. I understand that the Privacy Commissioner has issued a number of guidelines. I have seen those guidelines and in principle I am happy with them, but I would be much happier if that privacy question were addressed within the legislation. It is a vitally important matter, particularly if that sort of information is being matched with social security numbers, which in turn are matched to tax file numbers, however indirectly that may be at present.

The legislation also provides for other issues to be addressed. For example, if the individual patient is not eligible, which most commonly would relate to somebody coming from overseas, then the question arises as to what the pharmacist charges. The information we received from the Minister initially was that he would be allowed to charge market prices, that is, whatever was appropriate in a given situation. In fact, of course, that is the correct approach. Clearly there should be an allowance for pharmacists to charge whatever is appropriate.

However, this legislation does not say that. This legislation says that the price the pharmacist can charge for non-eligible patients under the PBS is limited to the Commonwealth price. There is no reason for that whatsoever. The only possible reason, which is somewhat far fetched, is that if the HIC computer in Canberra makes a mistake and somebody is deemed to be ineligible who subsequently proves to be eligible, then the Government may have to pay more to match up to the market price to fill in the gap than it would if it matched up to the Commonwealth price. Apart from that, there is no reason for this whatsoever.

I have to say, to be blunt about it, that it is pure socialism. There is no justification for imposing these sorts of restraints upon a free market, which is what we are actually talking about in terms of the pharmaceutical products for people who come from overseas, for a product which is not subsidised by the Government in any way and which the pharmacist is not subsidised to dispense. There can be no justification for imposing this cap upon the amount the pharmacist is allowed to charge.

There are other provisions in the legislation that make it essential, in fact compulsory, for pharmacists to utilise the computerised claims transmission system (CTS) to submit their dispensing claims. With a few exemptions, such as those in isolated pharmacies or those with power supply difficulties, it will be compulsory for every pharmacy to install a computer and use the CTS system. Let me say at the beginning that I understand this is obviously a very efficient system, efficient not only for the HIC but also, by and large, for most pharmacies, except where they happen to be very small. I have to say that I think most sensible pharmacists would choose to use this particular system.

Having said that, there is a difference between what may be sensible and this imposition, this requiring of pharmacists who may not want to purchase a computer and the appropriate software-I understand the costs involved are around $10,000-when in their own judgment it may not be appropriate. This clearly would apply in particular to a number of individuals who may have a small turnover of pharmaceutical products. That element of compulsion is abhorrent to us, even though it may be a sensible thing on a market basis for the pharmacist to do.

We have received legal advice that the compulsion to use the CTS is ultra vires in terms of the Government, and also that the imposition of a 22c charge, which is what the Government plans for those people who have to use the Health Insurance Commission bureau to enter their data, is also beyond the power of the Government to impose. So it will be interesting to see whether that stands up to any challenge that may be instituted by the Pharmacy Guild. I mention in passing that the Pharmacy Guild now does have major concerns about the extra workload involved in this pharmaceutical benefits legislation.

I foreshadow that, on the basis of what I have discussed, we will move a number of amendments. We will, for example, oppose clause 10 (2) (b), which limits the amount pharmacists can charge for non-benefits items. We will oppose clause 14, which makes it compulsory to submit claims via the CTS. As I mentioned, we will refer clause 7 and clause 11 to the appropriate Senate committee to investigate both the financial aspects and the privacy aspects of the checking system.

We will also move an amendment so that determinations by the Minister become disallowable by adding to clause 17, which relates to instruments that are disallowable, any determination under subsection 98c (1) of the National Health Act. This is a similar amendment to that which has been foreshadowed by my colleague the honourable member for Dawson (Mr Braithwaite) in relation to another aspect of this same Bill. It ensures that determinations by the Minister become disallowable and therefore are placed under the scrutiny of Parliament, as, of course, is only right and fair.

Let me say in summary that whilst we support the thrust of this legislation we have major doubts about whether it will achieve its financial objectives. We do object to some of the compulsion elements in the legislation and the fact that pharmacists are not only being used to perform extra unpaid work but are also being forced to act as policemen for the Government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newell Mr N.J.

TALK.START.PARA: -I also thank the Opposition for its support of the Health Legislation (Pharmaceutical Benefits) Amendment Bill 1991, even though it is a little qualified and does contain some foreshadowed amendments. The changes spelled out in the Bill before the House tonight and foreshadowed in the industry statement in March are another example of this Government's commitment to micro-economic reform. The changes spelled out by the Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services (Mr Staples) in his second reading speech demonstrate the Hawke Labor Government's commitment to revise, to refine and to reform not only in the interests of Australia as a whole but also in the interests of individual Australians.

SPEECH.PARA: The provisions in this Bill are a good example of what this Government is all about. People on the other side of the House are always shouting about not saving money, yet the provisions of this Bill exemplify what is happening all the time. The Minister has pointed out the savings that will accrue to this nation from the implementation of these changes. The $40m saving for the Australian community is $40m that can be applied to a better use in the interests of all Australians in other areas. The $40m a year saved is like putting in a plug to stop a great leak-in this case the waste of taxpayers' resources by the prescribing and giving of concessions to people who should not be entitled to them.

We are talking about changes that will prevent people receiving concessions to which they are not entitled at cost to Australian taxpayers. Of course, the objection will be made that people will be frightened and intimidated by the changes, and I think some of the comments of the shadow Minister, the honourable member for Lowe (Dr Bob Woods), alluded to this situation. I am not sure that some of his comments did not add to it as well.

The Minister has always pointed out there is no big deal; pharmacists do not have to use the on-line facilities. In many cases, probably in most, the chemists will know the people they are dealing with and will know their genuineness, so will not have to run identity checks to allow them to access the system. The scheme to be introduced protects both the honest customer, the pharmacist and Australian taxpayers from being ripped off. Already I have heard comment from the other side that the Bill discriminates against the elderly and the infirm. That is absolute rubbish. Firstly, the elderly and the infirm are those most likely to be known by their pharmacist. Secondly, the Bill refers not just to one group but to all those who seek benefits and concessions. Thirdly, such a claim is patronising senior citizens.

There have always been, and always will be, changes, and these changes will affect both young and old. People do cope and will cope. Their biggest hurdle is often to overcome the disinformation fed to them by pressure groups for their own political and sometimes financial gain. There have been and will be big changes implemented in our society in pursuit of better services and the targeting of those most in need, and in the interest of seeing that taxpayers are not ripped off by the unscrupulous and the dishonest. People will understand that these changes, like others before them, are for the good of the community, and they will accept them.

The Government has provided safeguards so that people's privacy is completely safeguarded. The privacy issues raised by any checking procedure must remain of concern to us all. We all need to remain vigilant to ensure that the privacy of ordinary Australians is completely safeguarded from unscrupulous people who would use information for their own advantage. The Government has taken the privacy issues in this matter very seriously. That is why it has taken such a long time to work through the processes. The provisions of the Bill now ensure that at the point of supply the pharmacist will be provided with a tool that will guarantee payment and provide sufficient information to know that and no more. The Privacy Commissioner has indicated that he is satisfied that both the customer and the information are completely safeguarded by the present provisions spelled out in the Bill now before the House. I have great faith in the pharmacists of this country. Like general practitioners, they always look after their people. A recent announcement indicates that the Pharmacy Guild of Australia is now working with the Government to implement the scheme.

Essentially, this Bill contains a very simple proposal. Through a simple mechanism, a pharmacist will use a Medicare card, a name or a Department of Social Security number to establish eligibility for pharmaceutical benefits. The Health Insurance Commission will immediately throw up one of four responses: the patient is entitled to free benefits; the patient is to be charged at the concessional rate; the patient is to be charged at the general rate; or the patient is not recorded. In many cases, if not most, the pharmacists may not even choose to check because they know their customers.

The Government is adamant that patients would receive their full entitlements-no more and no less. It has been argued elsewhere that, where a customer is not entitled to a pharmaceutical benefit, chemists should be able to charge whatever they like. That is not possible under this scheme. The shadow Minister for social security in his address also pointed this out. He made the great disclaimer that it was socialism at its best.

TALK.START.PARA: —Worst!

—I thank the honourable member for Lowe for his comment. The price for a no-benefit prescription is limited to the price of the drug, plus a 10 per cent mark up and a dispensing fee. Under the provisions of this Bill the pharmacist is precluded from charging private prescription rates. These provisions are not put in place to protect the hapless American or Japanese tourist, but to protect those in our society who are powerless and perhaps inarticulate and confused and who walk into a pharmacy and are not able to establish their eligibility for pharmaceutical benefits. The price they pay will be limited to the price for which the pharmacist is guaranteed payment by the Australian Government.

SPEECH.PARA: This Bill will save the taxpayers of Australia real money. Taxpayers have a right to expect that from a government which is committed to micro-economic reform in the interests of this nation. To oppose such reform is not only to oppose a Budget initiative, but is also to condone the bleeding away of scarce dollars by people who think it is okay to rip off money because it only comes from the Government. I ask the Opposition, when it moves its amendments to this Bill in its qualified support, to consider that the Australian taxpayers are entitled to know where their money is going and that the Government is responsible for handling those funds on behalf of the Australian taxpayers and people in need.

When one walks into a financial institution to obtain funds, it is a simple fact that one is required to have some degree of identification. It is only fair that the Government, in assuring the people of Australia that it is responsibly handling the finances of this nation, also expects people, when they walk into a pharmacy to obtain benefits provided at cost to other Australian taxpayers, clearly identify themselves to ensure that the benefit they receive from being resident in this great country is handled responsibly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McGauran Mr P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Last week I presented to the Parliament a petition bearing some 250 signatures calling on the Pharmaceutical Benefits Authority to place hormone replacement therapy (HRT) on the free list. While the exact number of women affected cannot accurately be calculated, medical practitioners number them in the thousands or tens of thousands.

SPEECH.PARA: However, I very much fear that I am getting ahead of myself: I wish to tell a story about a particular concern with the pharmaceutical benefits scheme (PBS) by way of an excellent letter written by one of my constituents, Mrs Gail Liddell, of Longford in Gippsland, which she asked me to forward to Mr Brian Howe, as the Federal Minister for Community Services and Health. I have advised Mrs Liddell that Minister Howe is almost certain to pass on her concerns regarding the PBS to the Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services (Mr Staples), who has more direct responsibility under the ministerial arrangements for this area. I had best read into the Hansard Mrs Liddell's letter because it sets out so well the background and the problems being encountered in regard to hormone replacement therapy. The letter is addressed to Brian Howe:
Dear Mr. Howe,

It is with increasing concern that I write to you as Minister for Health concerning the anomaly that currently exists in the essential availability of hormone replacement implants for women in this country.

Obviously, Hormone Replacement Therapy (HRT) is a sensitive subject but public ignorance of its application has compounded the issue and perhaps prevented health authorities from making an informed decision as to HRT implants being available on the Pharmaceutical Benefits free listing scheme.

From previous enquiries, much confusion and deferral has occurred between the P.B.A. and the manufacturer `Organon' with the ultimate result leaving the consumer frustrated and locked into a `Catch 22' situation.
Firstly, let me summarise the need for HRT in the form of implants:-

For a woman's body to function normally following surgical procedure to remove her reproductive system (complete hysterectomy/oophorectomy), replacement of these hormones is, of course, essential. However, to be effective, Oestrogen/Testosterone in tablet form is inadequate and this necessitates replacement of these hormones in a slow release form by means of an implant inserted under the skin which will relieve effects of hormone depletion for 3-6 months. Should this process not be undertaken, the following effects on a woman's body can, and do, occur:-
- Gradual development of osteoporosis (bone loss) and consequent risk of fractures.
- Increased incidence of heart disease and stroke
- Severe mood swings
- Depression
- Sleeplessness
- Increased urinary frequency and difficulty with bladder control
- Hot flushes
- Short term memory loss
- Frequent headaches
- Blurred vision
- And some comparatively minor symptoms.
The costs involved in each implant are costly, i.e.:-
Oestrogen: up to $150 per implant (depending on strength required) Testosterone/Progestogen (in the form of Androgen): up to $50 per implant

None of these costs are recoverable from any Medical or Health Benefits Fund-including, of course, Medicare. The regularity of treatment varies for the individual but generally occurs at 3-6 monthly intervals and can therefore cost any individual woman in excess of $1100 per year (only the Doctor's fee is claimable). As you can see, bearing in mind that this procedure may be necessary for women from the relatively young age of 30, the overall and ongoing essential treatment cost is expensive and has the potential of becoming socially discriminatory.

Upon consultation with the Managing Director of `Organon', the sole company that manufactures and distributes implants in Australia, I am informed that the cost of producing the implants in England, bringing them to Australia and distributing them more than justifies the price the company is charging. However, upon each request to have products free listed with P.B.A., they have been asked to `at least halve costs in most cases', making it totally infeasible and uneconomic to even lodge a request to have HRT implants free-listed, as P.B.A. offer no price exercise.

I also questioned `Organon' as to their approach to the P.B.A.C. Pricing Authority within the Dept. of Health (who advise me they would be interested and flexible). `Organon' feels the Pricing Authority is guided by Consumer Price Indexing prices and, based on experience, cannot guarantee that the manufacturer will receive price increases in relation to CPI and that Dept. of Health are unprepared to negotiate prices.

The bottom line, it appears, is that the manufacturer have previous listed products upon request from P.B.A. and have been given the option of accepting 33% of listed price or removing product from market.

As an overview, and certainly from a consumer's viewpoint, I cannot help but feel the Government's interest is elsewhere than the health and welfare of the Australian community and seek justification in the availability of HRT implants on the PBA free-list.

Although I present a petition to reinforce the public's and my firm conviction that HRT implants should be free-listed to halt the social and sexual discrimination, I have no doubt that `Organon's' response will be refusal to apply for free-listing on the grounds of `uneconomic viability of the proposition'.

I seek your assistance in enabling this product to be free-listed or, alternatively, enable a rebate through `Medicare'; however I feel that as soon as another company takes the initiative to commence either manufacture or import, all implant applications will be unquestionably PBA listed without manufacturers having to endure the uneconomic restrictions placed by authorities in a wonderful country that otherwise leads the world in many other fields of medicine.
Yours sincerely,
Gail Liddell

In preparation for my contribution to the debate on the legislation before the House, I considered writing my own speech, but I kept coming back time and again to Gail Liddell's own letter to the Minister for health and reached the obvious conclusion that I certainly cannot add to it or improve upon it. I do regard, as does Gail Liddell and so many other women who suffer a problem of hormone replacement therapy, the reading out of this plea to the Minister for health as a necessity. I certainly look forward to either his reply or that of the Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services to what is an obviously despairing need.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid The Hon N.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to make a contribution to the Health Legislation (Pharmaceutical Benefits) Amendment Bill because the Bill understates and underestimates the role of pharmacists in many areas of Australia, particularly in country areas of Australia. For many of us, it is the first point of contact when we feel a bit off colour. I dare say that every honourable member in this House has, at one time or another, sought assistance from a pharmacist, and generally, in most cases, that advice came free of charge, which is fairly rare in these days of professional activities. I want to be associated with the service that they do provide to the community in a purely voluntary capacity.

SPEECH.PARA: The legislation itself restricts entitlement to receive the pharmaceutical benefits scheme benefits to Australian residents or specially approved persons, and this brings it into line with the eligibility for the Medicare card. It also provides for an on-line entitlement checking device-and here we start with the black box-between the Health Insurance Commission (HIC) computer and community pharmacies to enable pharmacists to immediately check the eligibility of patients to free, concessional or general pharmaceutical benefits. It is said that the system is voluntary. However, the pharmacists will not be paid for prescriptions if the HIC records indicate a patient was not eligible for the level of subsidy claimed at the time of dispensing and the pharmacist has not checked the eligibility of the patient. The pharmacist must install and use the checking device or suffer a financial penalty. Further on, the legislation states that there will be some pharmacists exempted from this if they are in isolated locations. I am not exactly sure what `isolated' means, but I presume that the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Social Security (Mr Sciacca), who is at the table, may be able to describe what `isolated' means.

One matter that I thought would have been given some consideration would have been the pharmacist's ability to pay for the installation of the computer equipment. One would have thought that that would have been a very important criteria to ensure that the pharmacists have the ability to pay for that computer, which I understand would be about $10,000-worth. Many small country pharmacies would be looking very hard at that. In fact, I doubt whether many of them would have the ability to pay for that equipment. I think that what the Government has done is take a huge sledge-hammer to crack a walnut. The Government talks about tightening up the eligibility for pharmaceuticals and the flow of drugs to residents of other countries or overseas visitors and persons not entitled to pharmaceutical benefits. That may be some small advantage, but it puts a very heavy burden and a significant extra workload on all of the pharmacists who carry out those tasks. The pharmacists are put in the awkward position of being forced into the role of policemen. Really, that puts them in a very difficult situation with their customers. The embarrassment perhaps of customers who allege that they are entitled to the level of subsidy that they do seek, I believe, puts pharmacists in an invidious position.

Pharmacists will effectively be forced to use the checking device or run the risk of not being paid in the event that a patient is not eligible as claimed. The Government really has failed to substantiate the estimated savings from the eligibility testing-and it is talking about something like $12m in 1991-92. That is a bit of a fuzzy figure that it has estimated and, without any clarity, the Government really cannot determine exactly whether that in fact will be the net savings or not.

I am concerned about the privacy, security and separation of the data. I think that is absolutely vital. I believe that the legislation has the potential to build up a central database, as would have occurred with the Australia Card proposal, and we would want to fight that as vigorously as possible.

I do support the amendments which my colleague the shadow Minister for health, the honourable member for Lowe (Dr Woods), put forward. I am pleased that he has submitted those amendments, particularly the amendment opposing clause 14 which makes it compulsory to submit claims via the computerised transmission system. In the short time that I had available to me, I wanted to support the shadow Minister in his efforts on behalf of the pharmacists, particularly throughout country areas of Australia.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to report to the House on the matter of privilege raised last Monday by the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock). The complaint of the honourable member was based on reported statements of Mr Bill Ludwig to the effect that if certain Government members voted for the honourable member for Blaxland (Mr Keating) in the party leadership ballot, their party endorsement would be called into question.

INTERJECT.PARA: The honourable member quoted extracts from House of Representatives Practice and May's Parliamentary Practice on the questions of intimidation of members and improper influence. I am not aware of any exact precedents for the matters complained of.

Complaints of some relevance were raised in the House in 1983 and 1986. The 1983 case concerned alleged intimidation of Government members in connection with Government decisions relating to uranium mining, and the 1986 issue concerned reported statements of the then honourable member for Adelaide to do with disciplining Government members who had `caused a fuss' in connection with uranium sales.

In neither case was a motion given precedence, it being noted that Speakers of the House of Commons had expressed views to the effect that arrangements made within political parties were unlikely to give rise to matters of privilege or contempt. It was also noted that no member had claimed to have been intimidated, and reference was made to the policy of restraint in the use of the House's powers in relation to privilege and contempt.

In all parties, numerous matters arise for determination and members are subject to representations, urgings and pressure as to their positions. I repeat my view that, as a general rule, the House should not attempt to intervene in arrangements made within political parties.

Despite this, however, if any member sought the protection of the House in such matters, I believe that the House ought to seek the advice of the Committee of Privileges as to the proper course. But I do not believe that a complaint of alleged intimidation or improper influence raised by a third party is a good foundation for action in this area.

Accordingly, in the present case, as no member has used the procedures of the House to claim that he or she has been subject to intimidation or improper influence, I am not prepared to grant precedence to a motion on the complaint.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Fisher Mr P.S.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 13 May 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How many (a) males and (b) females receive unemployment benefits at the Minister's Department's offices at (i) Mildura, (ii) Swan Hill and (iii) Horsham, Vic.

(2) How many of the persons referred to in part (1) have (a) been receiving unemployment benefits for (i) fewer than and (ii) more than 12 months, (b) returned to the workforce since 1989 and are still employed and (c) undergone training programs.
(3) In the light of the new unemployment benefit procedures proposed by the Government, what is the prospect for unemployed persons in rural Australia.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howe The Hon B.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Social Security has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

(2) (b) The Department of Social Security does not hold information on the circumstances of people who have ceased receiving unemployment benefit.

(2) (c) Information relating to the number who have undergone retraining under Government schemes is not available from DSS files. All unemployment benefit recipients are required to register with the Commonwealth Employment Service and may be referred to retraining schemes by that agency.

(3) According to ABS labour force estimates, in April 1990 the rural unemployment rate was 7.1% compared with 5.9% in metropolitan areas. In April 1991 the unemployment rate was 10.3% in rural areas compared with 9.9% in the metropolitan areas. This shows that the gap between the metropolitan and non-metropolitan unemployment rate has narrowed over the 12 month period between April 1990 and April 1991 (from 1.2 percentage points to 0.4 percentage points).

A similar trend is shown using UB figures. Between March 1991 and April 1991 the number of unemployed in metropolitan areas increased by 4.2% while the number of unemployed in rural areas increased by 1.2%.

Unemployed persons in both rural and urban Australia will benefit from the provisions of the NEWSTART strategy. The NEWSTART program will lead to greater participation in employment, education and training by the unemployed and lower dependence on Commonwealth income support.

Experience with the existing NEWSTART program for long-term unemployment beneficiaries has shown that this type of intervention can produce positive results. Over the two years to February 1991, the number of long-term UB recipients declined while the total UB population increased by 151,000 (36%).

Experience with the current NEWSTART program for the long-term unemployed, with its significant formal contact between longterm unemployment beneficiaries and officers of DSS and CES and expanded labour market program opportunities, has been taken into account in developing the Newstart strategy which is to begin in July 1991. Results from a survey of the NEWSTART eligible population conducted in March 1990 found that those who received an intensive interview from DSS and CES officers were more likely to find employment and participate in a labour market program than those who did not receive an interview. The majority of those who received an interview reported that it was effective and thought that it improved their chances of gaining employment.
Expenditure on labour market programs was lifted substantially in the March 1991 Industry Statement and will continue to be monitored in the light of labour market conditions.

The Department of Social Security has recently produced a book, `Help for people in country areas', which outlines the range of Commonwealth and State Government assistance which is available to people in country areas.
